sentence: In December 1987, Congress amended the Nuclear Waste Policy Act to designate the Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository as the only site to be designated as a permanent repository for all highly radioactive wastes in the country.

name: nevada
sentence: Under the Constitution of the State of Nevada, the powers of the Government of Nevada are divided into three separate departments: the Executive, composed of the Governor of Nevada and their Cabinet, as well as other elected members of the Constitution; the Legislative, composed of the Legislative Assembly of Nevada and the Senate; and the Judicial, composed of the Supreme Court of Nevada and lower courts.

name: nevada
sentence: The Governor is the Chief Justice of Nevada, the Head of the Executive Department of the Government of the State, and the Commander-in-Chief of the State Military Forces.

name: nevada
sentence: The present governor is Steve Sisolak, Democrat.

name: nevada
sentence: The Nevada Legislative Assembly is a bicameral body divided into a Assembly and a Senator.

name: nevada
sentence: Members of the Assembly sit for two years and members of the Senate for four years.

name: nevada
sentence: The two Houses of the Nevada Legislative Assembly will be affected by the terms of office beginning in 2010, since senators and MPs/women will be limited to a maximum of 12 years in each chamber (by appointment or election that is a lifetime limit) – a provision of the Constitution that was recently confirmed by the Nevada Supreme Court in a unanimous decision.

name: nevada
sentence: Each session of the Parliament meets for a constitutional term of 120 days each odd year, or more if the Governor requests an extraordinary session.

name: nevada
sentence: On 18 December 2018, Nevada became the first in the United States with a female majority in its legislature.

name: nevada
sentence: Women hold nine of the 21 seats in the Nevada Senate and 23 of the 42 seats in the Nevada Assembly.

name: nevada
sentence: The Nevada Supreme Court is the Supreme Court of the State and the head of the judicial branch of Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: Initial jurisdiction is shared between district courts (with general jurisdiction) and courts and municipal courts (both of limited jurisdiction).

name: nevada
sentence: Appeals from district courts are addressed directly to the Nevada Supreme Court, which, in the context of a model of derogatory jurisdiction, has the discretion to refer cases to the Court of Appeal for final adjudication.

name: nevada
sentence: The cities incorporated in Nevada, known as cities, have the power to legislate on anything not prohibited by law.

name: nevada
sentence: A recent movement has begun to allow the local government to integrate the cities of Nevada to give them more flexibility and less restrictions from the Legislative Assembly.

name: nevada
sentence: The municipal councils of unincorporated cities are limited local governments created either by the local county commission or by referendum, and play a purely consultative role and do not in any way diminish the responsibilities of the county commission that creates them.

name: nevada
sentence: In 1900 the population of Nevada was the smallest of all states and was shrinking, as the difficulties of living in a "wild desert" began to prevail over the lure of money for many early settlers.

name: nevada
sentence: The historian Lawrence Friedman explained what happened after:

name: nevada
sentence: With the advent of air conditioning for the summer and the mild winters of southern Nevada, the state's fortunes began to turn around, as for Arizona, making these two states the fastest growth in the Union.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is the only state where prostitution is legal – in an approved brothel in a county that has explicitly voted to allow it.

name: nevada
sentence: It is illegal in large jurisdictions such as Clark County (which contains Las Vegas), Washoe County (which contains Reno) and the Independent City of Carson City.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada's first reputation as a "divorce paradise" stems from the fact that before the revolution of no-fault divorce in the 1970s divorces were difficult to obtain in the United States.

name: nevada
sentence: Having already legalized gambling and prostitution, Nevada has continued its tendency to strengthen its profile by adopting one of the nation's most liberal divorce laws.

name: nevada
sentence: The result was Williams v. North Carolina (1942), 317 US 287 (1942), in which the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that North Carolina should give "full faith and credit" to a divorce from Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: The Court changed its decision in Williams v. North Carolina (1945), 325 United States 226 (1945), stating that a State did not need to recognize a divorce in Nevada unless one of the parties was domiciled there at the time the divorce was granted and the forum State had the right to make its own decision.

name: nevada
sentence: In 2009, Nevada's divorce rate was above the national average.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada's tax laws are aimed at attracting new residents and businesses to the state.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada does not have personal or corporate income tax.

name: nevada
sentence: As Nevada does not collect income data, it cannot disclose this information to the federal government, the IRS.

name: nevada
sentence: The state sales tax (similar to VAT or GST) in Nevada varies according to the county.

name: nevada
sentence: The state-wide tax rate is 6.85% and five counties (Elko, Esmeralda, Eureka, Humboldt and Mineral) charge this amount.

name: nevada
sentence: Counties may charge additional rates through the approval of electors or through the approval of the state's legislature; as a result, the applicable sales tax varies from 6.85 per cent to 8.37 per cent (Clark County).

name: nevada
sentence: Clark County, which includes Las Vegas, imposes four separate county option taxes in addition to the state-wide rate: 0.25% for flood control, 0.50% for public transit, 0.25% for infrastructure, and 0.25% for more cops.

name: nevada
sentence: In Washoe County, which includes Reno, the sales tax rate is 7.725 per cent, due to the flood control county option rates, the ReTRAC railway trench project and public transit, and an additional county rate approved under the Local Government Tax Act, 1991.

name: nevada
sentence: The minimum rate of sales tax in Nevada changed on July 1, 2009.

name: nevada
sentence: The housing tax rate in the unincorporated Clark County, which includes the Las Vegas Band, is 12%.

name: nevada
sentence: Within the boundaries of Las Vegas and Henderson, the housing tax rate is 13%.

name: nevada
sentence: Companies such as Apple Inc. reportedly established investment companies and funds in Nevada to avoid paying taxes.

name: nevada
sentence: In 2009, the Nevada Legislative Assembly passed a bill to create a national register of partnerships that allows homosexual couples to enjoy the same rights as married couples.

name: nevada
sentence: In June 2015, gay marriage became lawful in Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada provides a user-friendly environment for the formation of companies, and many companies (especially in California) have formed in Nevada to take advantage of the benefits of Nevada's law.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada companies offer a great deal of flexibility to the board of directors and simplify or avoid many of the rules that are burdensome for business leaders in other states.

name: nevada
sentence: In addition, Nevada has no tax on deductibles, although it requires companies to have a licence for which the company must pay the state.

sentence: Similarly, many U.S. states have laws of wear and tear that limit the amount of interest a lender can charge, but federal law allows companies to import these laws from their home state.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada has very liberal liquor laws.

name: nevada
sentence: Bars are allowed to stay open 24 hours a day, without "last call".

name: nevada
sentence: Alcohol shops, convenience stores and supermarkets can also sell alcohol 24 hours a day and sell beer, wine and spirits.

name: nevada
sentence: In 2016, Nevada electors approved Question 2, which legislates the possession, transportation and cultivation of quantities of marijuana for personal use for adults 21 years of age and older, and authorizes the creation of a regulated market for the sale of marijuana to adults 21 years of age and older through state-licensed retail outlets.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada voters had previously approved medical marijuana in 2000 but rejected the legalization of marijuana in a similar referendum in 2006.

name: nevada
sentence: Marijuana in all its forms continues to be illegal under federal law.

name: nevada
sentence: In addition to legalizing cannabis, the laws on drugs other than alcohol are a notable exception to the libertarian principles of Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: It is remarkable to have the most severe sentences for drug addicts in the country.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada remains the only State that has yet to use mandatory guidelines on minimum penalties for possession of drugs.

name: nevada
sentence: In November 2006, Nevada voters adopted a smoking ban ("Nevada Clean Indoor Air Act"), which came into force on 8 December 2006.

name: nevada
sentence: It bans smoking in most workplaces and public places.

name: nevada
sentence: Smoking is allowed in bars, but only if the bar is not serving food, or if the bar is inside a larger casino.

name: nevada
sentence: Smoking is also permitted in casinos, certain hotel rooms, tobacco shops and brothels.

sentence: However, some companies do not comply with this legislation and the government tends not to apply it.

name: nevada
sentence: In 2011, restrictions on tobacco use in Nevada were eased for some places that only allow people 21 years of age or older inside.

name: nevada
sentence: In 2006, the crime rate in Nevada was about 24 per cent above the national average, although crime has since decreased.

sentence: Property crimes accounted for approximately 85 per cent of the total crime rate in Nevada, 21 per cent higher than the national rate.

name: nevada
sentence: The remaining 20.3 per cent were violent crimes.

name: nevada
sentence: Due to strong growth in the southern part of the state, there is a significant gap between northern and southern Nevada policy.

name: nevada
sentence: The north has long maintained control of key positions in the state government, even though the population of southern Nevada is larger than the rest of the combined state.

name: nevada
sentence: The north sees the high population of the south becoming more influential and perhaps dominant by the majority.

name: nevada
sentence: The south sees the north as the "old guard" trying to rule as an oligarchy.

name: nevada
sentence: This has aroused some resentment, however, due to an amendment to the time limit adopted by Nevada voters in 1994, and again in 1996, part of the northern grip on key positions will soon be lost to the south, leaving the north of Nevada with less power.

name: nevada
sentence: Historically, the North of Nevada has been very republican.

name: nevada
sentence: The most rural counties in the north are among the most conservative regions in the country.

name: nevada

sentence: New Hampshire has a humid continental climate (climate classification of Köppen Dfa in some areas of the south, Dfb in most states, and subarctic Dfc in some areas of the north of the highlands), with warm and humid summers, and long, cold and snowy winters.

sentence: Winters are cold and snowy throughout the state, and particularly severe in the north and mountainous areas.

sentence: Note: The percentages in the table do not add up to 100, because Hispanics are counted both by ethnicity and race, giving a higher overall number.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A Pew survey showed that the religious affiliations of New Hampshire residents were as follows: Protestants 30%, Catholics 26%, LDS (Mormon) 1%, Jews 1%, Jehovah's witnesses 2%, and non-religious 36%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A survey suggests that people in New Hampshire and Vermont are less likely than other Americans to attend weekly services and only 54% say they are "absolutely certain that there is a God" compared to 71% in the rest of the nation.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire and Vermont are also at the lowest levels among states engaged in religion.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2012, 23% of New Hampshire residents in a Gallup poll considered themselves "very religious", while 52% considered themselves "non-religious".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), the largest denominations are the Catholic Church with 311,028 members, the United Church of Christ with 26,321 members, and the United Methodist Church with 18,029 members.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2016, a Gallup Poll found that New Hampshire was the least religious in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Only 20% of New Hampshire respondents rated themselves as "very religious," while the national average was 40%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates that New Hampshire's total revenue in 2018 was $86 billion, ranking 40th in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The median household income in 2017 was 74,801, the fourth highest in the country (including Washington, D.C.).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its agricultural products include dairy products, nurseries, cattle, apples and eggs.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its industrial products are machines, electrical equipment, rubber and plastic products, and tourism is a major component of the economy.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire underwent a major change in its economic base during the 20th century.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Historically, the base was made up of traditional New England textiles, footwear manufacturing and small machine shops, taking advantage of low-wage labour from nearby small farms and Quebec regions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Today, of the total value of the state manufacturing dollar, these sectors contribute only 2% for textiles, 2% for leather goods and 9% for machining.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: They have experienced a sharp decline due to obsolete plants and the attractiveness of cheaper wages in the southern United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire now has a broad-based and growing economy, with a government GDP growth rate of 2.2% in 2018.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The government's main economic sectors in 2018, based on its contribution to GDP, are: 15% of real estate and leasing and leasing; 13% of professional business services; 12% of manufacturing; 10% of government and government services; and 9% of health and social services.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state budget for the 2018 fiscal year was $5.97 billion, including $1.79 billion in federal funds.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The question of taxation is controversial in New Hampshire, which has a property tax (under municipal control) but no general sales tax or income tax.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State has tighter taxes on meals, accommodation, vehicles, business and investment income, and tolls on State roads.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Energy Information Administration, New Hampshire's energy use and per capita energy consumption are among the lowest in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Seabrook nuclear power plant near Portsmouth is the largest nuclear reactor in New England and supplied 57% of New Hampshire's electricity generation and 27% of its electricity consumption in 2017.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2016 and 2017, New Hampshire achieved more wind power than coal-fired power plants.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: About 32% of New Hampshire's electricity consumption came from renewable resources (including nuclear, hydroelectric, wind and other renewable resources).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a net exporter of electricity exporting 63 trillion British thermal units (18 TWh).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's residential electricity consumption is low compared to the national average, partly because demand for air conditioning is low during the generally mild summer months and because few households use electricity as a primary energy source for domestic heating.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Nearly half of New Hampshire's households use fuel oil for winter heating, which is one of the largest shares in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has renewable energy potential such as wind, hydro and firewood.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State does not have a general sales tax or personal income tax (the State tax, at a rate of 5%, income from dividends and interest), and the legislator has exercised tax withholding.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Efforts have been made to diversify the overall economy of the State.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The absence of a general tax system in New Hampshire has led local government authorities to have some of the highest property taxes in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the overall tax burden of the State is relatively low; in 2010, New Hampshire ranked 44th among the states in terms of the combined average tax burden of States and local authorities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In February 2010, the state's unemployment rate was 7.1%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: By October 2010, the unemployment rate had fallen to 5.4%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The (preliminary) seasonal unemployment rate in April 2019 was 2.4% based on a civilian workforce of 767,500 people and 749,000 people in employment.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's workforce accounts for 90 per cent of non-agricultural employment, 18 per cent in trade, transport and public services, 17 per cent in education and health care, 12 per cent in government, 11 per cent in professional and commercial services and 10 per cent in recreation and hospitality.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to a 2013 study by Phoenix Marketing International, New Hampshire had the eighth highest percentage of millionaire households in the United States, or 6.48 per cent of all households.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2013, New Hampshire also recorded the lowest poverty rate in the country, at only 8.7 per cent of all residents, according to the Census Bureau.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In March 2018, 86% of New Hampshire's workforce was employed by the private sector, with 53% employed by companies with less than 100 employees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Approximately 14% of private sector employees work in companies with more than 1,000 employees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to community surveys conducted by the NH's Labour Market and Employment Security Information Bureau, the most important private employers in the State are:

sentence: The State Government of New Hampshire employs about 6,100 people.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In addition, the United States Department of State employs approximately 1,600 people at the Portsmouth National Visa Centre, which processes immigration visa applications from the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Since 5 January 2017, the Governor of New Hampshire is Chris Sununu (Republic).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The two senators in New Hampshire are Jeanne Shaheen and Maggie Hassan (the two Democrats), both former governors.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The two U.S. representatives of New Hampshire dated January 2019 are Chris Pappas and Ann McLane Kuster (the two Democrats).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a state that controls alcoholic beverages, and through the State Alcohol Commission, it takes $100 million from the sale and distribution of alcohol.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is the only state in the United States that does not require adults to wear seat belts in their vehicle.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This is one of the three states that do not have a mandatory helmet law.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Constitution of the State of New Hampshire of 1783 is the supreme law of the State, followed by the revised annotated New Hampshire Statutes and the New Hampshire Code of Administrative Regulation.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: These are similar to the U.S. Federal Constitution, the U.S. Code and the Code of Federal Regulations, respectively.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a bifurcated executive power, composed of the governor and a five-member executive council that votes on government contracts worth more than $5,000 and "advises and consents" to the governor's appointments to important government positions such as department heads, all judicial functions and all requests for pardons.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire does not have a Lieutenant Governor; the Speaker acts as "interim Governor" whenever the Governor is unable to discharge his or her duties.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The legislature is called the Tribunal.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is composed of the House of Representatives and the Senate.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There are 400 representatives, making them one of the largest elected bodies in the English-speaking world, and 24 senators.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Legislators receive a nominal salary of $200 a year, the lowest in the United States by far, so most are indeed volunteers, nearly half of whom are retirees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: (For details, see the article on Government of New Hampshire.)

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The only court of appeal in the state is the Supreme Court of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Superior Court is the court of general jurisdiction and the only court which provides for the trial of jurors in civil or criminal matters.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Other State courts are the Probation Court, the District Court and the Family Division.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There are 10 counties and 234 towns and villages in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a "Dillon Rule" state, i.e. the state retains all powers not specifically granted to municipalities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Despite this, the legislator is strongly in favour of local control, particularly with regard to land-use regulations.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The municipalities of New Hampshire are classified as cities, which differ mainly by form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most cities usually operate according to the form of government of municipal assemblies, where registered voters in the city act as municipal legislatures, and a selection board acts as the city's executive.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The major cities and the thirteen cities of the State operate either in the form of a council, in the form of a council, in the form of a council, or in the form of a mayor.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There is no difference, from the point of view of the state government, between cities and cities, apart from the form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: All state laws treat all municipalities in the same manner.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a small number of unincorporated areas called grants, locations, purchases or cantons.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: These sites are limited to the lack of self-government, and services are generally provided by neighbouring cities or the county or state if necessary.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2000 census, there were 25 persons left in New Hampshire, a total population of 173 (from 2000), many of whom were completely depopulated.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: All but two of these areas are in Coos County.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democratic Party and the Republican Party are the two largest parties of the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A plurality of electors are registered as undeclared, and can choose one or the other vote in the primary, and then regain their undeclared status after the vote.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Libertarian Party obtained official party status from 1990 to 1996.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There is also a program known as the Free State project to transform New Hampshire into a libertarian bastion by suggesting that libertarians move there to concentrate their power.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Libertarian Party regained access to the ballot papers after the 2016 election because the candidate for governor's office won more than 4% of the vote.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of February 5, 2016, there were 882,959 registered voters, of whom 389,472 (44.1%) had not declared affiliation to a political party, 262,111 (29.7%) were Republicans and 231,376 (26.2%) were Democrats.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is known internationally for the primary school in New Hampshire, the first primary in the quadrennial cycle of the US presidential elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: State legislation requires the Secretary of State to hold this election at least one week before any "similar event".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the Iowa caucus preceded the New Hampshire primary.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This first competition, which uses the same procedure as the general election, attracts more attention than in other States, and it has been decisive in the development of the national competition.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: State law allows a city with fewer than 100 inhabitants to open its polling stations at midnight, and to close its offices when all registered citizens have voted.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: For example, the communities of Dixville Notch in Coos County and Hart's Location in Carroll County, among others, chose to implement these provisions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Dixville Notch and Hart's Location have traditionally been the first places in New Hampshire and the United States to vote in primary and presidential elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Appointments for all other partisan functions are made at separate primary elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the presidential election cycles, this is the second primary election in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Saint Anselm College in Goffstown has become a popular campaign place for politicians as well as several national presidential debates due to its proximity to Manchester-Boston Regional Airport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the past, New Hampshire had often voted republican.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Between 1856 and 1988, New Hampshire voted six times for the Democratic presidential ticket: Woodrow Wilson (twice), Franklin D. Roosevelt (three times) and Lyndon B. Johnson (once).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: From 1992 onwards, New Hampshire became a state rotating in national and local elections and, at that time, supported the Democrats in all presidential elections, with the exception of 2000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It was the only state in the country to move from the support of Republican George W. Bush in the 2000 election to that of his democratic opponent in the 2004 election, when John Kerry, a senator from neighbouring Massachusetts, won the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Democrats dominated the New Hampshire elections in 2006 and 2008.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2006, the Democrats won both seats in the Congress (elected Carol Shea-Porter in the first district and Paul Hodes in the second), re-elected Governor John Lynch, and won a majority on the Executive Council and in both chambers for the first time since 1911.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats had not held both the parliament and the office of governor since 1874.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Neither of the U.S. senators was in a position to vote in 2006.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2008, the Democrats retained their majorities, their government and their seats in Congress, and former Governor Jeanne Shaheen beat outgoing Republican John E. Sununu for the U.S. senator in a retake of the 2002 competition.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 2008 elections resulted in women holding a majority of 13 of the 24 seats in New Hampshire Senatte, a first for any legislative body in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the mid-term elections of 2010, the Republicans made historic gains in New Hampshire, capturing veto-proof majorities in the state's legislature, taking the five seats on the Executive Council, electing a new US senator, Kelly Ayotte, winning the two seats in the US Chamber of Deputies, and reducing the margin of victory of outgoing Governor John Lynch over his 2006 and 2008 victories.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2012 parliamentary elections, the Democrats took over the House of Representatives of New Hampshire and reduced the Republican majority in the New Hampshire Senate to 13-11.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2012, New Hampshire became the first state in U.S. history to elect an all-female federal delegation: Carol Shea-Porter, Congressional District 1 Democratic Member of Parliament, and Ann McLane Kuster, U.S. District 2 Member of Parliament.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Senator Jeanne Shaheen and Senator Kelly Ayotte in 2013.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In addition, the State elected its second female governor: the Democrat Maggie Hassan.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2014 election, the Republicans took over the House of Representatives of New Hampshire with a majority of 239 to 160 and increased their majority in the New Hampshire Senate to 14 of the 24 seats in the Senate.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: At the national level, outgoing senator Jeanne Shaheen beat her Republican challenger, former Senator Scott Brown of Massachusetts.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire also elected Frank Guinta (R) as its representative from the first district of Congress and Ann Kuster (D) as its representative from the second district of Congress.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2016 elections, the Republicans held the House of Representatives of New Hampshire with a majority from 220 to 175, and held their 14 seats in New Hampshire Senator.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the gibernatory race, outgoing governor Maggie Hassan was replaced by Republican Chris Sununu, who defeated Democratic candidate Colin Van Ostern.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Sununu became the first republican governor of the state since Craig Benson, who left his post in 2005 following the defeat of John Lynch.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Republicans control the governor's office and the two chambers of the state legislature, a trifecta of government in which the Republicans have the full power of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the presidential race, the state voted for the Democratic candidate, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on the Republican candidate, Donald Trump, by a margin of 2,736 votes, or 0.3%, one of the closest results the state has ever seen in a presidential race, while libertarian candidate Gary Johnson obtained 4.12% of the votes.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats have also won a race in competition in the second district of Congress, as well as a race in the Senate.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The parliamentary delegation in New Hampshire currently consists exclusively of democrats.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: At the 116th Congress of the United States, it is one of the only eight states with a fully democratic delegation, five of which are in New England (the others are Delaware, Hawaii and New Mexico).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a well-maintained and well-signed network of interstate highways, American highways and state highways.

sentence: Several road numbers line up with the same road numbers in neighbouring states.

sentence: The numbering of state roads is arbitrary, without a global system, as for American and inter-state systems.

sentence: New Hampshire has 25 public airports, three of which are served by regular passenger service.

sentence: The busiest airport is Manchester-Boston Regional Airport and Londonderry, which serves the Boston Metropolitan Area.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Amtrak's Vermonter and Downeaster lines provide toll rail passenger service.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Greyhound, Concord Coach, Vermont Translines and Dartmouth Coach all provide interurban connections to and from points in New Hampshire and to long-distance points beyond and between them.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2013, MBTA Commuter Rail based in Boston reached only northern Massachusetts.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire Rail Transit Authority is working to expand the Lowell Capital Corridor (Massachusetts) service to Nashua, Concord and Manchester, including the Manchester-Boston Regional Airport; and the Haverhill Coastal Corridor (Massachusetts) service to Plaistow, New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2007, the Act created the New Hampshire Rail Transit Authority (NHRTA) to oversee the development of commuter trains in the State of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2011, Governor John Lynch vetoed HB 218, a bill passed by Republican legislators, which would have considerably reduced the powers and responsibilities of NHRTA.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The I-93 corridor study suggested a railway alternative along the Manchester and Lawrence branch line that could provide freight and passenger services.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This railway corridor would also have access to Manchester-Boston Regional Airport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Eleven public transit authorities operate local and regional bus services around the State and eight private carriers operate express bus services that connect the national long distance bus network.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire Department of Transportation operates a state-wide match-sharing service, in addition to an independent journey matching program and a guaranteed return program.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The tourist railways include Conway Scenic Railroad, Hobo-Winnipesaukee Railroad and Mount Washington Cog Railway.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Freight railways in New Hampshire include Claremont & Concord Railroad (CCRR), Pan Am Railways via Springfield Terminal Railway (ST), New England Central Railroad (NHR, St. Lawrence and Atlantic Railroad (SLR) and New Hampshire Northcoast Corporation (NHN).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The first public secondary schools in the State are the secondary school for boys and the secondary school for girls in Portsmouth, founded in 1827 or 1830 according to the source.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has more than 80 public secondary schools, many of which serve more than one city.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The largest is Pinkerton Academy in Derry, which is owned by a private non-profit organization and serves as a public high school in several nearby cities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There are at least 30 private secondary schools in the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is also home to prestigious preparatory university schools such as Phillips Exeter Academy, St. Paul's School, Proctor Academy, Brewster Academy and Kimball Union Academy.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2008, the state was on an equal footing with Massachusetts as having the highest scores on SAT and ACT standardized tests given to high school students.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The following sports teams are located in New Hampshire:

sentence: Loudon's New Hampshire Motor Speedway is an oval circuit that has been visited by national motorsport championships such as NASCAR Cup Series, NASCAR Xfinity Series, NASCAR Camping World Truck Series, NASCAR Wholen Modified Tour, American Canadian Tour (ACT), Champ Car and IndyCar series.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Other racing sites include Star Speedway and New England Dragway in Epping, Lee Speedway in Lee, Twin State Speedway in Claremont, Monadnock Speedway in Winchester and Canaan Fair Speedway in Canaan.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has two universities at NCAA Division I in all college sports: Dartmouth Big Green (Ivy League) and New Hampshire Wildcats (America East Conference), as well as three NCAA Division II teams: Franklin Pierce Ravens, Saint Anselm Hawks and Southern New Hampshire Penmen (Northeast-10 Conference).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most other schools compete with NCAA Division III or NAIA.

sentence: Every year since 2002, all the high school stars compete against Vermont in ten sports in the playoffs "Twin State".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the spring, the numerous sap houses in New Hampshire hold open houses.

sentence: In the summer and early fall, New Hampshire hosts numerous county fairs, the most important being the Hopkinton State Fair in Contoocook.

sentence: The New Hampshire Lakes region is home to many summer camps, particularly around Lake Winnipesaukee, and is a popular tourist destination.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Peterborough Players have performed every summer in Peterborough since 1933.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Tamworth Barnstormers Theatre, founded in 1931, is one of the oldest professional theatres in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In September, New Hampshire hosted the Highland Games in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has also registered an official tartan with the competent authorities in Scotland, used to make kilts worn by the Lincoln Police Department while its agents serve during the games.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In winter, the ski resorts and snowmobile trails in New Hampshire attract visitors to a vast area.

sentence: After the freezing of the lakes, they become dotted with fishing ice cubes, known locally as bobhouses.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Funspot, the world's largest video arcade (now called a museum), is in Laconia.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's eminent personalities include founding father Nicholas Gilman, Senator Daniel Webster, revolutionary war hero John Stark, editor Horace Greeley, founder of Christian science religion Mary Baker Eddy, poet Robert Frost, astronaut Alan Shepard, rock musician Ronnie James Dio, author Dan Brown, actor Adam Sandler, inventor Dean Kamen, actors Sarah Silverman and Seth Meyers, restorers Richard and Maurice McDonald, and President Franklin Pierce of the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is a state in the Northeast Atlantic region of the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is bordered to the north and east by New York State; to the east, south-east and south by the Atlantic Ocean; to the west by Delaware River and Pennsylvania; and to the southwest by Delaware Bay and Delaware State.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the fourth smallest state by region, but the 11th most populous, with 8,882,190 residents in 2019 and an area of 8,722.58 square miles, making it the most populous of the 50 U.S. states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The capital is Trenton, while the biggest city is Newark.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All but one of New Jersey's counties are located in the combined statistical areas of New York City or Philadelphia; as a result, the largest metropolitan area of the state is in Greater New York.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was inhabited for the first time by Amerindians for at least 2,800 years, with Lenape as the dominant group at the time of the arrival of Europeans in the early 17th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch and Swedish settlers founded the first European colonies in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The British then took control of the area, naming it Province of New Jersey – after the largest of the Channel Islands, Jersey – and granting it as a colony to Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley, the 1st Baron Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was the scene of several important battles during the American Revolutionary War.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 19th century, factories in the cities of Camden, Paterson, Newark, Trenton, Jersey City and Elizabeth contributed to the country's industrial revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The central location of New Jersey in the northeast megalopolis fuelled its rapid growth and suburbanization in the second half of the 20th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: At the turn of the 21st century, the state's economy became increasingly diverse, while its multicultural population began to return to more urban areas within the state, surpassing the growth of the suburbs since 2008.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2020, New Jersey had the largest number of millionaires per capita in all U.S. states, with 9.76% of households — more than 323,000 out of 3.3 million — meeting the criteria.

name: new_jersey
sentence: According to 2017 data, this was the second poorest U.S. state according to median household income.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's public education system is consistently ranked among the 50 or best states in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Approximately 180 million years ago, during the Jurassic period, New Jersey was bordered by North Africa.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The pressure of the collision between North America and Africa was the cause of the Appalachians.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About 18,000 years ago, ice age produced glaciers that reached New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As the glaciers retreated, they left Lake Passaic behind, as well as many rivers, marshes and gorges.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was originally established by Amerindians, with Lenni-Lenape dominant at the time of contact.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Scheyichbi is Lenape's name for the country that is now New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Lenapes were several self-governing groups engaged in corn farming to complete their hunting and harvesting in the area surrounding the Delaware River, the Lower Hudson River, and the western Long Island Strait.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Lenape society was divided into matrilineal clans based on common female ancestors.

name: new_jersey
sentence: These clans were organized into three distinct phratries identified by their animal sign: turtle, Turkey and wolf.

name: new_jersey
sentence: They first met the Dutch at the beginning of the seventeenth century, and their main relationship with Europeans was the fur trade.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch became the first European to claim land in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch colony of New Netherlands consisted of parts of modern states of the Middle Atlantic.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although the European land ownership principle was not recognized by the Lenape, Dutch West India Company's policy required its settlers to purchase the land they settled.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The first one to do so was Michiel Pauw who established a patroness named Pavonia in 1630 along the northern river which eventually became the Bergen.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The purchase by Peter Minuit of land along the Delaware River established the colony of New Sweden.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The entire region became a territory of England on 24 June 1664, after an English fleet under Colonel Richard Nicolls sailed in what is now the port of New York and took control of Fort Amsterdam, annexing the entire province.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the English Civil War, Channel Island of Jersey remained loyal to the British Crown and gave the sanctuary to the king.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It was from the royal square of Saint-Hélier that Charles II of England was declared king in 1649, following the execution of his father, Charles I.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The North American lands were divided by Charles II, who gave to his brother, the Duke of York (later King James II), the area between New England and Maryland as an exclusive colony (as opposed to a royal colony).

name: new_jersey
sentence: James then granted land between the Hudson River and the Delaware River (the land that would become New Jersey) to two friends who had remained faithful during the English Civil War: Sir George Carteret and Lord Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The region was called the Province of New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Since the establishment of the state, New Jersey has been characterized by ethnic and religious diversity.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Congregationalists in New England settle alongside Scottish Presbyterians and Dutch Reformed immigrants.

name: new_jersey
sentence: While the majority of residents lived in cities with 100-acre (40 ha) individual lands, some wealthy owners owned large properties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The English Quakers and the Anglicans had large land properties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Unlike Plymouth Colony, Jamestown, and other colonies, New Jersey was populated by a second wave of immigrants from other colonies instead of those who migrated directly from Europe.

name: new_jersey

sentence: It provides for a bicameral legislature of New Jersey, consisting of a 40-member Senator in the Upper House and a general assembly of the 80-member Lower House.

sentence: The Superior Court of New Jersey is divided into the Law and Chancery Divisions at trial level; the Law Division hears both criminal and civil cases where the plaintiff's main remedy is damages, while the Chancery Division hears family cases, civil suits where the plaintiff's main remedy is a fair remedy, and probation proceedings.

sentence: New Jersey is the only state in the nation where elected county officials are called "Freeholders", which governs each county on its own board of directors of the elected Freeholders.

sentence: The number of free owners in each county is determined by referendum and must be composed of three, five, seven or nine members.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Depending on the county, executive and legislative functions may be exercised by the board of directors of the free shareholders elected or divided into different branches of government.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 16 counties, the members of the board of directors of the selected Freeholders perform legislative and executive functions on a commission basis, with each freeholder responsible for a department or group of departments.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the other five counties (Atlantic, Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Mercer), there is a directly elected county executive who performs executive functions while the board of directors of the selected free shareholders retains a legislative and supervisory role.

sentence: In undirected counties, a county administrator (or county director) may be hired for the day-to-day administration of county functions.

name: new_jersey

name: new_jersey
sentence: From the twentieth century onwards, largely driven by reform objectives, a series of six modern forms of government was implemented.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This began with the Walsh Act, promulgated in 1911 by the New Jersey Legislative, which provided for a three or five-member non-partisanly elected commission.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The 1923 Municipal Director Act, which offered a non-partisan council, provided for a weak mayor elected by and among council members, and introduced a government structure to manage municipal affairs with a manager appointed for day-to-day administration.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Faulkner Act, originally enacted in 1950 and largely amended in 1981, provides for four basic plans: the mayor-counsel, the council-manager, the small municipality and the mayor-counsel-administrative.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Act offers many choices to communities that prefer strong executive and professional management of municipal affairs and provides great flexibility to allow municipalities to choose the characteristics of their government: the number of seats on the council; the seats selected in general, by neighbourhoods or by a combination of the two; staggered or concurrent mandates; and a mayor chosen by the council or directly elected by voters.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Most large municipalities and the majority of New Jersey residents are governed by municipalities with Faulkner Charters Act.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Municipalities may also formulate their own unique form of government and operate under a Special Charter with the approval of the Legislative Assembly of New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although municipalities retain their name derived from the types of government, they may have changed for one of the modern forms of government, or even more so in the past for one of the other traditional forms, leading to municipalities whose formal names are rather disconcerting for the general public.

sentence: New Mexico (in Spanish: Nuevo México) is a state in the southwestern United States of America, whose capital is Santa Fe, founded in 1610 as the capital of Nuevo México (it was established as the province of New Spain in 1598), while its largest city is Albuquerque with its accompanying metropolitan area.

sentence: It is one of the mountain states and shares the Four Corners area with Utah, Colorado and Arizona.

sentence: New Mexico is also bordered by the state of Texas to the east-southeast, Oklahoma to the northeast, and the Mexican states of Chihuahua to the south and Sonora to the southwest.

sentence: With an estimated population of 2,096,829 as of July 1, 2019, the U.S. Census Bureau estimates New Mexico as the 36th state by population.

sentence: With a total area of 121,590 m2 (314,900 km2), it is the fifth largest and sixth smallest densely populated of the 50 states.

sentence: Republicans traditionally have their strongholds in the east and south of the state, in the Farmington area, in Rio Rancho and in the newly developed areas of North-West Mesa.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The north-eastern heights of Albuquerque have always focused on the Republicans, but have become a key sector for the Democrats in the last electoral cycles.

name: new_mexico
sentence: While registered democrats are more numerous than Republicans registered by nearly 200,000, New Mexico's voters favored moderate to conservative candidates from both parties at the state and federal levels.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico abolished its death penalty law, but not retroactively, as of 1 July 2009.

name: new_mexico
sentence: This means that people on New Mexico's death row can still be executed.

name: new_mexico
sentence: On March 18, 2009, then Governor Bill Richardson signed the law abolishing the death penalty in New Mexico after the vote in the assembly and the Senate the previous week, becoming the 15th U.S. state to abolish the penalty.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With respect to firearms control, New Mexico may have some of the country's least restrictive firearms laws.

name: new_mexico
sentence: State law prevents all local arms control orders.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico residents can purchase a firearm that is deemed legal under federal law.

name: new_mexico
sentence: There is no waiting period under state law to pick up a firearm after it has been purchased, and there are no restrictions on the capacity of magazines.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In addition, New Mexico is a "responsible" state for hidden transport permits.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Before December 2013, New Mexico's law did not expressly authorize or prohibit same-sex marriage.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The policy on the issuance of marriage permits to same-sex couples has been determined at the county level, that is, some county clerks have issued marriage permits to same-sex couples, while others have not.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In December 2013, the Supreme Court of New Mexico issued a unanimous decision ordering all county clerks to issue marriage permits to same-sex couples, making New Mexico the 17th state to recognize same-sex marriage across the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Due to its relatively small population, combined with many federally funded research institutions, New Mexico had the highest concentration of doctoral students in any state in 2000.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Despite this, the State regularly ranks at the bottom of the scale in the quality surveys of primary and secondary education.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In a landmark decision, a state judge ruled in 2018 that "New Mexico violates the constitutional rights of students at risk by failing to provide them with sufficient education" and ordered that the Governor and the Legislative Assembly provide an adequate system by April 2019.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico has a higher concentration of people who do not complete high school or have a college without a diploma than the nation as a whole.

name: new_mexico
sentence: For the State, 23.9% of people over the age of 25 went to university but did not graduate.

name: new_mexico
sentence: This proportion is compared to 21.0% of the country as a whole, as estimated by the American Community Survey of the United States Census Office 2014.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Los Alamos County has the largest number of post-secondary graduates in any county in New Mexico, with 38.7% of the population (4,899 people) estimated by the American Community Survey 2010-2014.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Department of Public Education of New Mexico supervises the operation of primary and secondary schools.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is one of eight states that fund university scholarships through the state lottery.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The state of New Mexico requires that the lottery put 30% of its gross sales into the scholarship fund.The scholarship is available to residents who have graduated from a state high school, and who attend a full-time state university while maintaining a GPA of 2.5 or more.It covered 100% of tuition fees when first declared in 1996, decreased to 90% and then dropped to 60% in 2017.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Value increased slightly in 2018, and a new law was passed to indicate which funds are available by type of institution.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With an Amerindian population of 134 000 in 1990, New Mexico is an important centre of Amerindian culture.

sentence: The Apache and a few Ute live on federal reserves within the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Many new Mexicans speak a unique Spanish dialect.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Due to the historical isolation of New Mexico from other speakers of the Spanish language, part of the vocabulary of Spanish in New Mexico is unknown from other Spanish speakers.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It uses many Amerindian words for local features and includes anglicized words that express American concepts and modern inventions.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Albuquerque has the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science, the National Hispanic Cultural Center and the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History, as well as the famous Albuquerque Balloon Festival every fall.

sentence: A great arts community thrives in Santa Fe, and has included people like Bruce Nauman, Richard Tuttle, John Connell and Steina Vasulka.

sentence: The capital has several art museums, including the New Mexico Museum of Art, the Spanish Colonial Art Museum, the International Folk Art Museum, the Indian Arts and Culture Museum, the Museum of Contemporary Indigenous Arts, the Santa Fe SITE and others.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The colonies of artists and writers flourish, and the small town is full of art galleries.

sentence: In August, the city hosts the Indian market of Santa Fe, which is the oldest and largest indigenous art showcase in the world.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Performing arts include the famous Santa Fe Opera, which presents five operas in the repertoire every July to August, the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival held every summer, and the Lensic Theatre restored a main venue for many types of shows.

sentence: The weekend following the Labour Day is marked by the burning of Zozobra, a 15-metre puppet, during the Santa Fe Fiestas.

sentence: Art is also a common theme in Albuquerque, New Mexico's largest city.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The National Hispanic Cultural Center organized hundreds of artistic events, art exhibitions and other events related to Spanish culture in New Mexico and around the world in the Roy E Disney Center for the Performing Arts centre or in other locations of the 53-acre institution.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Residents and visitors to New Mexico can enjoy shows from around the world in the Popejoy Hall on the campus of the University of New Mexico.

sentence: Popejoy Hall welcomes singers, dancers, Broadway shows, other types of acts, and Shakespeare.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Albuquerque also has the unique and memorable KiMo Theater built in 1927 in the Pueblo Revival Style architecture.

name: new_mexico
sentence: KiMo presents live theatre and concerts as well as simultaneous films and operas.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In addition to other theatres of general interest, Albuquerque also has the African American Performing Arts Center and the Exhibition Hall, which showcases the achievements of people of African descent and the Indian Pueblo Cultural Center, which showcases the cultural heritage of New Mexico's First Nations.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is strongly committed to its Spanish heritage.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The old Spanish traditions such as zarzuelas and flamenco are popular in New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Flamenco dancer and native New Mexican María Benítez founded the Maria Benítez Institute for Spanish Arts "to present programs of the highest quality of Spain's rich artistic heritage, as expressed by music, dance, visual arts and other forms of art".

name: new_mexico
sentence: There is also the Internacional Flamenco Festival of Alburquerque which takes place every year during which Spanish and neo-Mexican native flamenco dancers perform at the University of New Mexico.

sentence: In the middle of the 20th century, there was a flourishing Hispano Literature School and a scholarship in English and Spanish.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The most notable authors were Angélico Chávez, Nina Otero-Warren, Fabiola Cabeza de Baca, Aurelio Espinosa, Cleofas Jaramillo, Juan Bautista Rael and Aurora Lucero-White Lea.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In addition, writer D. H. Lawrence lived near Taos in the 1920s at Ranch D. H. Lawrence, where there is a sanctuary containing its ashes.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The major Spanish, Amerindian and wild West Border motifs of New Mexico have provided equipment to many internationally recognized authors of the State, including Rudolfo Anaya and Tony Hillerman.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Silver City, in the mountains of the southwestern part of the state, was originally a mining town and at least one nearby mine still works.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It is perhaps better known today as the home or exhibition center for a large number of artists, visuals and others.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Another ancient mining town that became an art paradise is Madrid, New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It was brought to national fame as the filming location for Wild Hogs in 2007.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The city of Las Cruces, in southern New Mexico, has a museum system affiliated with the Smithsonian Institution Affiliates Program.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Las Cruces also offers a variety of cultural and artistic opportunities for both residents and visitors.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In addition to the Wild Hogs mentioned above, other films filmed in New Mexico include Sunshine Cleaning and Vampires.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The various seasons of the A&E/Netflix Longmire series have been filmed in several locations in New Mexico, including Las Vegas, Santa Fe, Eagle Nest and Red River.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The widely acclaimed Breaking Bad television show and its spin-off Better Call Saul were put and filmed in and around Albuquerque.

name: new_mexico
sentence: No major professional sports team in the league is based in New Mexico, but the Albuquerque Isotopes are a Triple-A baseball subsidiary of the Colorado MLB Rockies Pacific Coast League.

sentence: New Mexico hosts several Pecos League baseball teams: Roswell Invaders, Ruidoso Osos, Santa Fe Fuego and White Sands Pupfish.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Tom Jager, Olympic gold medallist, who is a champion of controversial high-altitude swimming training, led training camps in Albuquerque at 5,312 feet (1,619 m) and Los Alamos at 7,320 feet (2,231 m).

sentence: Raton's NRA Whittington Center is the largest and most comprehensive competitive training and shooting centre in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is a state in the northeastern United States of America.

name: new_york
sentence: It was one of the 13 colonies of origin that formed the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: With a total area of 54,555 square miles (141,300 km2), New York is the 27th largest state.

name: new_york
sentence: Its population of more than 19 million in 2019 makes it the fourth most populous.

name: new_york
sentence: Sometimes called the State of New York, it's the home of New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: Two thirds of the state's population lives in the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: With an estimated population of 8.34 million in 2019, New York City is the most populated city in the United States and the first gateway to immigration to the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: The metropolitan area of New York City is one of the most populated in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: As a world city, New York City is home to the United Nations Headquarters and has been described as the world's cultural, financial and media capital, as well as the most economically powerful city in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The other four most populated cities in the state are Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers and Syracuse, while the state capital is Albany.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has a variety of geography.

name: new_york
sentence: The state is bordered by New Jersey and Pennsylvania to the south, and Connecticut, Massachusetts, and Vermont to the east.

name: new_york
sentence: The state has a maritime border with Rhode Island, east of Long Island, and an international border with the Canadian provinces of Quebec to the north and Ontario to the northwest.

name: new_york
sentence: The southern portion of the state is located on the Atlantic coastal plain and includes Long Island and several associated small islands, as well as the City of New York and the lower Hudson River valley.

name: new_york
sentence: The larger Upstate New York area includes several ranges of larger Appalachian mountains, and Adirondack Mountains in the northeast lobe of the state.

name: new_york
sentence: The north-south of the Hudson River Valley and the east-west of the Mohawk River Valley are these more mountainous regions.

name: new_york
sentence: Western New York is considered to be part of the Great Lakes region and is bordered by Lake Ontario, Lake Erie and Niagara Falls.

name: new_york
sentence: The central part of the state is dominated by Finger Lakes, a tourist destination and popular holidays.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was inhabited by tribes of Algonquian and Iroquoian Amerindians for several hundred years when the first Europeans came to New York.

name: new_york
sentence: French settlers and Jesuit missionaries came south of Montreal to trade and proselytize.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1609 the area was visited by Henry Hudson who sailed for the Dutch East India Company.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch built Fort Nassau in 1614 at the confluence of the Hudson and Mohawk rivers, where the present capital of Albany subsequently developed.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch soon moved to New Amsterdam and parts of the Hudson Valley, establishing the multicultural colony of New Netherlands, a trade and immigration centre.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1664 England seized the colony of the Dutch.

name: new_york
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War (1775-1783), a group of settlers from New York Province tried to take control of the British colony and succeeded in establishing independence.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 19th century, the development of the interior by New York, beginning with the Erie Canal, gave it incomparable advantages over other parts of the east coast and built its political and cultural ascendant.

name: new_york
sentence: Many monuments in New York City are well known, including four of the ten most visited tourist attractions in the world in 2013: Times Square, Central Park, Niagara Falls and Grand Central Terminal.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is the home of the Statue of Liberty.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 21st century, New York became a global hub of creativity and entrepreneurship, social tolerance and environmental sustainability.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has about 200 colleges and universities, including New York State University.

name: new_york
sentence: Several of them have been ranked among the top 100 in the country and the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The tribes of what is today New York were mainly Haudenosaunee and Algonquian.

name: new_york
sentence: Long Island was divided roughly in two between Wampanoag and Lenape.

name: new_york
sentence: Lenape also controlled most of the area surrounding the port of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: North of Lenape was a third Algonquin nation, the Mohicans.

name: new_york
sentence: To the north of them, from east to west, were three Iroquoian nations: the Mohawks, the original Iroquois, and the Petuns.

name: new_york
sentence: To the south of them, divided about along Appalachia, were Susquehannock and Erie.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the Wampanoag and Mohican peoples were caught in the war of King Philip, a joint effort of many tribes of New England to repel Europeans from their land.

name: new_york
sentence: After the death of their leader, Chief Philip Metacomet, most of these peoples fled to the interior of the country, dividing themselves into Abenaki and Schaghticoke.

name: new_york
sentence: Many Mohicans remained in the area until the 1800s, however, a small group known as Ouabano migrated southwest to Western Virginia at an earlier time.

name: new_york
sentence: They may have merged with the Shawnee.

name: new_york
sentence: The Mohawk and Susquehannock were the most militaristic.

name: new_york
sentence: In trying to stop trade with Europeans, they targeted other tribes.

name: new_york
sentence: The Mohawks were also known for refusing white colonization on their land and banishing any people who converted to Christianity.

name: new_york
sentence: They represented a major threat to the Abenakis and Mohicans, while the Susquehannock briefly conquered the Lenape in the 1600s.

name: new_york
sentence: The most devastating event of the century, however, was beaver wars.

name: new_york
sentence: Between 1640 and 1680, the Iroquoian peoples conducted campaigns ranging from modern Michigan to Virginia against the Algonquian and Siwan tribes, as well as between them.

name: new_york
sentence: The goal was to control more land for the trapping of animals, a career that most Aboriginal people had turned to in the hope of first trading with whites.

name: new_york
sentence: This completely changed the ethnography of the region, and most of the big game was hunted before the whites fully exploded the land.

name: new_york
sentence: After that, the Iroquois Confederation offered shelter to refugees from the Muscouten, Erie, Chononton, Tutelo, Saponi and Tuscarora nations.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 1700s, they also merged with the Mohawks during the Franco-Indian war and took to the remaining Susquehannock of Pennsylvania after being decimated in the war.

name: new_york
sentence: Most of these other groups came together until they ceased to exist.

name: new_york
sentence: Then, after the Revolution, a large group of them split up and returned to Ohio, becoming known as Mingo Senatorca.

name: new_york
sentence: The six current tribes of the Iroquois Confederation are the Senatorca, Cayuga, Onondaga, Oneida, Tuscarora and Mohawk.

name: new_york
sentence: The Iroquois fought for both sides during the Revolutionary War

name: new_york
sentence: Today, the Iroquois still live on several reserves in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Meanwhile, the Lenapes established a close relationship with William Penn.

name: new_york
sentence: However, when Penn died, his sons managed to take over much of their land and banish it to Ohio.

name: new_york
sentence: When the United States drafted the Indian Removal Act, the Lenapes were moved to Missouri, while their cousins, the Mohicans, were sent to Wisconsin.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition, in 1778, the United States moved Nanticoke from the Delmarva Peninsula to the former Iroquois lands south of Lake Ontario, although they did not stay long.

name: new_york
sentence: They mostly chose to migrate to Canada and merge with the Iroquois, although some moved westward and merged with the Lenapes.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1524, Giovanni da Verrazzano, an Italian explorer serving the French crown, explored the Atlantic coast of North America between the Carolinas and Newfoundland, including New York Harbor and Narragansett Bay.

name: new_york
sentence: On 17 April 1524 Verrazzano entered New York Bay, passing through the strait now called the Narrows in the north bay which he called Santa Margherita, in honour of the sister of the king of France.

name: new_york
sentence: Verrazzano described it as "a vast coastline with a deep delta in which every type of ship could pass" and added: "that it extends inside for a league and opens to form a beautiful lake.

name: new_york
sentence: This vast water table warmed up with native boats."

name: new_york
sentence: He landed on the tip of Manhattan and perhaps the furthest point of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: Verrazzano's stay was interrupted by a storm that pushed him north in the direction of Martha's Vineyard.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1540, French traders from New France built a castle on Castle Island in the current Albany; it was abandoned the following year due to flooding.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1614 the Dutch, under Hendrick Corstiaensen's command, rebuilt the French castle, which they called Fort Nassau.

name: new_york
sentence: Fort Nassau was the first Dutch settlement in North America and was located along the Hudson River, also in the present Albany.

name: new_york
sentence: The little fort serves as a trading post and warehouse.

name: new_york
sentence: Located on the floodplain of the Hudson River, the rudimentary "strong" was swept away by flooding in 1617, and abandoned for good after the construction of Fort Orange, New Newfoundland, near in 1623.

name: new_york
sentence: Henry Hudson's voyage of 1609 marks the beginning of European engagement in the region.

name: new_york
sentence: Sailing for the Dutch East India Company and looking for a passage in Asia, he entered Upper New York Bay on September 11 of that year.

name: new_york
sentence: His findings encouraged Dutch traders to explore the coast in search of a profitable fur trade with local American Aboriginal tribes.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 17th century, Dutch trading posts were established for the trade of hides from the Lenape, Iroquois and other tribes in the colony of New Netherlands.

name: new_york
sentence: The first of these trading posts was Fort Nassau (1614, near Albany today); Fort Orange (1624, on the Hudson River, just south of the present town of Albany and created to replace Fort Nassau), developing in the Beverwijck settlement (1647), and in what became Albany; Fort Amsterdam (1625, to develop in the city of New Amsterdam which is now New York City); and Esopus (1653, now Kingston).

name: new_york
sentence: The success of Rensselaerswyck (1630), which surrounded Albany and lasted until the mid-19th century, was also a key factor in the colony's initial success.

name: new_york
sentence: The English captured the colony during the Second Anglo-Dutch War and governed it as the province of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The city of New York was taken over by the Dutch in 1673 during the third Anglo-Dutch war (1672–74) and renamed New Orange.

name: new_york
sentence: He returned to the English under the Treaty of Westminster a year later.

name: new_york
sentence: The Sons of Liberty were organized in New York during the 1760s, largely in response to the oppressive Stamp Act adopted by the British Parliament in 1765.

name: new_york
sentence: The Congress of the Stamps Act met in the city on 19 October of the same year, composed of representatives of all the thirteen colonies that paved the way for the Continental Congress.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stamp Act Congress resulted in the Bill of Rights and Grievances, which was the first written expression by American representatives of many of the rights and complaints subsequently expressed in the Declaration of Independence of the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: That included the right to representative government.

name: new_york
sentence: At the same time, given the close commercial, personal and sentimental ties with Britain, many residents of New York were loyalists.

name: new_york
sentence: The capture of Fort Ticonderoga provided the cannon and gunpowder necessary to force a British withdrawal from the siege of Boston in 1775.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was the only colony not to vote for independence, since delegates were not allowed to do so.

name: new_york
sentence: New York subsequently endorsed the Declaration of Independence on 9 July 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: The Constitution of the State of New York was framed by a convention that met in White Plains on July 10, 1776, and after repeated adjournments and change of location, concluded its work in Kingston on Sunday evening, April 20, 1777, when the new constitution drafted by John Jay was adopted with a single dissenting voice.

name: new_york
sentence: It has not been submitted to the people for ratification.

name: new_york
sentence: On July 30, 1777, George Clinton was inaugurated as the first governor of New York City in Kingston.

name: new_york
sentence: About a third of the battles of the American Revolutionary War took place in New York; the first major (and largest of the whole war) was the Battle of Long Island, a.k.a.

name: new_york
sentence: The Battle of Brooklyn in August 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: After their victory, the British occupied the city of New York, making it their military and political base of operations in North America throughout the conflict, and hence the centre of interest of General George Washington's intelligence network.

name: new_york
sentence: Of the famous British prison ships in Wallabout Bay, more American fighters have died of intentional negligence than of being killed in combat in every battle of the combined war.

name: new_york
sentence: Both sides of the fighters lost more soldiers due to illness than to pure injuries.

name: new_york
sentence: The first of the two great British armies was captured by the Continental Army at the Battle of Saratoga in 1777, a success that influenced France to join the revolutionaries.The state constitution was promulgated in 1777.

name: new_york
sentence: New York became the 11th state to ratify the United States Constitution on July 26, 1788.

name: new_york
sentence: In an attempt to maintain sovereignty and remain an independent nation positioned between the new United States and British North America, four of the Iroquois nations fought on the British side; only the Oneida and their dependents, the Tuscarora, joined the Americans.

name: new_york
sentence: In retaliation for the attacks on the border by the Mohawk forces of Joseph Brant and Loyalist, the Sullivan expedition in 1779 destroyed nearly 50 Iroquois villages, adjacent agricultural land and winter shops, forcing many refugees to travel to the British-held Niagara.

name: new_york
sentence: As British allies, the Iroquois were forced to leave New York, even if they had not participated in treaty negotiations.

name: new_york
sentence: They settled in Canada after the war and received territorial concessions from the Crown.

name: new_york
sentence: In the settlement of the treaty, the British handed over most Indian lands to the new United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Since New York entered into a treaty with the Iroquois without Congress' approval, some land purchases have been the subject of land claims by federal-recognized tribes since the late 20th century.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has sold more than 5 million acres (20,000 km2) of ancient Iroquois territory in the years following the revolutionary war, leading to rapid development in northern New York.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the Treaty of Paris, the last vestige of British authority in the Thirteen former colonies – their troops in New York – disappeared in 1783, which was long celebrated as a day of evacuation.

name: new_york
sentence: The City of New York was the national capital under the statutes of Confederation and the Perpetual Union, the first national government.

name: new_york
sentence: This organization was found to be insufficient, and prominent New Yorker Alexander Hamilton advocated a new government that would include an executive, national courts and the power to impose.

name: new_york
sentence: Hamilton led the Annapolis Convention (1786), which called for the Philadelphia Convention, which drafted the Constitution of the United States, in which he also participated.

name: new_york
sentence: The new government had to be a strong federal government to replace the relatively weak confederation of each state.

name: new_york
sentence: Following a lively debate, which included the publication of the now quintessential constitutional interpretation — The Federalist Papers — as a series of episodes in New York's newspapers, New York was the 11th state to ratify the United States Constitution on 26 July 1788.

name: new_york
sentence: New York remained the national capital under the new constitution until 1790 and was the site of the inauguration of President George Washington, the drafting of the United States Bill of Rights and the first session of the United States Supreme Court.

name: new_york
