sentence: It is estimated that 2.7 million households with residents aged 5 years and older speak Spanish.

name: new_york
sentence: Chinese, Slavic and French languages were the largest languages spoken by households in 2018.

name: new_york
sentence: The majority of New York's religious population is Christian (60%), followed by irreligious (27%), Judaism (7 %), Islam (2 %), Buddhism and Hinduism (1% each) and other denominations (0.5%).

name: new_york
sentence: Before the 1800s Protestant sects dominated New York's religious life, although religion did not play as important a role in Nova Scotia's public life as it did in New England with its Puritan population.

name: new_york
sentence: Historically, New York served as the foundation for new Christian confessions in the second great revival.

name: new_york
sentence: Non-Western Christian traditions and non-Christian religions did not grow for much of the State's history because immigration was mainly from Western Europe (which at the time was dominated by Western Christianity and favoured by quotas in federal immigration law).

name: new_york
sentence: The Immigration and Nationality Act 1965 abolished quotas, allowing for the growth of other religious groups.

name: new_york
sentence: The Roman Catholic Church is the largest Christian denomination in New York City (31%).

name: new_york
sentence: The largest Catholic diocese is the Archdiocese of the Latin Church in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The largest Eastern Catholic diocese is the Ruthenian Catholic eparchy of Passaic of the Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church.

name: new_york
sentence: The United Methodist Church is the largest main Protestant denomination and the second most important on the whole, followed by the Episcopal Church in the United States and other continuing Anglican organizations.

name: new_york
sentence: The Presbyterian Church (USA), the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, and the American Baptist Church were the following major confessions.

name: new_york
sentence: The main Protestants together represent 11% of the state's Christians.

name: new_york
sentence: In evangelical Protestantism, Baptists, non-denominational Protestants, and Pentecostals were the largest groups.

name: new_york
sentence: The National Baptist Convention (USA) and the Progressive National Baptist Convention were the largest historically black Protestant churches in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: About 10 per cent of New York Christians are evangelical Protestants.

name: new_york
sentence: Eastern Orthodox and Eastern Orthodox collectively represented 1% of the religious population alongside Jehovah's Witnesses and other Christians.

name: new_york
sentence: Non-Christian religions represented 12 per cent of the religious population.

name: new_york
sentence: Judaism is the second most important religion since 2014.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, 588,500 of them practiced Orthodox Judaism.

name: new_york
sentence: A little over 392953 professed Islam.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is home to the oldest Zoroastrian firing temple in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Less than 1% of New York's population practices New Age and contemporary paganism.

name: new_york
sentence: Amerindian religions are also a significant minority.

name: new_york
sentence: Irreligious is a growing community in the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: In the state as a whole, 17% do nothing in particular and 5% are atheists and agnostics.

name: new_york
sentence: Approximately 3.8% of the adult population in the state identifies as lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender.

name: new_york
sentence: It is an adult LGBT population of 570,388 people.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, the number of same-sex couples was approximately 48,932.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was the fifth state to allow same-sex marriages, after New Hampshire.

name: new_york
sentence: Michael Bloomberg, Mayor of New York City, said that "homosexual marriages in New York generated approximately $259 million in economic impact and $16 million in municipal revenue" in the first year after the adoption of the Marriage Equality Act.

name: new_york
sentence: Same-sex marriages in New York were legalized on 24 June 2011 and were allowed to commence 30 days thereafter.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also has the largest transgender population in the United States, estimated at 25,000 in 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: The annual New York Pride March (or gay pride parade) crosses 5th Avenue in Manhattan, ending at Greenwich Village, and rivals the Sao Paulo Gay Pride Parade as the largest pride parade in the world, attracting tens of thousands of participants and millions of spectators on the sidewalks every June.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stonewall riots were a series of spontaneous and violent protests by members of the gay community against a police raid that took place in the early morning of June 28, 1969, at Stonewall Inn, Greenwich Village, Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: They are generally considered to be the most important event leading to the gay liberation movement and the modern struggle for LGBT rights.

name: new_york
sentence: In June 2017, plans were announced for the first official LGBT monument commissioned by the State of New York, unlike the Stonewall National Monument, commissioned by the U.S. federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: The State Monument should be built in Hudson River Park in Manhattan, near the Hudson River wharves, which have historically served as an important symbol of New York's central role as a meeting place and refuge for LGBT communities.

name: new_york
sentence: As early as 2017, New York State planned to host the largest international celebration of LGBT pride in 2019, known as Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019, to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall riots.

name: new_york
sentence: In New York, the 2019 Stonewall 50–WorldPride NYC events produced by Heritage of Pride were enhanced through a partnership with the LGBT division of the I LOVE NY program and included a reception centre during the weeks surrounding the Stonewall 50 / WorldPride events that was open to all.

name: new_york
sentence: Other commemorative, cultural and educational arts programs to mark the 50th anniversary of the rebellion at Stonewall Inn took place throughout the city and around the world; Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019 was the largest celebration of LGBT pride in history, attracting approximately five million people.

name: new_york
sentence: Brooklyn Liberation March, the largest event on transgender rights in LGBTQ history, took place on June 14, 2020, from Grand Army Plaza to Fort Greene, Brooklyn, and focused on supporting the lives of black transgender people, attracting between 15,000 and 20,000 participants.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2018, New York's gross national product amounted to $1.7 trillion.

name: new_york
sentence: If the State of New York were an independent nation, it would be the 11th largest economy in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: However, in 2013, the multi-state metropolitan statistical area, centred on the city of New York, produced a gross metropolitan product (GMP) of nearly $1.4 trillion, while in 2012, the corresponding combined statistical area produced a GMP of more than $1.7 trillion, both of which were ranked first by a broad margin and behind the GDP of only nine countries.

name: new_york
sentence: Anchored by Wall Street in Lower Manhattan's financial district, New York City was called both the most economically powerful city and the world's largest financial centre.

name: new_york
sentence: Lower Manhattan is the third largest business district in the United States and is home to the New York Stock Exchange at Wall Street and NASDAQ at 165 Broadway, which are respectively the largest and second largest stock exchanges in the world, measured both by the average volume of daily transactions and by the total market capitalization of their listed companies in 2013.

name: new_york
sentence: Wall Street investment charges amounted to approximately $40 billion in 2012, while in 2013, senior managers of New York City banks who manage risk management and compliance functions earned up to $324,000 per year.

name: new_york
sentence: During the 2013–14 fiscal year, the Wall Street securities sector generated 19% of New York's tax revenues.

name: new_york
sentence: The city of New York remains the world's largest trading centre in the public capital and debt markets, partly under the influence of the size and financial development of the American economy.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also the leader in hedge fund management

name: new_york
sentence: Several investment banks and investment managers based in Manhattan are major participants in other global financial centres.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also the largest commercial banking centre in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the largest media conglomerates in the world are also based in the city.

name: new_york
sentence: Manhattan had about 520 million square feet (48.1 million square feet) of office space in 2013, making it the largest office market in the United States, while Midtown Manhattan is the nation's largest central business district.

name: new_york
sentence: Silicon Alley, centered in New York, has become a metanym of the sphere encompassing the high-tech and entrepreneurship ecosystem of the New York metropolitan area; in 2015, Silicon Alley generated more than $7.3 billion in venture capital investments.

name: new_york
sentence: High-tech industries, including digital media, biotechnology, software development, game design and other areas in the field of information technology, are growing, supported by New York's position at the terminus of several transatlantic fibre optic lines, its intellectual capital, as well as its growing external wireless connectivity.

name: new_york
sentence: In December 2014, the State of New York announced a $50 million venture capital fund to encourage companies working in the field of biotechnology and advanced materials; according to Governor Andrew Cuomo, start-up money would make it easier for entrepreneurs to market their research.

name: new_york
sentence: On December 19, 2011, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his choice of Cornell University and Technion-Israel Institute of Technology to build a $2 billion college of applied science on Roosevelt Island in Manhattan to transform New York into the world's first technological capital.

name: new_york
sentence: Albany, Saratoga County, Rensselaer County, and the Hudson Valley, collectively recognized as the Eastern New York Technology Valley, have experienced significant growth in high-tech computer hardware, with major advances in nanotechnology, digital electronics design, and the manufacture of microchip integrated circuits dependent on water and electricity, including companies such as IBM and its Thomas J. Watson Research Center, and the three foreign companies, GlobalFoundries, Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor.

name: new_york
sentence: The region's high-tech ecosystem is supported by technology-based academic institutions, including the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and SUNY Polytechnic Institute.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2015, Tech Valley, which straddles both sides of the Adirondack Northway and New York Thruway, generated more than $163 million in venture capital investments.

name: new_york
sentence: The Rochester region is important in the field of photographic processing and imaging as well as in the incubation of an increasingly diverse high-tech sphere encompassing STEM domains, as well as the results of private start-up companies working with major academic institutions, including the University of Rochester and Cornell University.

name: new_york
sentence: Westchester County developed a booming biotechnology sector in the 21st century, with more than $1 billion in private investment expected from 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: Creative industries, which generate and disseminate knowledge and information, such as new media, digital media, film and television production, advertising, fashion, design and architecture, account for an increasing share of employment, with the City of New York having a significant competitive advantage in these industries.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2014, the State of New York offered tax incentives of up to $420 million per year for the production of films within the state, the most generous among the U.S. states.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also attracted more visual effects jobs by increasing its tax credit to a maximum of 35% for post-film production in Upstate New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The filmed entertainment industry grew in New York, contributing nearly $9 billion to the New York economy in 2015.

name: new_york
sentence: I Love New York is a slogan, logo and state song that form the basis of an advertising campaign and has been used since 1977 to promote tourism in New York State, including New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: The logo of the brand belongs to New York State Empire State Development.

name: new_york
sentence: The Broadway League reported that Broadway programs sold approximately $1.27 billion in tickets for the 2013–14 season, an increase of 11.4% from $1.39 billion for the 2012–13 season.

name: new_york
sentence: Attendance in 2013–14 was $12.21 million, an increase of 5.5% compared to the $11.57 million in the 2012–13 season.

name: new_york
sentence: New York exports a wide variety of products such as prepared food, computers and electronics, cut diamonds and other commodities.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2007, the Government exported goods valued at $71.1 billion, the top five foreign export markets being Canada ($15 billion), the United Kingdom ($6 billion), Switzerland ($5.9 billion), Israel ($4.9 billion) and Hong Kong ($3.4 billion).

name: new_york
sentence: New York's largest imports are oil, gold, aluminum, natural gas, electricity, rough diamonds and softwood lumber.

name: new_york
sentence: The state also has a large manufacturing sector that includes clothing printing and production, primarily in New York; and furs, railway equipment, automotive parts and bus line vehicles, concentrated in Upstate areas.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the country's third largest producer of grapes, and the second largest producer of wine by volume, behind California.

name: new_york
sentence: The hills of South Finger Lakes, the Hudson Valley, the northern fork of Long Island and the southern shore of Lake Erie are the main wine-growing and wine-growing areas of New York, with many vineyards.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2012, New York had 320 wineries and 37,000 hectares of vines, generating full-time jobs for nearly 25,000 people and annual wages over $1.1 billion, and generating $4.8 billion in direct economic impact from grapes, grape juice, and wine and grape products.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York agricultural industry is an important producer on the whole, ranking among the top five states for agricultural products, including maple syrup, apples, cherries, cabbage, dairy products, onions and potatoes.

name: new_york
sentence: The State is the largest cabbage producer in the United States

name: new_york
sentence: The state owns about a quarter of its agricultural land and produced $3.4 billion in agricultural products in 2001.

name: new_york
sentence: The south shore of Lake Ontario offers the right mix of soil and microclimate for many apple, cherries, plums, pears and peaches.

name: new_york
sentence: Apples are also cultivated in the Hudson Valley and near Lake Champlain.

name: new_york
sentence: A commercial medium-sized saltwater fishery is conducted along the Atlantic side of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: The main catches are clams, lobsters, squid and folds.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, the State of New York consumed 156,370 gigawatt hours (GWh) of electrical energy.

name: new_york
sentence: The lower-state regions (Hudson Valley, New York and Long Island) consumed 66% of this amount.

name: new_york
sentence: The outermost regions produced 50% of this quantity.

name: new_york
sentence: The maximum load in 2017 was 29 699 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, resource capacity was 42,839 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: The NYISO market monitor described the overall average price of electricity as a range (a single value was not provided) from $25 per MWh to $53 per MWh in 2017.

name: new_york
sentence: At the post-secondary level, the public academic system at the national level is the State University of New York (SUNY).

name: new_york
sentence: The SUNY system consists of 64 community colleges, technical colleges, undergraduate colleges and doctoral institutions, including several universities.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's flagship university is Buffalo University, which was founded by U.S. President Billard Fillmore.

name: new_york
sentence: With Buffalo University, Binghamton University is also one of the largest public universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has its own City University of New York (CUNY), which is funded by the city.

name: new_york
sentence: Columbia University, Cornell University and New York University are among the most important higher education institutions in New York, all world-renowned private universities and members of the Association of American Universities, the first group of research universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Other notable private universities include Syracuse University and Fordham University.

name: new_york
sentence: The smallest private higher education institutions are Rockefeller University, Mercy College, New York Institute of Technology, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Yeshiva University and Hofstra University.

name: new_york
sentence: There are also a multitude of postgraduate schools in New York State, including medical, law and engineering schools.

name: new_york
sentence: West Point, the U.S. Army Service Academy, is located just south of Newburgh, on the west bank of the Hudson River.

name: new_york
sentence: The Federal Merchant Marine Academy is located in Kings Point, Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: A number of private liberal arts institutions are located in New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: These include Bard College, Barnard College, Colgate University, Hamilton College, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Marist College, Sarah Lawrence College, Skidmore College, Union College, and Vassar College.

name: new_york
sentence: Two of these schools, Barnard and Vassar, are members of the Seven Sisters elite, all originally women's schools with links to the Ivy League.

name: new_york
sentence: Barnard was affiliated with Columbia University, its neighbour in Manhattan, and Vassar became a co-educator in 1969 after refusing an offer to merge with Yale University.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also home to what is widely regarded as the best performing arts schools in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: Juilliard School, located in Manhattan's Upper West Side, is one of the largest music and dance schools in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The Eastman School of Music, a professional school at the University of Rochester, has been ranked first in American music schools by US News & World Report for five consecutive years.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State University accredits and establishes standards for primary, middle and secondary education in the State, while the New York State Department of Education supervises public schools and monitors their standard tests.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York Department of Education operates the New York public school system.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1894, reflecting general racial discrimination, the State passed a law allowing communities to set up separate schools for children of African-American descent.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1900, the State passed another law requiring the integration of schools.

name: new_york
sentence: In fiscal year 2013, New York spent more money on public education per pupil than any other state, according to U.S. Census Bureau statistics.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has one of the largest and oldest transport infrastructure in the country.

name: new_york
sentence: The engineering problems posed by the state's complex terrain and the unique infrastructure problems of New York City caused by urban congestion had to be overcome on a permanent basis.

name: new_york
sentence: The expansion of the state's population followed the path of the first waterways, first the Hudson River and the Mohawk River, and then the Erie Canal.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 19th century, railways were built along the river valleys, followed by the New York State Thruway in the 20th century.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) is the New York Government Department responsible for the development and operation of highways, railways, public transport systems, ports, waterways and air facilities in New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: The NYSDOT is headquartered at 50 Wolf Road in Colonie, Albany County.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York and New Jersey Port Authority (PANYNJ) is a joint venture between the states of New York and New Jersey and authorized by the American Congress, established in 1921 by an inter-State agreement, which oversees much of the regional transportation infrastructure, including bridges, tunnels, airports and seaports, within the geographic jurisdiction of the port of New York and New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: This harbour area of 1,500 km2 (3,900 km2) is generally covered within a 25 mi (40 km) radius of the National Monument of the Statue of Liberty.

name: new_york
sentence: The Port Authority is headquartered at the 4 World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition to the well-known New York Metro system, which is confined to the city of New York, four suburban rail networks enter and leave the city: Long Island Railway, Metro-North Railway, Port Authority Trans-Hudson and five of New Jersey Transit's railway lines.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Department of Transportation (NYCDOT) is the New York City government agency responsible for the management of much of New York's transportation infrastructure.

name: new_york
sentence: Other cities in New York City have urban and regional public transport.

name: new_york
sentence: In Buffalo, the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority manages Buffalo Metro Rail's light rail system; in Rochester, Rochester Metro operated from 1927 to 1956, but became obsolete as the state and federal government invested in highways.

name: new_york
sentence: The State Department of Motor Vehicles of New York (NYSDMV or DMV) is the government agency responsible for registering and inspecting motor vehicles and other motor vehicles, as well as issuing permits to drivers in New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2008, NYSDMV had 11,284,546 driver's licences and 10,697,644 vehicle registrations in force.

name: new_york
sentence: All gasoline vehicles registered in New York State must be inspected for emissions every 12 months to ensure that environmental quality controls are aimed at preventing air pollution.

name: new_york
sentence: Diesel-powered vehicles with a gross weight of more than 8500 pounds that are registered in most counties of Downstate New York are subject to an annual emission inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: All vehicles registered in New York State must undergo an annual safety inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: Portions of the transport system are intermodal, allowing passengers to easily switch from one mode of transport to another.

name: new_york
sentence: One of the most notable examples is AirTrain JFK, which allows rail passengers to travel directly to the John F. Kennedy International Airport terminals and the New York Metro.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York Government embodies the Government structure of the State of New York established by the Constitution of the State of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: It is composed of three branches: executive, legislative and judicial.

name: new_york
sentence: The Governor is the head of state administration and is assisted by the Lieutenant Governor.

name: new_york
sentence: The two are elected on the same ticket.

name: new_york
sentence: Other elected officials include the Attorney General and the Controller.

name: new_york
sentence: The Secretary of State, former elected leader, is currently appointed by the Governor.

name: new_york
sentence: The Legislative Assembly of the State of New York is bicameral and consists of the Senator of the State of New York and the Assembly of the State of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The Assembly consists of 150 members, while the Senate varies according to its membership, which currently has 63 members.

name: new_york
sentence: The Legislature has the power to legislate, subject to the Governor's power to veto a bill.

name: new_york
sentence: However, the veto may be cancelled by the legislator if there is a two-thirds majority in favour of winning it in each chamber.

name: new_york
sentence: General standing laws are codified in the consolidated laws of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The highest court of appeal in the unified judicial system is the Court of Appeal, whereas the first court of first instance is the County Court (or the Supreme Court of New York).

name: new_york
sentence: The Supreme Court also acts as an intermediate court of appeal for many cases, and the local courts deal with a variety of other issues, including small disputes, contraventions and local zoning issues, and are the starting point for all criminal cases.

name: new_york
sentence: The courts in New York City are the most important local justice system.

name: new_york
sentence: The State is divided into counties, cities, towns and villages, all of which are municipal corporations vis-à-vis their own governments, as well as various corporations that serve for unique purposes that are also local governments, such as school districts, fire districts and public utility corporations in New York State, often known as development authorities or corporations.

name: new_york
sentence: Each municipal corporation is given different home government powers, as provided for in the New York Constitution.

name: new_york
sentence: The state also has 10 Indian reserves.

name: new_york
sentence: There have been several movements about the secession of New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: Proposals include a State of Long Island, consisting of everything on the island outside New York; a State called Niagara, the counties of western New York State; the counties of northern New York State called Upstate New York; making New York City a State; a proposal for a new County of Peconic on the east of Long Island; and for the borough of Staten Island to separate from New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The death penalty was reintroduced in 1995 under the Pataki administration, but the law was declared unconstitutional in 2004, when the New York Court of Appeal ruled in People v. LaValle that it violated the Constitution of the State.

name: new_york
sentence: The remaining death penalty was commuted by the court to life imprisonment in 2007, in People v. John Taylor, and death row was dissolved in 2008, pursuant to an order issued by Governor David Paterson.

name: new_york
sentence: There have been no executions in New York since 1963.

name: new_york
sentence: Legislative efforts to amend the law had failed, and the death penalty was no longer required at the state level, although certain crimes falling within the federal government's jurisdiction were punishable by the federal death penalty.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is represented by Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand in the United States Senate.

name: new_york
sentence: There are twenty-seven congress districts, the third largest number of congress districts in the country, equal to Florida and behind the 53 of California and 36 of Texas.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2019, 21 districts were represented by Democratic Party members and 6 by Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Representation was reduced by 29 in 2013 due to the slowdown in the overall population growth of the State compared to national population growth.

name: new_york
sentence: New York had 29 votes in the national presidential elections, down from its 47-vote summit in 1933 to 1953.

name: new_york
sentence: The state is heavily unbalanced with the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the New York State Comptroller's Office, New York received 91 cents of services for every dollar it sent in taxes to the U.S. federal government in fiscal year 2013; New York ranked 46th in the federal balance of payments to the state on a per capita basis.

name: new_york
sentence: In April 2016, the Democrats represented a plurality of voters in New York State, more than twice as many registered voters as any other affiliation or absence of a political party.

name: new_york
sentence: Since the second half of the twentieth century, New York has generally supported Democratic Party candidates in the national elections.

name: new_york
sentence: Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama won New York State by more than 25 percentage points in 2012 and 2008.

name: new_york
sentence: New York, along with other major cities in the state, including Albany, Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers and Syracuse, are important democratic bastions, with liberal politics.

name: new_york
sentence: However, rural areas of New York State are generally more conservative than cities and tend to favour Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Suburban, densely populated areas, such as Westchester County and Long Island, have crossed the major parties since the 1980s, but most often they support the Democrats.

name: new_york
sentence: The city of New York is the largest source of political fund-raising in the United States for the two major parties.

name: new_york
sentence: Four of the nation's top five zip codes for political contributions are located in Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: The first postal code, 10021 in the Upper East Side, generated the most money for the 2000 presidential campaigns of George W. Bush and Al Gore.

name: new_york
sentence: New York State has the distinction of being the State of origin for the two major parties running for three presidential elections.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1904 presidential election saw former New York governor and outgoing president Theodore Roosevelt face Alton B. Parker, chief justice of the New York Court of Appeal.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1944 presidential election had Franklin D. Roosevelt, following the footsteps of his cousin Theodore as former governor of New York and outgoing president running for re-election against the current governor of New York Thomas E. Dewey.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 2016 presidential election, former U.S. Senator Hillary Clinton, residing in Chappaqua, was the Democratic Party candidate.

name: new_york
sentence: The Republican Party candidate was the businessman Donald Trump, a Manhattan resident and a Queens native.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is an important centre for international diplomacy.

name: new_york
sentence: United Nations Headquarters has been located on the eastern side of Midtown Manhattan since 1952.

name: new_york
sentence: The state of New York is geographically home to a National Football League team, the Bills Buffalo, based in the Buffalo suburb of Orchard Park.

name: new_york
sentence: Although the New York Giants and the New York Jets represent the New York metropolitan area and were previously located in New York City, they play at the MetLife Stadium, located in East Rutherford, New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also had two baseball teams, the New York Yankees (based in the Bronx) and the New York Mets (based in the Queens).

name: new_york
sentence: Minor league baseball teams also play in New York State, including Long Island Ducks, Brooklyn Cyclones and Staten Island Yankees, as well as Rochester Red Wings, Binghamton Rumble Ponies, Syracuse Mets, Auburn Doubledays, Batavia Muckdogs, Hudson Valley Renegades and Buffalo Bisons.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is home to three National Hockey League franchises: the New York Rangers in Manhattan, the New York Islanders in Brooklyn and Nassau County in Long Island, and the Buffalo Sabres.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has two National Basketball Association teams, the New York Knicks in Manhattan, and the Brooklyn Nets in Brooklyn.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the seat of a Major League soccer franchise, New York City FC, which currently plays in the Bronx.

name: new_york
sentence: Although the New York Red Bulls represent the metropolitan area of New York, they play in the Red Bull Arena in Harrison, New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: New York hosts the 1932 and 1980 Olympic Winter Games at Lake Placid.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1980 Games are known for the US-US ice hockey game known as the Miracle on Ice, during which a group of American students and amateurs defeated the highly favoured Soviet 4–3 national ice hockey team and won the gold medal against Finland.

name: new_york
sentence: With St. Moritz, Switzerland and Innsbruck, Austria, Lake Placid is one of three cities to host the Olympic Winter Games twice.

name: new_york
sentence: New York bid for the 2012 Summer Olympics but lost against London.

name: new_york
sentence: Several U.S. national sports halls are or have been located in New York.

name: new_york

sentence: The exclusion of the right to vote has far-reaching effects: it means that American blacks cannot be used in juries or in any local office.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After a decade of white supremacy, many people have forgotten that North Carolina has never had prosperous middle-class black Americans.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Black citizens have no political voice in the State until after the adoption of the 1964 Federal Civil Rights Act and the 1965 Voting Rights Act to enforce their constitutional rights.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It was only in 1992 that another African-American was elected American representative of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the reconstruction, North Carolina became a single-party state dominated by the Democratic Party.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state has maintained itself mainly with an economy based on tobacco, cotton textiles and commodity farming.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Large cities remained in limited numbers.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state was the place where the Wright brothers near Kitty Hawk allowed the first flight heavier than air, on December 17, 1903.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the first half of the 20th century, many African Americans left the state to go north for better opportunities, in the Great Migration.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Their departure changed the demographic characteristics of several regions.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina was hard hit by the Great Depression, but Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal programs for cotton and tobacco have greatly helped farmers.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the Second World War, the state economy grew rapidly, evidenced by the growth of cities such as Charlotte, Raleigh and Durham in the Piedmont region.

sentence: Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill form the Triangle of Research, an important field of universities and advanced scientific and technical research.

sentence: In the late 1960s, driven in part by the increasingly left-wing inclination of national democrats, the conservative whites began to vote for national Republican candidates and gradually for more republicans locally.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Greensboro Sit-ins played a crucial role in the Civil Rights Movement to bring full equality to Black Americans.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Since the 1970s, North Carolina has experienced a steady increase in population growth.

sentence: The State of North Carolina, Duke University and the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill helped the Raleigh region (Research Triangle) attract an educated workforce and create more jobs.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Tourism has also been a boom for North Carolina's economy, as people flock to the coastal areas of the outer banks and the Appalachian Mountains, anchored by Asheville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is bordered by South Carolina to the south, Georgia to the southwest, Tennessee to the west, Virginia to the north and the Atlantic Ocean to the east.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau places North Carolina in the South Atlantic division of the southern region.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina consists of three major geographic regions: the Atlantic coastal plain, which occupies the eastern part of the state; the central Piedmont region; and the western mountainous region, which is part of the Appalachians.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain includes more precisely defined areas such as the outer shores, a chain of sandy and narrow islands separated from the continent by sounds or inlets, including the Albemarle Strait and Pamlico Strait, the tidal waters region, the home of the venous flyer, and the inland coastal plain, where long-leaved pines are native.

name: north_carolina
sentence: So many ships have been lost off Cape Hatteras that the area is known as "Atlantic Caveyard"; more than a thousand ships have sunk in these waters since the records began in 1526.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The most famous of them is the revenge of Queen Anne (flagship of the Black Barbe pirate), who failed at Beaufort Inlet in 1718.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain passes to the Piedmont region along the autumn line of the Atlantic coast, the altitude at which the waterfalls first appear on streams and rivers.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Piedmont region of central North Carolina is the most populated area of the state, with the six largest cities in the state per population.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It consists of a gently sloping country often broken by low mountain hills or ridges.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Small, isolated and deeply eroded mountain ranges are located in Piedmont, including the Sauratown Mountains, Pilot Mountain, Uwharrie Mountains, Crowder's Mountain, King's Pinnacle Mountains, Brossy Mountains and the South Mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Piedmont ranges from about 91 metres in the east to about 1,500 feet (460 metres) in the west.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The western part of the state is part of the Appalachian chain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Among the sub-ranges of the Appalachians in the state are the Smoky Mountains, the Blue Ridge Mountains and the Black Mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Black Mountains are the highest in the eastern U.S. and peak at Mount Mitchell at 2684 feet (2,037 m), the highest point east of Mississippi.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has 17 important watersheds.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The five basins west of the Blue Ridge Mountains flow to the Gulf of Mexico, while the rest flow to the Atlantic Ocean.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Of the 17 basins, 11 are from the state of North Carolina, but only four are located entirely within the state border: Cap Peur, the Neus, the White Oak and the Tar-Pamlico Basin.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Elevation above sea level is the main cause of temperature change throughout the state, the mountain area being the coolest all year round.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The climate is also influenced by the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf Stream, especially in the coastal plain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: These influences tend to cause warmer winter temperatures along the coast, where temperatures fall only occasionally below freezing point at night.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain represents an average of about 2.5 cm of snow or ice per year, and there may be no snow or ice in many years.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Atlantic Ocean has less influence on the climate of the Piedmont region, which has warmer summers and colder winters than along the coast, although the maximum daily average is still less than 90°F (32°C) in most locations.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina experiences severe weather in summer and winter, with the threat of hurricanes, tropical storms, heavy rains and flooding.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The destructive hurricanes that struck North Carolina include Hurricane Fran, Hurricane Florence, Hurricane Floyd, Hurricane Hugo and Hurricane Hazel, the largest storm ever in the state, as a category 4 in 1954.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Hurricane Isabel is among the most destructive of the 21st century.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has an average of less than 20 tornadoes per year, most of which are produced by hurricanes or tropical storms along the coastal plain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Storm tornadoes are a risk, especially in the eastern part of the state.

name: north_carolina

name: north_carolina
sentence: A phenomenon known as a "cold-air dyke" often occurs in the northwestern part of the state, which can weaken storms, but can also lead to major ice events in the winter.

sentence: Thirty confirmed tornadoes fell, mainly in eastern Piedmont and Sandhills, killing at least 24 people.

sentence: In September 2019, Hurricane Dorian struck the area.

name: north_carolina

sentence: Hickory owns the Valley Hills Mall.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Piedmont Triad, or central state, houses Krispy Kreme, Mayberry, Texas Pete, Lexington Barbecue Festival and Moravian cookies.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The internationally recognized North Carolina Zoo in Asheboro attracts visitors to its animals, plants and a 57-piece art collection along five miles of shaded trails in the world's largest natural habitat park.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Seagrove, in the central part of the State, attracts many tourists along the Pottery Road (NC Hwy 705).

sentence: MerleFest in Wilkesboro attracts more than 80,000 people to its four-day music festival; and Wet 'n Wild Emerald Pointe Water Park in Greensboro is another attraction.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The outer shores and surrounding beaches attract millions of people each year to the Atlantic beaches.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The continental part of the northeastern part of the state, having recently adopted the name of inner banks, is also known as the Albemarle region, for the colonies of Albemarle, some of the first colonies in the part of the Atlantic coastal plain in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The historic sites of the regions are linked by the historic visit to the Albemarle.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina offers a wide range of recreational activities, from swimming to beach to skiing in the mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina offers autumn colours, freshwater and saltwater fishing, hunting, bird watching, agrotourism, mountain biking, hot air ballooning, climbing, cycling, hiking, skiing, navigation and sailing, camping, canoeing, gardens and arboretums.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has theme parks, aquariums, museums, historic sites, lighthouses, stylish theatres, concert halls and refined restaurants.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Northern Carolinians enjoy outdoor recreation through numerous local cycling trails, 34 state parks and 14 national parks.

name: north_carolina
sentence: National Park Service Units include the Appalachian National Scenic Trail, Blue Ridge Drive, Cape Hatteras National Marine Shore, Cape Lookout National Marine Shore, Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site in Flat Rock, Fort Raleigh National Historic Site in Manteo, Smoky Great Mountains National Park, Guilford Courthouse National Military Park in Greensboro, Moores Creek National Battlefield near Currie in Pender County, Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail, Old Salem National Historic Site in Winston-Salem, Tears National Historic Trail and Wright Brothers National Memorial in Kill Devil Hills.

name: north_carolina
sentence: National forests include the Uwharrie National Forest in Central North Carolina, the Croatian National Forest in Eastern North Carolina, the Pisgah National Forest in the Western Mountains and the Nantahala National Forest in the southwestern part of the State.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has traditions in art, music and cuisine.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The not-for-profit arts and culture industry generates $1.2 billion in direct economic activity in North Carolina, supporting more than 43,600 full-time equivalent jobs and generating $119 million in revenues for local governments and the state of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina created the North Carolina Museum of Art as the country's first large museum collection to be formed by state legislation and funding and continues to bring millions into the NC economy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: See also this list of museums in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: One of the most famous arts communities in the state is Seagrove, the capital of the artisan pottery of the United States, where artisans create artisan pottery inspired by the same traditions that began in this community more than two hundred years ago.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has a large number of remarkable jazz musicians, some of the most important in the genre's history.

name: north_carolina
sentence: These include John Coltrane (Hamlet, High Point); Thelonious Monk (Rocky Mount); Billy Taylor (Greenville); Woody Shaw (Laurinburg); Lou Donaldson (Durham); Max Roach (Newfoundland); Tal Farlow (Greensboro); Albert, Jimmy and Percy Heath (Wilmington); Nina Simone (Tryon); and Billy Strayhorn (Hillsborough).

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is also famous for its ancient music tradition, and many recordings were made in the early 20th century by folk-song collector Bascom Lamar Lunsford.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Musicians such as the North Carolina Ramblers helped solidify the sound of country music in the late 1920s, while the influential bluegrass musician Doc Watson is also native to North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Both North Carolina and South Carolina are homes for traditional rural blues, especially the style known as the Piedmont blues.

name: north_carolina

Cole, Shirley Caesar, Roberta Flack, Clyde McPhatter, Nennena Freelon, Warren Haynes, Jimmy Herring, Michael Houser, Eric Church, Future Islands, Randy Travis, Ryan Adams, Ronnie Milsap, Anthony Hamilton, The Avett Brothers and Luke Combs.

sentence: Metal and punk, such as Corrosion of Conformity, Between the Buried and Me, and Nightmare Sonata, are from North Carolina.

sentence: University conservatories and universities also produce fully staged operas, such as the A. J. Fletcher Opera Institute of the University of North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem, the Department of Music at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill and the UNC Greensboro.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A basic food for North Carolina is pork barbecue.

name: north_carolina
sentence: There are strong regional differences and rivalries on the sauces and methods used to make the barbecue.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The common trend in western North Carolina is the use of superior Boston buttocks.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Western North Carolina pork barbecue uses tomato-based sauce, and only pork shoulder (black meat) is used.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Western North Carolina barbecue is commonly referred to as Lexington BBQ after the town of La Triade du Piedmont de Lexington, the home of Lexington Barbecue Festival, which attracts more than 100,000 visitors each October.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Eastern North Carolina pork barbecue uses vinegar and red pepper sauce and the "whole pig" is cooked, incorporating both white and dark meat.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Krispy Kreme, an international donut shop chain, was founded in North Carolina; the company's headquarters are in Winston-Salem.

sentence: Pepsi-Cola was first produced in New Bern in 1898.

sentence: In 2013, Southern Living named Durham–Chapel Hill "the most beautiful city in the South."

sentence: Over the past decade, North Carolina has become a cultural epicentre and a refuge for internationally award-winning wines (Noni Bacca Winery), internationally-recognized cheeses (Ashe County), "International Institute for Gastronomic Arts: Conquer Yanks the Truffles, January 15, 2010" international hub for truffles (Garland Truffles) and beer manufacturing, as tobacco lands have been converted into grape orchards, while state laws regulating volume alcohol (ABV) in beer have allowed a jump of six to fifteen percent.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Yadkin Valley in particular has become a strengthening market for grape production, while Asheville recently won recognition for being named "Beer City USA".

name: north_carolina
sentence: Asheville has the highest number of breweries per capita in any city in the United States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The beer brands recognized and marketed in North Carolina are Highland Brewing, Duck Rabbit Brewery, Mother Earth Brewery, Weeping Radish Brewery, Big Boss Brewing, Foothills Brewing, Carolina Brewing Company, Lonerider Brewing and White Rabbit Brewing Company.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has extensive pasture areas for beef and dairy cattle.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Truck farms are in North Carolina.

sentence: A truck farm is a small farm where fruits and vegetables are grown for sale on local markets.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Government's shipping, commercial fishing and softwood lumber industries are important to its economy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Services industries, including education, health care, private research and retail, are also important.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Research Triangle Park, a large industrial complex located in the Raleigh-Durham region, is one of the largest electronics and medical research centres in the country.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Tobacco was one of the first major industries to grow after the civil war.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Many farmers cultivated a little tobacco, and the invention of cigarettes made the product particularly popular.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Winston-Salem is the birthplace of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company (RJR), founded by R.J. Reynolds in 1874.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1914, it sold 425 million packages of camels per year.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Today, it is the second largest tobacco company in the United States (behind the Altria Group).

name: north_carolina
sentence: RJR is an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of Reynolds American Inc., which in turn is owned by 42% of British American Tobacco.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Several ships have been named according to the state, the most famous USNorth Carolina in the Pacific Ocean theatre of the Second World War.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Now disused, she's part of the USNorth Carolina Battleship Memorial in Wilmington.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Another U.S. North Carolina nuclear attack submarine was commissioned in Wilmington on 3 May 2008.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Crown maintains a group of protected areas, known as the North Carolina State Park System, which is managed by the North Carolina Division of Parks & Recreation (NCDPR), an agency of the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources (NCDENR).

name: north_carolina
sentence: Fort Bragg, near Fayetteville and Southern Pines, is a large and comprehensive military base and is the headquarters of the XVIIIth Airborne Corps, the 82nd Airborne Division and the Special Operations Command of the U.S. Army.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The air wing of Fort Bragg is Pope Field, also near Fayetteville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Located in Jacksonville, Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune, combined with the nearby Marine Corps Air Station (MCAS) bases Cherry Point, MCAS New River, Camp Geiger, Camp Johnson, Stone Bay and Courthouse Bay, is the largest concentration of Marines and sailors in the world.

name: north_carolina
sentence: MCAS Cherry Point is home to 2 Wing marine aircraft.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Located in Goldsboro, Air Force Base Seymour Johnson hosts 4 Wing Fighters and 916 Wing Air Refuelling.

name: north_carolina
sentence: One of the busiest U.S. Coast Guard air stations is at the Coast Guard Air Station in Elizabeth City.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Also stationed in North Carolina is the military terminal of Sunny Point Ocean in Southport.

name: north_carolina
sentence: On January 24, 1961, a B-52G broke out in the open and crashed after suffering a serious loss of fuel near Goldsboro, dropped two nuclear bombs without detonation.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2013, it was revealed that three single-bomb security mechanisms had failed, leaving only one low-voltage switch preventing detonation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is a state of the U.S. Midwest.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It bears the name of the Amerindian tribes Lakota and Dakota Sioux, which represent a large part of the population and historically dominate the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the nineteenth largest in the region, the fourth least populated, and the fourth least populated in the 50 states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its capital is Bismarck, its biggest city is Fargo.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was admitted to the Union on 2 November 1889, as well as its neighbouring State, South Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They were the 39th and 40th States admitted to union.

name: north_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison modified the state documents before signing them so that no one would know what became a state first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For ease of reference, both states are officially numbered in alphabetical order.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, the natural resources of North Dakota played a major role in its economic performance, including the extraction of oil from the Bakken Formation, located under the north-western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This has led to population growth and a reduction in unemployment, which has led North Dakota to the second lowest unemployment rate in the nation (after Hawaii).

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is home to the highest man-made structure in the Western Hemisphere, the KVLY-TV mast.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located in the Upper Midwest area of the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It lies in the centre of the North American continent and borders Canada to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The geographic centre of North America is near the city of Center.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck is the capital of North Dakota, and Fargo is the largest city in the country.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Land is the most precious resource in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the basis of the State's great agricultural wealth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota also has enormous mineral resources.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These mineral resources include billions of tonnes of lignite.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, North Dakota has large reserves of oil.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Oil was discovered in the state in 1951 and soon became one of the most valuable mineral resources in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 2000s, the emergence of hydraulic fracturing techniques enabled mining companies to extract huge amounts of oil from the formation of Bakken shale rocks in the western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota economy relies more on agriculture than on the economies of most other states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many North Dakota plants process agricultural products or produce agricultural equipment.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many of the state's merchants also depend on agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Farms and ranches cover almost the entire North Dakota area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They stretch from the flat valley of the Red River to the east, through the hilly plains, to the rugged Badlands to the west.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The main crop, wheat, is grown in almost every county.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota harvests more than 90 per cent of the canola and flax of the nation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is also the largest domestic producer of barley and sunflower seeds and a leader in the production of beans, honey, lentils, oats, peas and sugar beets.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Few white settlers arrived in the North Dakota region before the 1870s because the railways had not yet entered the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 1870s, the North Pacific Railway began to cross the Dakota territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Large-scale agriculture also began during the 1870s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Eastern societies and some families have established huge wheat farms covering vast tracts of land in the Red River valley.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The farms made huge profits as they were called Bonanza Farms.

name: north_dakota
sentence: White settlers, attracted by the success of the Bonanza farms, flocked to North Dakota, rapidly increasing the territory's population.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1870, there were 2,405 people in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1890 the population was 190,983.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was named for the Sioux who once lived on the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Sioux were called Dakota or Lakota, meaning allies or friends.

name: north_dakota
sentence: One of the nicknames in North Dakota is the Peace Garden State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This nickname honours the International Garden of Peace, located on the state border with Manitoba, Canada.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is also known as the state of Flickr because of the numerous land squirrels (Richardson land squirrels) that live in the central part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located in the U.S. region known as the Great Plains.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state shares the Northern Red River with Minnesota to the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is to the south, Montana is to the west, and the Canadian provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba are to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located near the middle of North America, with a stone marker in Rugby, North Dakota, which marks the "Geographic Centre of the North American Continent."

name: north_dakota
sentence: With an area of 70,762 square miles (183,273 km2), including 178,712 square kilometres, North Dakota is the 19th largest state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The western half of the state consists of the hilly Great Plains and the northern part of the Badlands, which are west of the Missouri River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state's highest point, White Butte at 3506 feet (1,069 m), and Theodore Roosevelt National Park are in the Badlands.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The region is rich in fossil fuels, including natural gas, crude oil and lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River forms Sakakawea Lake, the third largest artificial lake in the United States, behind the Garrison Dam.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The central area of the state is divided into the Drift Prairie and the Missouri Plateau.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The eastern part of the state consists of the flat valley of the Red River, the bottom of glacial lake Agassiz.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its fertile soil, drained by the Red River that winds north into Lake Winnipeg, supports an important agricultural industry.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Devils Lake, the largest natural lake in the state, is also in the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Most of the state is covered with meadows

name: north_dakota
sentence: Natural trees are usually found in North Dakota where there is good drainage, such as the ravines and valley near Pembina Gorge and Killdeer Mountains, Turtle Mountains, the hills around Devil Lake, the dunes of McHenry County in central North Dakota, and along the slopes of the Sheyenne Valley and Sheyenne Delta.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This varied land is home to almost 2,000 species of plants.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota enjoys a continental climate with hot summers and cold winters.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Temperature differences are significant due to its remote interior position and being in the centre of the Northern Hemisphere, with approximately equal distances with the North Pole and the equator.

name: north_dakota
sentence: American Aboriginal peoples were living in what is now North Dakota for thousands of years before the arrival of Europeans.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The known tribes included the Mandan people (around the 11th century), while the first Hidatsa group arrived a few hundred years later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Both gathered in villages on tributaries of the Missouri River in what was to become the western centre of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Crow Indians travelled to the western plains to visit and trade with related Hidatas after the split between them, probably in the 17th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Later came the divisions of the Dakota people – Lakota, Santee, and Yanktonai.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Crees of Assiniboine and Plains undertake journeys southward to the Indians of the village, either for trade or for war.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Shoshone Indians in today's Wyoming and Montana may have carried out attacks on Indian enemies as far east as Missouri.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A group of Cheyennes lived in a village of earth houses at the bottom of the Sheyenne River (site Biesterfeldt) for decades in the 18th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As a result of attacks by Crees, Assiniboines and Chippewas armed with firearms, they left the area around 1780 and crossed Missouri some time later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A band of the few Sotaio Indians lived east of the Missouri River and met uprooted Cheyennes before the end of the century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They soon followed the Cheyennes across Missouri and lived among them south of the Cannonball River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Finally, the Cheyennes and the Sutaio became a tribe and turned into buffalo hunters with ranges primarily outside North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Before the middle of the 19th century, Arikara entered the future southern state and joined the Mandan and Hidatsa.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Over time, a number of Indians have entered into treaties with the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many treaties define the territory of a specific tribe (see map).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The first European to reach the region was French-Canadian merchant Pierre Gaultier, Sieur de La Vérendrye, who led an exploration and trade group in the villages of Mandan in 1738.

name: north_dakota
sentence: From 1762 to 1802, the area was part of the Spanish Louisiana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: American Europeans did not settle in the Dakota territory until the end of the 19th century, when railways opened the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the advantage of land concession, they vigorously traded their properties, exalting the region as the ideal for agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: On February 22, 1889, Congress passed an omnibus bill for North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington, entitled Enabling Act of 1889, under the administration of President Grover Cleveland.

name: north_dakota
sentence: His successor, Benjamin Harrison, signed the proclamations in which he officially admitted North Dakota and South Dakota to the Union on 2 Nov. 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The rivalry between the two new states presented a dilemma which must first be admitted to exist.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Harrison ordered Secretary of State James G. Blaine to mix the papers and obscure him that he signed first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The order was not recorded, so no one knows which Dakotas were admitted first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, since North Dakota appears alphabetically in front of South Dakota, its proclamation was first published in the At Large Statutes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The carelessness among wheat producers, particularly among Norwegian immigrants, led to a populist political movement centered in the non-partisan League ("NPL") around the time of the First World War.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The NPL presented candidates on the Republican ticket (but merged into the Democratic Party after World War II).

name: north_dakota
sentence: He tried to isolate North Dakota from the power of banks and out-of-state corporations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition to founding the Bank of North Dakota and North Dakota Mill and Elevator (both are still in place), NPL has established a state railway line (later sold to Soo Line Railroad).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Anti-society laws virtually prohibited a company or bank from owning title to land in the form of agricultural land.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These laws, still in force today, after being confirmed by the state and federal courts, make it almost impossible to close down agricultural land, since even after the seizure, the title to property cannot be held by a bank or a mortgage company.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, the North Dakota Bank, with powers similar to those of a federal reserve branch bank, exercised its power to limit the issuance of sub-prime mortgages and their guarantee in the form of derivative instruments, thus preventing the collapse of housing prices in the state following the 2008 financial crisis.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The original North Dakota Capitol at Bismarck burned on the ground on December 28, 1930.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It has been replaced by an art deco skyscraper with limestone facets that still stands today.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A series of federal investment and construction projects began in the 1950s, including the Garrison Dam and the Minot and Grand Forks Air Force Bases.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Western North Dakota experienced a boom in oil exploration in the late 1970s and early 1980s, as higher oil prices made development profitable.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This boom ended after the drop in oil prices.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In recent years, the State has recorded unemployment rates below the national average and has increased employment and population growth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Much of the growth was based on the development of Bakken's oil fields in the western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Estimates of the remaining amount of oil in the region vary, some of which are estimated to be more than 100 years old.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For decades, the annual rate of North Dakota murder and the violent crime rate were consistently lowest in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, in recent years, although still below the national average, crime has risen sharply.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2016, the violent crime rate was three times higher than in 2004, and the increase mainly occurred in the late 2000s, coinciding with the oil boom era.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This occurred at a time when the national rate of violent crime declined slightly.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Workers in oil boom cities have been accused of much of the increase.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the North Dakota population was 762,062 on 1 July 2019, an increase of 13.30 per cent since the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This makes North Dakota the US state with the highest percentage of population growth since 2011.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is the fourth least populous state in the country; only Alaska, Vermont and Wyoming have fewer residents.

sentence: As with the U.S. federal government, the political power of the state government of North Dakota is divided into three branches: executive, legislative, and judicial.

sentence: The executive branch is chaired by the elected governor.

sentence: There are 42 District Court judges in seven judicial districts.

sentence: The North Dakota Supreme Court hears all appeals from district courts and the Court of Appeal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Historically, North Dakota was populated by the Mandan, Hidatsa, Lakota and Ojibwe, followed by the Sanish and Métis.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Today, five tribes recognized by the federal government within the boundaries of North Dakota have independent and sovereign relations with the federal government and territorial reserves:

name: north_dakota
sentence: The U.S. Senators of North Dakota are John Hoeven (R) and Kevin Cramer (R).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has a large congress district represented by representative Kelly Armstrong (R).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Federal court cases are heard by the United States District Court for the North Dakota District, which is based in Bismarck, Fargo, Grand Forks and Minot.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The appeals are heard by the Court of Appeal of the eighth electoral district of Saint-Louis, Missouri.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The major political parties in North Dakota are the Democratic Party and the Republican Party.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2007, the Constitutional Party and the Libertarian Party were also state-run parties.

name: north_dakota
sentence: At the state level, the government has been held by the Republican Party since 1992, at the same time as the majority of legislatures and state officials.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Dem-NPL's demonstrations were strong in the 2000 governor's race and in the 2006 general election, but the League has not seen a major breakthrough since the administration of former state governor George Sinner.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The candidate for the presidency of the Republican Party generally carries the state; in 2004, George W. Bush won with 62.9% of the vote.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of all the candidates for the democratic presidency since 1892, only Grover Cleveland (1892, one of three votes), Woodrow Wilson (1912 and 1916), Franklin D. Roosevelt (1932 and 1936) and Lyndon B. Johnson (1964) received votes from the North Dakota Electoral College.

name: north_dakota
sentence: On the other hand, Dem-NPL's candidates for the federal seats of the senator and the House of North Dakota won each election between 1982 and 2008, and the federal government delegation was fully democratic from 1987 to 2011.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, the two current United States

name: north_dakota
sentence: Senators John Hoeven and Kevin Cramer are Republicans, as is the only member of the House, Kelly Armstrong.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The income tax structure of North Dakota is slightly progressive; the five tranches of the government's income tax rates are 1.1%, 2.04%, 2.27%, 2.64% and 2.90% in 2017.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2005, North Dakota ranked 22nd in relation to per capita taxes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Sales tax in North Dakota is 5% for most items.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state allows municipalities to introduce local sales taxes and special local taxes, such as the 1.75% additional sales tax in Grand Forks.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Excise taxes are charged on the purchase price or market value of aircraft registered in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Crown imposes a user tax on goods purchased elsewhere but used within North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Property owners in North Dakota pay property taxes to their county, municipality, school district and special tax districts.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Tax Foundation classifies North Dakota as the state with the 20th most "business-friendly" tax climate in the nation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Tax Freedom Day arrives on April 1, 10 days before the National Tax Freedom Day.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2006, North Dakota was the country where the number of returns filed by taxpayers with adjusted gross income above $1 million was the lowest, only 333.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of the 762,062 inhabitants of North Dakota, 56.54 per cent live in one of the fifteen most populated cities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fargo is the largest city in North Dakota and is the economic center of the region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck, in south-central North Dakota, along the shores of Missouri, has been the capital of North Dakota since 1883, first as the capital of the Dakota Territory, then as the state capital since 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Minot is a town in northern North Dakota and is home to North Dakota State Fair and Norsk Høstfest.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A few miles west of Bismarck, on the west side of the Missouri River, Mandan was named in honour of the Mandan Indians who lived in the area at the time of the Lewis and Clark Expedition.

name: north_dakota
sentence: New Salem is the site of the largest statue in the world of a holstein cow

name: north_dakota
sentence: Grand Forks and Devils Lake are in picturesque areas of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: West Fargo, North Dakota's fifth largest city, is one of the fastest growing cities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Williston is near the confluence of the Missouri River and Yellowstone River near Montana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Medora in North Dakota Badlands hosts the Medora Musical every summer and is the gateway to Theodore Roosevelt National Park.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fort Yates, along the Missouri River on the Rock Indian Permanent Reserve, claims to host the last resting place for Hunkpa Lakota's leader Sitting Bull (Mobridge, South Dakota also claims his grave).

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are 11 public colleges and universities, five tribal community colleges and four private schools.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The largest institutions are North Dakota University and North Dakota University.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The higher education system consists of the following institutions:

sentence: North Dakota University System (public institutions):

sentence: Tribal Establishments:
