name: north_dakota
sentence: "The Flickr State" is one of the nicknames of North Dakota and is derived from the Richardson Squirrel (Spermophilus richardson ii), a very common animal in the region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The ground squirrel constantly strikes its tail in a distinctive manner.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1953, legislation to make land squirrel the emblem of the state was passed by the State Parliament.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has 10 daily newspapers, the biggest being the Fargo-Moorhead Forum.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other weekly and monthly publications (most of which are entirely funded by advertising) are also available.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The most important is the alternate weekly High Plains Reader.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The oldest state radio station, WDAY-AM, was launched on May 23, 1922.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The three main radio markets in North Dakota are located around Fargo, Bismarck and Grand Forks, but stations broadcast in all regions of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 2010s, a number of new stations were built in Williston.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has 34 AM and 88 FM radio stations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: KFGO in Fargo has the biggest audience.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Television broadcasting in North Dakota began on April 3, 1953, when KCJB-TV (now KXMC-TV) began operating in Minot.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota television media markets are Fargo-Grand Forks (117th largest country), including half of the eastern state, and Minot-Bismarck (152nd), which make up the western half of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are currently 31 full-power television stations, divided into 10 networks, with 17 digital sub-channels.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public broadcasting in North Dakota is provided by Prairie Public, with national television and radio networks affiliated to PBS and NPR.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public television stations open for community programming are available on cable networks in Bismarck, Dickinson, Fargo and Jamestown.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is a state in the eastern Midwestern United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Of the fifty states, it is the 34th largest by region, and with a population of nearly 11.7 million, it is the seventh most populous and the tenth most densely populated.

name: ohio
sentence: The state capital and the largest city are Columbus, with the metropolitan area of Columbus, the Grand Cincinnati and the Grand Cleveland being the largest metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bordered by Lake Erie to the north, Pennsylvania to the east, West Virginia to the southeast, Kentucky to the southwest, Indiana to the west and Michigan to the northwest.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is historically known as "Buckeye State" after its Ohio buckeyes, and Ohions are also known as "Buckeyes".

name: ohio
sentence: The state derives its name from the Ohio River, whose name comes in turn from the word Senatorca ohi=yo', meaning "good river," "great river," or "great river."

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was born from the lands west of Appalachia that were disputed from the colonial era through the Indian wars of the late 18th century.

name: ohio
sentence: It was separated from the resulting Northwest Territory, which was the first border of the new United States, and became the 17th State admitted to the Union on March 1, 1803, and the first under the North-West Ordinance.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was the first free post-colonial state admitted to union, and became one of the first and most influential industrial power stations in the 20th century; although it evolved into an information- and service-based economy in the 21st century, Ohio remains an industrial state, ranking seventh in GDP in 2019, with the third largest manufacturing sector and second largest automotive production.

name: ohio
sentence: The government of Ohio is composed of the executive branch, headed by the Governor; the legislature, composed of the General Assembly of Bicameral Ohio; and the judiciary, headed by the Supreme Court of the State.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has 16 seats in the House of Representatives of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: The state is known for its status as both an oscillating state and a gazebo in the national elections.

name: ohio
sentence: Eight presidents from the United States came from Ohio, the most from any state, which led to receiving the moniker "Mother of Presidents".

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's geographic location has proven to be an asset for economic growth and expansion.

name: ohio
sentence: As Ohio connects the Northeast to the Midwest, many goods and business traffic cross its borders along its well-developed highways.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has the country's 10th largest road network and is less than a day's drive away from 50 per cent of the North American population and 70 per cent of North America's manufacturing capacity.

name: ohio
sentence: To the north, Lake Erie gives Ohio 312 miles (502 km) of coastline, allowing many loading ports.

name: ohio
sentence: The southern Ohio border is defined by the Ohio River (the boundary being at the lower limit of 1792 on the north side of the river), and most of the northern boundary is defined by Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's neighbours are Pennsylvania to the east, Michigan to the northwest, Lake Erie to the north, Indiana to the west, Kentucky to the south, and West Virginia to the southeast.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's boundaries were defined in the enabling legislation of 1802 as follows:

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bounded by the Ohio River, but most of the river itself belongs to Kentucky and West Virginia.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1980, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that, according to the wording of Virginia's cessation of territory (which at the time included what is now Kentucky and West Virginia), the Ohio-Kentucky border (and consequently West Virginia) is the north low water mark of the river as it existed in 1792.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio only has this part of the river between the 1792 low water mark and the current high water mark.

name: ohio
sentence: The border with Michigan also changed, following the Toledo War, to a slightly northeasterly angle to the north shore of the mouth of the Maumee River.

name: ohio
sentence: Much of Ohio has glacial till plains, with an exceptionally flat area in the northwest known as Great Black Swamp.

name: ohio
sentence: This glazed region of the north-west and central state is bordered first to the east and south-east by a belt known as the glazed Allegheny plateau, and then by another belt known as the unglazed Allegheny plateau.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of Ohio is of low terrain, but the unglazed Allegheny plateau has rugged hills and forests.

name: ohio
sentence: The rugged southeastern quadrant of Ohio, which extends in an arc-shaped arc along the Ohio River from the Panhandle of West Virginia to the periphery of Cincinnati, forms a distinct socio-economic unit.

name: ohio
sentence: Geologically similar to parts of West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania, coal mining in that area, dependence on small pockets of former manufacturing facilities, and the distinctive regional dialect have removed this section from the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1965, the United States Congress passed the Appalachian Regional Development Act, an attempt to "respond to the persistent poverty and growing economic despair of the Appalachian region."

name: ohio
sentence: This Act defines 29 Ohio counties as part of Appalachia.

name: ohio
sentence: While 1/3 of Ohio's land mass is in the Appalachian region defined by the federal government, only 12.8% of Ohio's people live there (1.476 million).

name: ohio
sentence: Important rivers in the state include the Cuyahoga River, the Great Miami River, the Maumee River, the Muskingum River and the Scioto River.

name: ohio
sentence: Rivers in the northern part of the state flow into the northern Atlantic Ocean via Lake Erie and the St. Lawrence River, and rivers in the southern part of the state flow through the Gulf of Mexico via Ohio and then Mississippi.

name: ohio
sentence: The worst weather disaster in Ohio history occurred along the Great Miami River in 1913.

name: ohio
sentence: Known as the Dayton Great Flood, the entire Miami River watershed has flooded, including Dayton's downtown business district.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result, the Miami Conservancy District was established as the first major floodplain engineering project in Ohio and the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Great Lake St. Marys, in the western central part of the state, was built as a water source for canals at the time of canal construction from 1820 to 1850.

name: ohio
sentence: For many years, this stretch of water, over 52 km2, was the largest artificial lake in the world.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio canal projects are not the economic fiasco that similar efforts have been made in other states.

name: ohio
sentence: Some cities, such as Dayton, owe their industrial emergence to their location on the canals, and as early as 1910, the inland canals transported much of the state's bulk cargo.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio climate is a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa/Dfb climate classification) in most of the state, except in the extreme southern counties of the Bluegrass region of Ohio, which are located on the northern periphery of the subtropical humid climate (Cfa) and the Upland South region of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Summers are generally warm and humid throughout the state, while winters usually range from cold to cold.

name: ohio
sentence: Rainfall in Ohio is moderate throughout the year.

name: ohio
sentence: Violent weather is not uncommon in the state, although there are generally fewer reports of tornadoes in Ohio than in states in what is known as the tornado alley.

name: ohio
sentence: Lake-effect snow storms are not uncommon on the southeast shore of Lake Erie, which is located in an area known as the snow belt.

name: ohio
sentence: Although mostly not in a subtropical climate, some warmer and more climatic flora and fauna reach Ohio well.

name: ohio
sentence: For example, some trees with more southern ranges, such as the black oak, Quercus marilandica, are located northerly of Ohio, just north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: Also referring to this climate transition from subtropical to continental climate, several plants such as southern magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora), Albizia julibrissin (mimosa), Crape Myrtle, and even occasionally Needle Palm are robust landscaping materials regularly used as street, courtyard and garden plantations in the Ohio Bluegrass area; but these same plants will simply not thrive in many of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: This interesting change can be observed by traveling to Ohio on Interstate 75 from Cincinnati to Toledo; the traveller observing this various state can even catch a glimpse of Cincinnati's common lizard, one of the few examples of permanent "subtropical" wildlife in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Due to the floods that caused serious road damage, Governor Mike DeWine declared a state of emergency in 37 counties in Ohio in 2019.

name: ohio
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 113 °F (45 °C), near Gallipolis on July 21, 1934.

name: ohio
sentence: The lowest recorded temperature was −39°F (−39°C) at Milligan on 10 February 1899, during the Great Blizzard of 1899.

name: ohio
sentence: Although few individuals have registered as being visible to the average resident, more than 200 earthquakes with a magnitude of 2.0 or more have occurred in Ohio since 1776.

name: ohio
sentence: The seismic zone of western Ohio and part of the seismic zone of the southern Great Lakes are located in the state, and there are numerous faults below the surface.

name: ohio
sentence: The largest earthquake in Ohio's history was the earthquake in Anna, Shelby County, on March 9, 1937.

name: ohio
sentence: It was centred in western Ohio and had a magnitude of 5.4, and was VIII-intensity.

name: ohio
sentence: Other major earthquakes in Ohio include: an earthquake of magnitude 4.8 near Lima on September 19, 1884; an earthquake of magnitude 4.2 near Portsmouth on May 17, 1901; and one of the 5.0 in LeRoy Township, Lake County on January 31, 1986, which continued to trigger 13 replicas of magnitude 0.5 to 2.4 for two months.

name: ohio
sentence: Significant earthquakes in Ohio in the 21st century included an earthquake on December 31, 2011, about 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) northwest of Youngstown, and an earthquake on June 10, 2019, about 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) north-northwest of Eastlake, under Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Columbus is the capital of Ohio, located near the geographic center of the state and well known for Ohio State University.

name: ohio
sentence: However, other Ohio cities operate as economic and cultural centres in metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Akron, Canton, Cleveland, Mansfield and Youngstown are in the northeast, known for the major industrial companies Goodyear Tire and Rubber and Timken, the top-ranked colleges Case Western Reserve University and Kent State University, the Cleveland Clinic, and cultural attractions including the Cleveland Art Museum, Big Five Group Cleveland Orchestra, Playhouse Square, the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

name: ohio
sentence: Lima and Toledo are the main cities in northwestern Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Northwestern Ohio is known for its glass industry, and is home to Owens Corning and Owens-Illinois, two Fortune 500 companies.

name: ohio
sentence: Dayton and Springfield are located in the Miami Valley, home to Dayton University, Dayton Ballet and the large base of the Wright-Patterson Air Force.

name: ohio
sentence: Cincinnati anchors southwestern Ohio and is the largest economy of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: It houses the University of Miami and the University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati Union Terminal, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, as well as various Fortune 500 companies including Procter & Gamble, Kroger, Macy's, Inc. and the fifth-third bank.

name: ohio
sentence: Steubenville is the only metropolitan town in Appalachian Ohio, home to Hocking Hills State Park.

name: ohio
sentence: The Cincinnati metropolitan area extends as far as Kentucky and Indiana, the Steubenville metropolitan area extends as far as West Virginia, the Toledo metropolitan area extends as far as Michigan and the Youngstown metropolitan area extends as far as Pennsylvania.

name: ohio
sentence: Other metropolitan areas that contain cities in Ohio include:

name: ohio
sentence: The cities of Ohio, which serve as centres for micropolitan areas in the United States, include:

name: ohio
sentence: Archaeological evidence of spear points of the Folsom and Clovis types indicates that the Ohio Valley was inhabited by nomads as early as 13,000 B.C.

name: ohio
sentence: These first nomads disappeared from Ohio by 1000 BC.

name: ohio
sentence: Between 1000 and 800 B.C., Adena's sedentary culture emerged.

name: ohio
sentence: The Adenas were able to establish "semi-permanent" villages because they domesticated plants, including sunflowers, and "wheat squash and possibly corn." With hunting and gathering, this crop supported more established and complex villages.

name: ohio
sentence: The most notable remnant of the Adena culture is the Grand Snake Mound, located in Adams County, Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Around 100 B.C., Adena evolved to become the people of Hopewell who were also mound builders.

name: ohio
sentence: Their complex and technologically sophisticated works of earth can be found in Marietta, Newark and Circleville today.

name: ohio
sentence: They were also a prolific commercial company, their commercial network extending over a third of the continent.

name: ohio
sentence: Hopewell disappeared from the Ohio Valley about 600 AD.

name: ohio
sentence: Mississippi culture increased as Hopewell culture declined.

name: ohio
sentence: Many people speaking the Siwan of the plains and the east coast claim them as ancestors and say they lived throughout the Ohio region until about the 13th century.

name: ohio
sentence: There were three other contemporary cultures with the Mississippians: the ancient Fort people, the Whittlesey Focus people, and Monongahela culture.

name: ohio
sentence: All three cultures disappeared in the 17th century.

name: ohio
sentence: Their origins are unknown.

name: ohio
sentence: The Shawns may have absorbed the people of the Old Fort.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also possible that Monongahela does not have land in Ohio during the colonial era.

name: ohio
sentence: The Mississippi culture was close and exchanged much with the people of the ancient Fort.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio Valley Indians are greatly affected by the aggressive tactics of the Iroquois Confederation, based in central and western New York.

name: ohio
sentence: After the mid-17th century beaver wars, the Iroquois claimed much of Ohio as a hunting ground and, more importantly, as a beaver trap.

name: ohio
sentence: After the devastation of epidemics and war in the middle of the 17th century, which largely emptied the country of Ohio from indigenous peoples in the mid-17th century to the end of the 17th century, the land gradually became repopulated by the predominantly Algonquian.

name: ohio
sentence: Many of these Ohio nations were multi-ethnic (sometimes multi-lingual) societies born from the devastation caused by disease, war and subsequent social instability.

name: ohio
sentence: They survived on agriculture (maize, sunflowers, beans, etc.)

name: ohio
sentence: supplemented by seasonal hunting.

name: ohio
sentence: In the 18th century, they were part of a larger world economy created by Europe's entry into the fur trade.

name: ohio
sentence: Indigenous nations living in Ohio during the historical period included the Iroquoians, the Algonquians, and the Siwans.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio country was also the site of Indian massacres, such as the Yellow Creek massacre, the Gnadenhutten massacre and the Pontiac School of Rebellion massacre.

name: ohio
sentence: Most Aboriginal people who remained in Ohio were gradually redeemed and convinced to leave, or ordered by law, in the early 19th century with the Indian Abduction Act of 1830.

name: ohio
sentence: During the 18th century, the French established a trading post system to control the fur trade in the region.

name: ohio
sentence: As early as 1754, France and Britain fought the French and Indian wars.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result of the Treaty of Paris, the French gave control of Ohio and the rest of the Old North West to Great Britain.

name: ohio
sentence: In the Treaty of Paris of 1783, Britain ceded to the United States all the claims of the Ohio country.

name: ohio
sentence: The United States created the Northwest Territory under the North-West Order of 1787.

name: ohio
sentence: Slavery is not permitted in the new territory.

name: ohio
sentence: The establishment began with the founding of Marietta by the Ohio Company of Associates, which had been formed by a group of U.S. Revolutionary War veterans.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result of the Ohio Company, the Miami Company (also known as the "Purchase of Symmes") claimed the southwest section, and Connecticut Land Company surveyed and established the Connecticut Western Reserve in present-day northeast Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Territorial surveyors at Fort Steuben began to survey approximately at the same time an area in eastern Ohio called the Seven Ranges.

name: ohio
sentence: The former Northwest Territory originally consisted of areas previously known as Ohio Country and Illinois Country.

name: ohio
sentence: As Ohio was preparing to become a state, Indiana was created, which reduced the territory of the Northwest to about the present size of Ohio, plus half of the lower Michigan Peninsula and the eastern tip of the upper peninsula and a portion of the southeastern Indiana called "The Gore".

name: ohio
sentence: The coalition of Amerindian tribes, known as the Confederation of the West, was forced to cede a vast territory, including much of the present Ohio, in the Treaty of Greenville in 1795.

name: ohio
sentence: Under the North-West Ordinance, areas could be defined and admitted as States when their population reaches 60,000.

name: ohio
sentence: Although the population of Ohio was only 45,000 in December 1801, Congress determined that it was growing rapidly and that it had already begun the road to statehood.

name: ohio
sentence: With regard to the natives of Leni Lenape, Congress decided that 10,000 acres on the Muskingum River in the present state of Ohio would be "separated and their property would be vested in the Moravian Brothers [...] or a Society of the said Brothers for civilizing the Indians and encouraging Christianity."

name: ohio
sentence: Rufus Putnam played an important role in the French and Indian wars and in the American revolutionary war.

name: ohio
sentence: He was one of the most respected men in the early years of the U.S.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1776 Putnam created a method of construction of portable fortifications that allowed the Continental Army to drive the British from Boston.

name: ohio
sentence: George Washington was so impressed that he turned Putnam into his chief engineer.

name: ohio
sentence: After the war, Putnam and Manasseh Cutler contributed to the creation of the North-West Ordinance, which opened the Northwest Territory to colonization.

name: ohio
sentence: This land was used as compensation for what was due to the veterans of the revolutionary war.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also at Putnam's recommendation that the land be surveyed and arranged in six-square-mile townships.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam organized and led the first group of veterans in the Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: They moved to Marietta, Ohio, where they built a great fort called Campus Martius.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam and Cutler insisted that the territory of the Northwest be a free territory – no slavery.

name: ohio
sentence: They were both from Puritan New England, and the Puritans firmly believed that slavery was morally evil.

name: ohio
sentence: The Northwest Territory doubled the size of the United States, and it was extremely important to consider it as slavery-free in the decades that followed.

name: ohio
sentence: It included what became Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin, and part of Minnesota.

name: ohio
sentence: Had those states been slave states, and their electoral votes had been attributed to Abraham Lincoln's main competitor, Lincoln would not have been elected president.

name: ohio
sentence: The civil war would not have been carried out.

name: ohio
sentence: And, even if there had been a civil war in the end, the North would probably have lost.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam, in Puritan tradition, has influenced the establishment of education in the Northwest Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: Important land has been reserved for schools.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam had been one of the principal benefactors in the founding of the Leicester Academy in Massachusetts, and in 1798 he also created the plan for the construction of the Muskingum Academy (now Marietta College) in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1780, the directors of the Ohio Company appointed him superintendent of all of his affairs relating to the settlement north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1796 he was commissioned by President George Washington as Surveyor General of the United States Lands.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1788 he was judge in the first court of the Northwest Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1802 he served in the assembly to form a constitution for Ohio State.

name: ohio
sentence: On February 19, 1803 U.S. President Thomas Jefferson signed a law of Congress that approved the borders and constitution of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: However, Congress had never passed a resolution officially recognizing Ohio as the 17th state.

name: ohio
sentence: The current custom of Congress to declare an official date of the state did not begin until 1812, with the admission of Louisiana as the 18th state.

name: ohio

sentence: On November 11, 1911, the temperature in Oklahoma City reached 83°F (28°C) (the record for that date), then a cold front of unprecedented intensity slammed through the state, resulting in the temperature reaching 17°F (−8°C) (the low record for that date) at midnight.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The people of Oklahoma have less than average life expectancy than many other states.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2014, men in Oklahoma lived on average 73.7 years compared to a national average of 76.7 years and women on average 78.5 years compared with a national average of 81.5 years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In addition, the increase in life expectancy was lower than the national average.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Men's life expectancy in Oklahoma between 1980 and 2014 increased by an average of 4.0 years, compared to a national average of 6.7 years of increasing men's life expectancy.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Women's life expectancy in Oklahoma between 1980 and 2014 increased by 1.0 years compared to a national average of 4.0 years of increasing women's life expectancy.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Using 2016-2018 data, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation calculated that life expectancy in Oklahoma counties ranged from 71.2 years for Okfuskee County to 79.7 years for Cimarron and Logan County.

name: oklahoma
sentence: For the State as a whole, life expectancy was 76.0 years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Television broadcast in Oklahoma began in 1949 when KFOR-TV (then WKY-TV) in Oklahoma City and KOTV-TV in Tulsa began broadcasting a few months apart.

sentence: Currently, all major U.S. broadcasting networks have affiliated television channels in the State.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The State has two primary newspapers.

sentence: Oklahoman, based in Oklahoma City, is the largest newspaper in the state and the 54th largest in the nation by broadcast, with a weekly readership of 138,493 and a readership on Sundays of 202,690.

sentence: Oklahoma has a few ethnic television stations that broadcast in Spanish and Asian, and there is some Amerindian programming.

sentence: TBN, a Christian religious television network, had a studio in Tulsa, and built its first wholly owned subsidiary of TBN in Oklahoma City in 1980.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Transportation in Oklahoma is generated by a system of anchoring inter-state highways, inter-city rail lines, airports, inland ports and public transport networks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Located along an integral point of the U.S. interstate network, the Oklahoma contains three main highways and four auxiliary highways.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In Oklahoma City, Interstate 35 connects Interstate 44 with Interstate 40, one of the most important intersections along the U.S. road network.

name: oklahoma
sentence: More than 12,000 miles (19,000 km) of roads are the Government's main road skeleton, including government-operated roads, ten turn towers or major toll roads, and the longest section of Highway 66 in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2008, Interstate 44 in Oklahoma City was the busiest highway in Oklahoma, with a daily volume of 123,300 cars.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2010, the state had the third largest number of bridges classified as structurally deficient, with nearly 5,212 bridges in poor condition, including 235 bridges in the national road network.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma's largest commercial airport is Will Rogers World Airport in Oklahoma City, with an annual passenger average of over 3.5 million (1.7 million boardings) in 2010.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tulsa International Airport, the second largest commercial airport in the state, served more than 1.3 million boardings in 2010.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Between the two, six airlines operate in Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In terms of traffic, R.L. Jones Jr. Airport (Riverside) in Tulsa is the busiest airport in the state, with 335,826 take-offs and landings in 2008.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has more than 150 public airports.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is connected to the national rail network via Amtrak's Heartland Flyer, its only regional passenger transport line.

name: oklahoma
sentence: It currently extends from the town of Oklahoma to Fort Worth, Texas, although legislators began seeking funding in early 2007 to link the Heartland Flyer to Tulsa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Two inland ports on rivers serve Oklahoma: the port of Muskogee and the port of Tulsa de Catoosa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The port of Tulsa de Catoosa is one of the most inland international ports in the United States, at the head of the navigational system of the McClellan–Kerr Arkansas River, which connects the traffic of Tulsa and Muskogee barges to the Mississippi River.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The port ships more than two million tonnes of goods per year and is a designated foreign commercial area.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is a constitutional republic with a government shaped by the U.S. federal government, with executive, legislative and judicial powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state has 77 counties with jurisdiction over most of the local government functions in each area, five districts of Congress, and a voting base with plurality in the Republican Party.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The representatives of the State are elected by pluralist ballot in the State of Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has the death penalty as a legal penalty, and the state has had (between 1976 and mid2011) the highest per capita execution rate in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Legislature of Oklahoma is composed of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

name: oklahoma
sentence: As a legislative branch of the state government, it is responsible for collecting and distributing the money needed to manage the government.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The honourable senator has 48 members for a four-year term, while the House has 101 members for a two-year term.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The State has a legislative limit that limits any person to twelve cumulative years of service between the two legislative branches.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The judiciary of Oklahoma consists of the Supreme Court of Oklahoma, the Criminal Appeal Court of Oklahoma and 77 district courts each serving a county.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma judicial system also includes two independent courts: an indictment court and the Oklahoma court on the judiciary.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has two courts of last resort: the State Supreme Court rules on civil cases and the State Criminal Appeal Court rules on criminal cases (this system exists only in Oklahoma and nearby Texas).

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania (German: Pennsilfaani), officially the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, is a state in the Middle Atlantic, Appalachian and Great Lakes region of the northeastern United States of America.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Commonwealth is bordered by Delaware in the southeast, Maryland in the south, West Virginia in the southwest, Ohio in the west, Lake Erie and the Canadian province of Ontario in the northwest, New York in the north, and New Jersey in the east, while Appalachians cross its middle.

name: pennsylvania

sentence: It is the 9th densely populated of the 50 states.

sentence: Of the 13 original colonies, Pennsylvania is the only state that does not border the Atlantic Ocean.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The boundaries of the state are the Mason-Dixon line (39°43'N) to the south, the 12-mile circle on the Pennsylvania-Delaware border, the Delaware River to the east, 80°31'W to the west and 42°N to the north, except for a short segment at the west end, where a triangle extends north to Lake Erie.

sentence: The cities include Philadelphia, Reading, Lebanon and Lancaster in the southeast, Pittsburgh in the southwest, the three cities of Allentown, Bethlehem and Easton in the east (known as the Lehigh Valley).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island () is a state in the New England region of the United States of America.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It is the smallest U.S. state by region and the seventh least populated (1,059,361 in 2019), but it is also the second most populous state behind New Jersey.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state takes its name from Rhode Island; however, most of the state is located on the mainland.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state has land borders with Connecticut in the west, Massachusetts in the north and east, and the Atlantic Ocean in the south via Rhode Island Sound and Block Island Sound.

sentence: Providence is the state capital and the most populous city on Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: On 4 May 1776 the colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations was the first of the Thirteen colonies to renounce allegiance to the British Crown, and it was the fourth state to ratify the statutes of the Confederation, doing so on 9 Feb. 1778.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state boycotted the 1787 convention which drafted the United States Constitution and initially refused to ratify it; it was the last of the 13 States of origin to do so on 29 May 1790.

sentence: Officially named State of Rhode Island and Providence Plants since joining the Union in 1790, state voters approved an amendment to the State Constitution in November 2020, renamed State of Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island

name: rhode_island

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 1790, after the American Revolution, the new state incorporated both Rhode Island and Providence Plantations, becoming known as the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The word plantation in the name of the State became a disputed issue during the 20th century and the increased awareness of slavery and its role in the history of Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The General Assembly voted on 25 June 2009 to hold a general referendum scheduled for November 2010 to determine whether "and Providence plantations" would be abandoned with the official name.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The supporters of the plantation's excitation claimed that the word symbolized an alleged legacy of the abandonment of voting rights for many inhabitants of Rhode Island, as well as the proliferation of slavery in the colonies and in the post-colonial United States.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The supporters of maintaining the name claimed that the plantation was an archaic synonym for the colony and had nothing to do with slavery.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The referendum election took place on 2 November 2010 and the people voted massively (78% to 22%) to keep the entire original name.

name: rhode_island
sentence: On June 19, 2020, Senator Harold Metts introduced a resolution for another referendum on the vote to delete the words "and Providence Plants" from the name of the state, saying, "Whatever the meaning of the term "plantations" in the context of Rhode Island's history, it bears a horrible connotation when it comes to the tragic and racist history of our nation."

name: south_carolina
sentence: Under the presidential reconstruction (1865–66), the liberated men (former slaves) were granted limited rights.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Under the radical reconstruction (1867-1877), a republican coalition of liberators, upholsterers and scalawags was under control, supported by the forces of the Union army.

name: south_carolina
sentence: They established public education, social welfare institutions and the domestic system for the counties, thereby expanding democracy.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In Texas vs. White (1869), the Supreme Court ruled that the secession orders (including that of South Carolina) were invalid, and therefore these states had never left the Union.

name: south_carolina
sentence: However, South Carolina did not resume its representation in Congress before that date.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Until the presidential election of 1868, South Carolina's legislature, not voters, chose state voters for the presidential election.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was the last state to have chosen its voters in this way.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On 19 Oct. 1871 President Ulysses S. Grant suspended habeas corpus in nine counties of South Carolina under the authority of the Ku Klux Klan Act.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Directed by Grant's attorney general, Amos T. Akerman, hundreds of Klansmen were arrested and 2,000 Klansmen fled the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This was done to suppress Klan's violence against South African-American and White voters.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the mid and late 1870s, white democrats used paramilitary groups such as the Red Shirts to intimidate and terrorize black voters.

name: south_carolina
sentence: They took over political control of the state under the conservative white "Redemptors" and the pro-business bourbon democrats.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1877, the federal government withdrew its troops as part of the compromise of 1877 that ended the reconstruction.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State became a home of racial and economic tensions during the populist and agrarian movements of the 1890s.

name: south_carolina
sentence: A biracial Republican-Popularist coalition temporarily took power with the White Democrats.

name: south_carolina
sentence: To prevent this from happening again, the Democrats obtained the adoption of a new constitution in 1895 that effectively deprived almost all blacks and many poor whites by new requirements in terms of voting taxes, residence and literacy tests that significantly reduced the electoral roll.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1896, only 5,500 black voters were registered, although they constituted a majority of the population of the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The 1900 census showed the extent of exclusion: the 782,509 African-Americans represented more than 58 per cent of the population of the state, but they were essentially without political representation in Jim Crow society.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The 1895 constitution overturned the local representative government, reducing the role of the counties to the agents of the state government, effectively governed by the General Assembly, through the legislative delegations of each county.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Since each county had a state senator, this person had considerable power.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The counties did not have representative government until the adoption of the internal system in 1975.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Governor Pitchfork Ben Tillman, a populist, led the effort to deny blacks and poor whites the right to vote, although he controlled democratic state policy from 1890 to 1910 with a base among the poor white farmers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: During the constitutional assembly of 1895, he supported another man's proposal that the State should adopt a rule of one drop, as well as prohibiting marriage between whites and anyone of known African descent.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Some members of the Convention have realized that prominent white families of African descent could be affected by such legislation.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In terms similar to a debate in Virginia in 1853 on a similar proposal (which was abandoned), George Dionysius Tillman stated in the opposition:

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State has postponed such a law by a drop for years.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Virginian legislators passed a law of one drop in 1924, forgetting that their state had many people of mixed ancestry among those who identified themselves as white.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the early 20th century, South Carolina developed a flourishing textile industry.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state has also converted its cotton agricultural base into more profitable crops; attracted large military bases through its powerful delegation to the Democratic Congress, a part of the South following the abandonment of the right to vote of blacks at the beginning of the century; and created tourism industries.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the early 20th century, millions of African Americans left South Carolina and other southern states for jobs, opportunities and relative freedom in American cities outside the former Confederate states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In total, between 1910 and 1970, 6.5 million Blacks left the South in the Great Migration.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1930, South Carolina had a white majority for the first time since 1708.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of the many states that initially rejected the nineteenth amendment (1920) giving women the right to vote.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The South Carolina Parliament then ratified the amendment on July 1, 1969.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The struggle of the civil rights movement took place in South Carolina as in other southern states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: However, South Carolina has experienced a much less violent movement than other southern states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This quiet transition from a Jim Crow company occurred because the white and black state leaders were willing to accept a slow change rather than being totally reluctant to accept a change.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Other Southern Carolinians, like Senator Strom Thurmond, on the other hand, were among the most radical and effective opponents of social equality and integration in the nation.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2015, South Carolina had one of the lowest percentages among all women's states in the state legislature, at 13.5% (only Louisiana, Oklahoma and Wyoming had a lower percentage; the national average was 24.3%; the highest percentage was in Colorado at 41%).

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2011, South Carolina ranked first in the country in terms of the rate of women killed by men.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As the 21st century progressed, South Carolina attracted new businesses with a 5% corporate income tax rate, no state property tax, no local income tax, no inventory tax, no sales tax on manufacturing equipment, industrial energy or materials for finished products, no wholesale tax, and no unit global income tax.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of the first states to stop paying for "early" baby deliveries, under Medicaid and private insurance.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The term early elective is defined as a work induction or caesarean section between 37 and 39 weeks that is not medically based.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This change is intended to ensure the health of babies and to reduce unnecessary costs for South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On 20 November 2014, South Carolina became the 35th state to legalize homosexual marriages, when a federal court ordered the change.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has numerous sites for visual and performing arts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Gibbes Museum of Art in Charleston, the Greenville County Museum of Art, the Columbia Museum of Art, the Spartanburg Art Museum and the South Carolina State Museum in Columbia, among others, provide access to the State's visual arts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also many historical sites and museums scattered throughout the state, paying tribute to many events and periods in the history of the state, from Amerindian housing to today.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina also has art rooms such as the Peace Center in Greenville, the Koger Center for the Arts in Columbia, and the Newberry Opera House, among others, to bring local, national and international talent to South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Several major venues can host major events, including Colonial Life Arena in Columbia, Bon Secours Wellness Arena in Greenville and North Charleston Coliseum.

name: south_carolina
sentence: One of the main performing arts festivals, the Spoleto Festival USA, is held each year in Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also countless local festivals across the state that highlight many cultural traditions, historical events and folklore.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the South Carolina Arts Commission, the creative industries generate $9.2 billion a year and support over 78,000 jobs in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: A 2009 national survey conducted by the Institute for Public Service and Policy Research at the University of South Carolina found that 67% of residents had participated in the arts in some form in the past year and that, on average, citizens had participated in the arts 14 times in the previous year.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), in 2010 the largest religion was Christianity, the largest denominations of which were the Southern Baptist Convention with 913,763 adherents, the Methodist Church united with 274,111 adherents, and the Roman Catholic Church with 181,743 adherents.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The fourth largest is the African Methodist Episcopal Church with 564 congregations and 121,000 members, and the fifth largest is the Presbyterian Church (United States) with 320 congregations and nearly 100,000 members.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2010, South Carolina was the US state with the highest proportion of citizens per capita following the Bahá'í Faith, with 17,559 adherents, making Bahá'í the second religion of the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Although no major professional sports team is based in South Carolina, the Caroline Panthers have training facilities in the state and played their first home game season at Clemson Memorial Stadium, however, they now play at the Bank of America Stadium in North Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Panthers consider themselves "the Carolines team" and refrain from naming themselves after Charlotte or one or the other of the Carolinas.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state also houses numerous professional teams of minor leagues.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The College's teams represent their unique institutions in South Carolina, and are the main options for football, basketball and baseball in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also a destination of choice for golf and water sports.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also home to one of NASCAR's first runways and its first paved speed track, Darlington Raceway, northwest of Florence.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina's GDP in 2019 was $249.9 billion, making the state the 26th largest GDP in the United States.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the United States Bureau of Economic Analysis, South Carolina's gross national product (GDP) was $97 billion in 1997 and $153 billion in 2007.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Its real per capita gross domestic product (GDP) in 2000 dollars was $26,772 in 1997 and $28,894 in 2007; it accounted for 85% of real GDP per capita for the United States in 1997 and 76% of the $38,020 for the United States in 2007.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Public debt in 2012 was calculated from a source of $22.9 billion, or $7,800 per taxpayer.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Industrial products include textile products, chemicals, paper products, machinery, automobiles, automotive products and tourism.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Government's main agricultural products are tobacco, poultry, cotton, cattle, dairy products, soybeans, hay, rice and pork.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, as of March 2012, South Carolina had 1,852,700 non-agricultural jobs, including 12 per cent in manufacturing, 11.5 per cent in leisure and hospitality, 19 per cent in trade, transport and public services, and 11.8 per cent in education and health services.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The service sector accounts for 83.7 per cent of South Carolina's economy.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Many large companies have moved their locations to South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Boeing opened an aircraft manufacturing plant in Charleston in 2011, which is one of the last two assembly sites at 787 Dreamliner.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is a state of the right to work and many companies use recruitment agencies to temporarily occupy positions.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Domtar in Rock Hill is the only Fortune 500 company based in South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Fortune 1000 list includes SCANA, Sonoco Products and ScanSource.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also benefiting from foreign investment.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are 1,950 foreign companies operating in South Carolina employing almost 135,000 people.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Foreign direct investment (FDI) contributed $1.06 billion to the government economy in 2010.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Since 1994, BMW has had a production plant in Spartanburg County near Greer and, since 1996, the Zapp Group has operated in Summerville near Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are 36 TV channels (including PBS affiliates) serving South Carolina with terrestrial access and some online streaming.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The markets for the stations include Columbia, Florence, Allendale, Myrtle Beach, Greenville, Charleston, Conway, Beaufort, Hardeeville, Spartanburg, Greenwood, Anderson and Sumter.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State has the fourth largest state system in the country, consisting of 11 interstates, numbered highways, public highways and secondary roads, with a total of approximately 41,500 miles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On secondary roads, South Carolina uses a numbering system to follow all non-interstate and primary roads maintained by the South Carolina Department of Transportation.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Secondary roads are numbered by the county number followed by a unique number for the road in question.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Amtrak Passenger Train operates four passenger routes in South Carolina: Crescent, Palmetto, Silver Meteor and Silver Star.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Crescent route reaches the cities of Upstate, the silver star reaches the cities of Midlands, and the Palmetto and Silver Meteor routes reach the cities of Lower Countries.

sentence: FreightCSX Transportation and Norfolk Southern are the only Class I railway companies in South Carolina, as other freight companies in the state are short lines.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are seven important airports in South Carolina, all of which act as regional airport centres.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Charleston International Airport is the busiest of all passengers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On the other side of the North Carolina border, Charlotte/Douglas International Airport is the 30th busiest airport in the world in terms of passengers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2010, South Carolina was one of the three states that did not agree to use internationally competitive math and language standards.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2014, the South Carolina Supreme Court ruled that the state had not provided "minimumly adequate" education to children in all parts of the state, as required by the state constitution.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has 1,144 K-12 schools in 85 school districts, with a enrolment rate of 712,244 in the fall of 2009.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Starting in the 2008-2009 school year, South Carolina spent $9,450 per student, placing it 31st in the country for spending per student.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2015, the national average TSS was 1490 and South Carolina was 1442, 48 points lower than the national average.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is the only state that owns and operates a State-wide school bus system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In December 2016, the State maintained a fleet of 5,582 buses, the average vehicle in service being 15 years old (the national average is six) having travelled 236 000 miles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Half of the state's school buses are more than 15 years old, and some would be up to 30 years old.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2017 in the draft budget, Education Superintendent Molly Spearman asked the government lease to purchase 1,000 buses to replace the most decrepit vehicles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: An additional 175 buses could be purchased immediately as part of the Treasury's main lease program.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On January 5, 2017, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency awarded South Carolina more than $1.1 million to replace 57 school buses with new cleaner models through its Diesel Emissions Reduction Act.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has a variety of institutions, ranging from large publicly funded research universities to small colleges that cultivate liberal arts, religious or military traditions.

name: south_carolina
sentence: For all health care, South Carolina ranks 33rd out of 50 states, according to the Commonwealth Fund, a private health foundation working to improve the health care system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Kaiser Family Foundation, the State teenage birth rate was 53 births per 1,000 adolescents, compared to the national average of 41.9 births.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State infant mortality rate was 9.4 deaths per 1,000 births, compared with the national average of 6.9 deaths.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There were 2.6 physicians per 1,000 persons compared to the national average of 3.2 physicians.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Health spending per capita in the State was $5,114, compared to a national average of $5,283.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There were 26 per cent of children and 13 per cent of seniors living in poverty in the state, compared to 23 per cent and 13 per cent, respectively, doing so in the United States, and 34 per cent of children were overweight or obese, compared to the national average of 32 per cent.
