name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is a U.S. state located in the Midwest region of the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It bears the name of the Amerindian tribes Lakota and Dakota Sioux, which represent a large part of the population and historically dominate the territory.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is the seventeenth largest by region, but the fifth least populated, and fifth least dense of the 50 United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As a southern part of the former Dakota territory, South Dakota became a state on November 2, 1889, along with North Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This is either the 39th or the 40th State admitted to union.

name: south_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison modified the state documents before signing them so that no one would know what became a state first.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Pierre is the capital of the state, and Sioux Falls, with a population of about 187,200 inhabitants, is the largest city in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is bordered by the states of North Dakota (north), Minnesota (east), Iowa (southeast), Nebraska (south), Wyoming (west), and Montana (northwest).

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state is divided by Missouri, dividing South Dakota into two geographically and socially distinct halves, known to residents as the "East River" and the "West River."

name: south_dakota
sentence: Eastern South Dakota is home to most of the state's population, and the fertile soil in the area is used to cultivate a variety of crops.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the west of Missouri, livestock is the main agricultural activity, and the economy is more dependent on tourism and defence spending.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Most of the Amerindian reserves are in the West River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills, a group of low-covered mountains of sacred Sioux pines, are located in the southwestern part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mount Rushmore, an important tourist destination, is here.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a temperate continental climate, with four distinct seasons and precipitation ranging from moderate to semi-arid to the west.

name: south_dakota
sentence: State ecology has species typical of a North American prairie biome.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Humans lived in the area for several millennia, the Sioux becoming dominant at the beginning of the 19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the late 19th century, Euro-American colonization intensified after a gold rush in the black hills and the construction of eastern railways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The encircled miners and settlers triggered a number of Indian wars, culminating in the massacre of the wounded knee in 1890.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Key events in the 20th century included the Dust Bowl and the Great Depression, increased federal spending in the 1940s and 1950s on agriculture and defence, and an industrialization of agriculture that reduced family farming.

name: south_dakota
sentence: While several Democrats have represented South Dakota for multiple terms in both chambers of Congress, the state government is largely controlled by the Republican Party, whose candidates have carried South Dakota to each of the last 13 presidential elections.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Historically dominated by an agricultural economy and a rural way of life, South Dakota has recently sought to diversify its economy in the regions to attract and retain residents.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The history of South Dakota and its rural character still have a strong influence on the culture of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is located in the north central United States and is considered to be part of the Midwest by the United States Census Bureau and is also part of the Great Plains region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Western South Dakota culture, economy and geography are more common in the west than in the Midwest.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a total area of 77 116 square miles (199730 km2), making the state the 17th largest in the Union.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Elk Peak, formerly Harney Peak, with an altitude of 7,242 ft (2,207 m), is the highest point in the state, while the shore of Big Stone Lake is the lowest, with an altitude of 966 ft (294 m).

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is bordered north by North Dakota

name: south_dakota
sentence: The geographic centre of the United States is 27 km west of Castle Rock, Butte County.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The North American continental pole of inaccessibility is located between Allen and Kyle, 1024 mi (1,648 km) from the nearest coastline.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Missouri River is the largest and longest river in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Cheyenne, James, Big Sioux, and White rivers are other major rivers in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The eastern South Dakota has many natural lakes, mostly created by periods of glaciation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In addition, the Missouri dams create four large reservoirs: Oahe Lake, Sharpe Lake, Francis Case Lake, Lewis Lake, and Clark Lake.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is generally divided into three regions: eastern South Dakota, western South Dakota, and the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River serves as a boundary in terms of geographical, social and political differences between eastern and western South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The geography of the Black Hills, long considered sacred by the Amerindians, differs from its environment to the extent that it can be considered distinct from the rest of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sometimes the Black Hills are combined with the rest of western South Dakota, and people often refer to the two resulting regions, divided by the Missouri River, such as the West River and the East River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Eastern South Dakota generally has higher precipitation and lower topography than the western part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Smaller geographic areas include the Prairie Coteau, the Dissolved Till Plains and the James River Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Prairie Coteau is a plateau bordered to the east by the Minnesota River Valley, and to the west by the James River Basin.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Further to the west, the James River basin is primarily low, flat and heavily eroded land, following the flow of the James River through South Dakota from north to south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Till Plains Dissected, an area of hilly hills and fertile soil covering much of Iowa and Nebraska, extends to the southeast corner of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The layers deposited during the Pleistocene era, from about two million years ago, cover most of eastern South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: These are the youngest layers of rock and sediment in the state, the product of successive periods of glaciation that deposited a large amount of rock and soil, known as till, on the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Great Plains cover most of the western part of two thirds of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the west of Missouri, the landscape becomes more arid and more rugged, composed of hilly hills, plains, ravines and steep flat-top hills called buttes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the south, east of the Black Hills, we find the Badlands of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The erosion of the Black Hills, marine skeletons that fell to the bottom of a vast shallow sea that once covered the area, and volcanic material all contribute to the geology of this region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills are located in the southwest part of South Dakota and extend to Wyoming.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This range of low mountains covers 6,000 km2 (16 000 km2), with peaks increasing from 2,000 to 4,000 feet (600 to 1,200 m) above their bases.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills are the location of Black Elk Peak (7,242 ft or 2,207 m above sea level), the highest point in South Dakota, and also the highest point in the United States east of the Rocky Mountains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The two billion-year-old Precambrian formations, the oldest rocks in the state, form the central nucleus of the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The formations of the Paleozoic era formed the outer ring of the black hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This area presents rocks such as limestone, which were deposited here when the area formed the shore of an ancient inland sea.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Much of South Dakota (except Black Hills) is dominated by a temperate prairie biome.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although grasses and crops cover most of this area, deciduous trees such as cottonwood, elms and willows are common near rivers and in shelter belts.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state bird, the collared pheasant, adapted well to the region after being introduced from China.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Increasing populations of bald eagles spread throughout the state, particularly near the Missouri River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Prairie rivers and lakes are home to populations of goldeneye, carp, pike, bass and other species.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River also houses the prehistoric spatular.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Due to higher elevations and precipitation levels, the ecology of the Black Hills differs significantly from that of the plains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The mountains are covered with various types of pines, including ponderosa and lodgepole pines, as well as spruce.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Hills mammals include deer, elk, sheep, mountain goats, pine martens, and mountain lions, while streams and lakes contain several species of trout.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a continental climate with four distinct seasons, ranging from cold and dry winters to hot and semi-wet summers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: During summers, the average state temperature is often close to 90°F (32°C), although it cools to almost 60°F (16°C) at night.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is not uncommon for South Dakota to have severe warm and dry periods in summer with temperatures rising above 100°F (38°C) several times a year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Winters are cold, with high January temperatures being on average below freezing temperature and low temperatures being on average below 10°F (−12°C) in most of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 120°F (49°C) at Usta on 15 July 2006 and the lowest recorded temperature was −58°F (−50°C) at McIntosh on 17 February 1936.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Average annual precipitation in South Dakota ranges from semi-arid conditions in the northwestern part of the state (approximately 15 inches or 380 mm) to semi-wet conditions around the southeastern part of the state (approximately 25 inches or 640 mm), although a small lead-centered area in the black hills has the highest precipitation at nearly 30 inches (760 mm) per year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The summers of South Dakota lead to frequent, sometimes severe, thunderstorms with strong winds, thunders and hail.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The eastern part of the State is often considered part of the Tornado gangway, and South Dakota suffers an average of 30 tornadoes each year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Severe blizzards and ice storms often occur in winter.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has several sites managed by the National Parks Service.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two national parks were established in the state, both in the southwest region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Wind Cave National Park, established in 1903 in the Black Hills, has a vast network of caves and a large herd of bison.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Badlands National Park was established in 1978 and is home to a brightly coloured, eroded landscape surrounded by semi-arid grasslands.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Rushmore Mountain National Memorial, located in the Black Hills, was established in 1925.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The sculpture of four American presidents was carved on the side of the mountain by sculptor Gutzon Borglum.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other areas managed by the National Parks Service include the Jewel Cave National Monument near Custer, the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail, Minuteman Missile National Historic Site, which includes a decommissioned nuclear missile silo and a separate multi-kilometre missile control area, and the Missouri National Recreational River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Crazy Horse Memorial is a large mountainside sculpture near Mount Rushmore, which is built with private funds.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Mammouth site near Hot Springs is another private attraction in Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is a paleontological excavation of work and has one of the highest concentrations of mammoth remains in the world.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Humans have been living in what is today South Dakota for thousands of years.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The first inhabitants were Paleoindian hunter-gatherers and disappeared from the area around 5000 BC.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Between 500 and 800 AD, a semi-nomadic population known as the Mound Builders lived in central and eastern South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 14th century, the Crow Creek massacre took place, in which hundreds of men, women and children were killed near the Missouri River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As early as 1500, the Arikara (or Ree) had settled in much of the Missouri Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: European contact with the region began in 1743 when the LaVérendrye brothers explored the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The LaVérendrye group buried a plaque near the site of modern Pierre, claiming the region for France as part of the Great Louisiana.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1762, the entire region became part of the Spanish Louisiana until 1802.

name: south_dakota
sentence: By the early 19th century, the Sioux had largely replaced Arikara as the dominant group in the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1803 the United States purchased the territory of Louisiana, a region that included most of South Dakota from Napoleon Bonaparte, and President Thomas Jefferson organized a group commonly known as the "Lewis and Clark Expedition" to explore the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1817, an American fur trade post was established at the present Fort Pierre, which began to settle continuously in the United States in the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1855, the American army purchased Fort Pierre, but abandoned it in 1857 in favour of Fort Randall in the south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: At that time, the establishment by the Americans and Europeans increased rapidly, and in 1858 the Yankton Sioux signed the Treaty of 1858, giving to the United States most of the present South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The land speculators founded two of the largest cities in South Dakota today: Sioux Falls in 1856 and Yankton in 1859.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1861, the territory of Dakota was created by the United States government (it originally included North Dakota, South Dakota and parts of Montana and Wyoming).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Colonization of the region, mainly by residents of the eastern United States as well as western and northern Europe, increased rapidly, especially after the completion of an eastern rail link to Yankton in 1873.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1874 gold was discovered in the Black Hills during a military expedition led by George A. Custer and miners and explorers began illegally entering the land promised to the Lakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Custer expedition took place despite the fact that the Sioux had received the entire western half of the present South Dakota (West River) in 1868 by the Treaty of Laramie under the Great Sioux Reserve.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Sioux refused to grant mining rights or lands in the Black Hills, and the war broke out after the United States did not prevent white miners and settlers from entering the area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Finally, the United States won and separated the Great Sioux Reserve into five reserves, settling the Lakota there.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1980, the Supreme Court and Congress ordered compensation, but the Lakota still refused to accept it, insisting on the restitution of their lands.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A growing population and political concerns (the accession of two states meant the arrival of four new senators for the Republican Party) caused the division of Dakota territory and President Benjamin Harrison signed proclamations in which he officially admitted South Dakota and North Dakota to union on November 2, 1889.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Harrison had the papers tight to mask which was signed first and the order was not recorded.

name: south_dakota
sentence: On 29 December 1890, the massacre of the injured knee occurred in the Pine Ridge Indian Reserve.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Considered the last major armed conflict between the United States and the Lakota Sioux nation, this massacre resulted in the death of at least 146 Sioux, many of whom were women and children.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 31 U.S. soldiers were also killed during the conflict.

name: south_dakota
sentence: During the 1930s, several economic and climate conditions combined with disastrous results for South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Lack of precipitation, extremely high temperatures and inappropriate cultivation techniques produced what was known as the Dust Bowl in South Dakota and several other plain states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Fertile soil was blown into massive dust storms, and several crops were completely destroyed.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The experiences of the Dust Bowl, coupled with the seizure of local banks and the general economic effects of the Great Depression, led to the release of many Dakotas from the south of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The South Dakota population declined by more than 7% between 1930 and 1940.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Economic stability returned with the entry of the United States into the Second World War in 1941, when demand for state agricultural and industrial products increased as the nation mobilized for war.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1944, the Pick–Sloan Plan was adopted by the U.S. Congress as part of the 1944 Flood Control Act, resulting in the construction of six large dams on the Missouri River, four of which are at least partially located in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The control of floods, hydropower and recreational activities, such as boating and fishing, is ensured by dams and their reservoirs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In recent decades, South Dakota has moved from a state dominated by agriculture to a state with a more diversified economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The tourism industry has grown considerably since the completion of the interstate system in the 1960s, with Black Hills becoming an increasingly important destination.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The financial services sector also began to grow in the state, with the transfer of the Citibank from its credit card operations in New York to Sioux Falls in 1981, a movement that was followed by several other financial companies.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota was the first State to eliminate interest rate ceilings.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2007, the recently closed Homestake Gold Mine site near Lead was selected as a site for a new underground research facility, the Deep Underground Science and Engineering Laboratory.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Despite the growth of the State's population and recent economic development, many rural areas have struggled over the past 50 years with the decline of local populations and the emigration of educated young adults to major cities in South Dakota, such as Rapid City or Sioux Falls, or to other states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mechanization and consolidation of agriculture have greatly contributed to the reduction in the number of small family farms and the resulting economic and demographic challenges for rural cities.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, the state often ranks first for its way of life, and Gallup's Well-Being Index in 2018 has named South Dakota the happiest and healthier state in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the population of South Dakota was 884,659 on July 1, 2019, an 8.66 per cent increase over the 2010 U.S. census, while only North Dakota, Alaska, Vermont and Wyoming have fewer residents.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2019, the population of South Dakota was estimated at 884,659, an increase of 70,479 or 8.66% since 2010.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 7.3% of the population of South Dakota was under the age of 5, 24% under the age of 18 and 14.3% over the age of 65.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Women make up about 50.2 per cent of the population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 2000 census, South Dakota ranked fifth in the population and population density.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Of the South Dakota population, 65.7 per cent were born in South Dakota, 31.4 per cent were born in another U.S. state, 0.6 per cent were born in Puerto Rico, parts of the United States island or were born abroad to U.S. parents, and 2.3 per cent were born in another country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The South Dakota population centre is located in Buffalo County, in the unincorporated county seat of Gann Valley County.

name: south_dakota
sentence: According to the 2010 Census, the racial composition of the population was as follows:

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ethnically, 2.7 per cent of the population of South Dakota was of Hispanic, Latin or Spanish origin (they may be of any race).

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2011, 25.4% of the population of South Dakota under 1 years of age were minorities, which means that there was at least one non-Hispanic white parent.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2000, the five main ancestry groups of South Dakota were German (40.7%), Norwegian (15.3%), Irish (10.4%), Native American (8.3%), and English (7.1%).

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Germans are the largest ancestry group in most parts of the state, especially in the eastern part of the river (eastern Missouri), although there are also large Scandinavian populations in some counties.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has the largest population of Hutterites, a communal anabaptist group that emigrated in 1874 from Europe, mainly from German-speaking regions.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Indians, largely Lakota, Dakota and Nakota (Sioux), are predominant in several counties and account for 20 per cent of the West River population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The seven major Indian reserves of the state occupy a very small area compared to the former Sioux Great Reserve of the West River, which the federal government had previously attributed to the Sioux tribes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has the third largest proportion of Amerindians in all states, behind Alaska and New Mexico.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Five of the state's counties are entirely within the limits of sovereign Indian reserves.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Because of the limitations of climate and land, and the isolation of urban areas with more employment opportunities, the standard of living on many South Dakota reserves is often well below the national average; Ziebach County ranked as the poorest county in the nation in 2009.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The unemployment rate in Fort Thompson, Crow Creek Reserve, is 70% and 21% of households do not have basic plumbing or kitchen equipment.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A 1995 study by the U.S. Census Bureau found that 58% of homes on the Pine Ridge Indian Reserve did not have telephones.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The isolation of reserves also impedes their ability to generate income from gambling casinos, an avenue that has proved profitable for many tribes closer to urban centres.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1995, the legislature passed a law making English the "common language" of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since 2019, "the language of the Great Sioux Nation, composed of three dialects, Dakota, Lakota and Nakota", is an official language.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 2000 census, 1.90 per cent of the population aged 5 years or older speak German at home, 1.51 per cent speak Lakota or Dakota, and 1.43 per cent speak Spanish.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2010, 93.46% (692,504) of South Dakota residents aged 5 years and older spoke English as their main language.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 6.54 per cent of the population spoke a language other than English.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 2.06 % (15,292) of the population speak Spanish, 1.39 % (10,282) speak Dakota and 1.37% (10,140) speak German.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The other languages spoken were Vietnamese (0.16 per cent), Chinese (0.12 per cent) and Russian (0.10 per cent).

name: south_dakota
sentence: In recent decades, the population of many rural areas has declined in South Dakota, as in other states of the Great Plains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The change was described as a "rural leak" as family farming declined.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Young people moved to cities to find more jobs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This trend has continued in recent years, with 30 counties in South Dakota losing their population between the 1990 census and the 2000 census.

name: south_dakota
sentence: During this period, nine counties suffered a population loss of more than 10 per cent, with Harding County in the northwest corner of the state losing nearly 19 per cent of its population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Low birth rates and the lack of young immigrants have led to an increase in the median age of many of these counties.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 24 counties, at least 20% of the population is over the age of 65, compared with a national rate of 12.8 per cent.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, the effect of rural flight was not uniformly spread in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although most rural counties and small towns have lost population, the Sioux Falls region, the largest counties along Interstate 29, the Black Hills and many Indian reserves have all gained population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As the reserves exercised more sovereignty, some Sioux returned to urban areas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Lincoln County near Sioux Falls was the fastest growing seventh (percentage) county in the U.S. in 2010.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Growth in these regions offset losses in the rest of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The total population of South Dakota continues to increase steadily, albeit at a slower rate than the national average.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The largest denominations by membership in 2010 were the Roman Catholic Church with 148,883 members, the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America (ELCA) with 112,649 members and the United Methodist Church (UMC) with 36,020 members.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (ELCA and UMC are specific denominations in the broader terms "Lutheran" and "Methodist", respectively.

name: south_dakota
sentence: )The results of a 2001 survey in which the South Dakotas were asked to identify their religion include:

name: south_dakota
sentence: Government revenue in current South Dakota dollars was $39.8 billion in 2010, the fifth smallest state output in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Per capita personal income was $38,865 in 2010, ranking 25th in the United States, and 12.5% of the population was below the poverty line in 2008.The list of the CNBC's Top States for Business for 2010 recognized South Dakota as the seventh best state of the nation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As of July 2011, the state unemployment rate was 4.7%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The services industry is the largest economic contributor to South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This sector includes the retail, financial and health care sectors.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Citibank, which was the largest banking holding company in the United States at one time, established domestic banking operations in South Dakota in 1981 in order to take advantage of favourable banking rules.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Public spending is another important segment of the state economy, accounting for more than 10 per cent of gross national product.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ellsworth Air Force Base, near Rapid City, is the second-largest single employer in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Agriculture has always been a key component of the South Dakota economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although other industries have experienced rapid growth in recent decades, agricultural production remains very important for the state economy, especially in rural areas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The five most valuable agricultural products in South Dakota are livestock, maize, soybeans, wheat and pigs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Agriculture-related industries, such as meat packaging and ethanol production, also have a considerable economic impact on the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is the sixth largest ethanol producer in the country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Another important sector of South Dakota's economy is tourism.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Many travel to see the attractions of the state, especially those of the Black Hills area, such as the historic Deadwood, Rushmore Mount, and neighbouring national and state parks.

name: south_dakota
sentence: One of the largest tourist events in the state is the annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The five-day event attracted over 739,000 participants in 2015; as the state has a total population of 850,000.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2006, tourism provided some 33,000 government jobs and contributed more than $2 billion to the South Dakota economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has 83,609 miles (134556 km) of highways, roads and streets, as well as 679 miles (1,093 km) of interstate highways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two major interstates cross South Dakota: Interstate 90, which crosses the southern half of the State to the east and west, and Interstate 29, which extends north and south in the eastern part of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Corridor I-29 generally has higher population and economic growth rates than areas in eastern South Dakota farther from the interstate.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Also in the state are the shorter Interstates 190, a spur in the center of Rapid City, and 229, a loop around the south and east of Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Several major American highways cross the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American roads 12, 14, 16, 18 and 212 travel east and west, while U.S. roads 81, 83, 85 and 281 travel north and south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota and Montana are the only states that share a land border that is not crossed by an asphalt road.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The South Dakota contains two national bypass routes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Peter Norbeck National Scenic Byway is in the Black Hills, while the Native American Scenic Byway runs along the Missouri River in the north-central part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other scenic passages include the Badlands Loop Scenic Byway, the Spearfish Canyon Scenic Byway, and the Wildlife Loop Road Scenic Byway.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Railways have played an important role in South Dakota transport since the mid-19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Some 7,110 kilometres of railway were built in South Dakota in the late 19th century and early 20th century, but only 3,960 kilometres are active.

name: south_dakota
sentence: BNSF Railway is the largest railway in South Dakota; Rapid City, Pierre and Eastern Railroad (formerly Dakota, Minnesota and East) is the other largest carrier in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other state carriers include Dakota Southern Railway, Dakota and Iowa Railroad, Ellis and Eastern Railroad, Sunfloor Railroad, Canadian Pacific Railway and Sisseton Milbank Railroad.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rail transportation in the state is mostly freight, but there are two historic passenger railways: the Black Hills Central and the Prairie Village, Herman and Milwaukee.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, South Dakota is one of two contiguous states that do not have Amtrak's service.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (South Dakota is the only contiguous state that has never had Amtrak—Wyoming was served by the San Francisco Zephyr and Pioneer.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: The largest commercial airports in South Dakota in terms of passenger traffic are Sioux Falls Regional Airport and Rapid City Regional Airport.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Delta Air Lines, Frontier Airlines and Allegiant Airlines, as well as the suburban airlines using the affiliate brand with the major airlines, serve the two largest airports.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Several other cities in the State also have commercial air services: Aberdeen Regional Airport, Pierre Regional Airport and Watertown Regional Airport, some of which are subsidized by the essential air services program.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Like other American states, the structure of the South Dakota government follows the same separation of powers as the federal government, with the executive, legislative and judicial branches.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The structure of the Government of the State is defined in the Constitution of South Dakota, the highest law of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Constitution may be amended by a majority vote of the two Houses of the Legislative Assembly or by the initiative of the electors.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Governor of South Dakota occupies the executive power of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The present governor is Kristi Noem, a Republican.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Constitution of the State gives the Governor the power to sign laws or bills on the veto adopted by the legislature of the State, to exercise the functions of commander-in-chief of the National Guard of South Dakota, to appoint a cabinet, to commute criminal penalties or to pardon persons convicted of crimes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Governor is appointed for a term of four years and may not serve more than two consecutive terms.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The legislature consists of two bodies, the 35-member Senate and the 70-member House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is divided into 35 legislative districts, with voters electing two representatives and one senator per district.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Parliament meets for an annual session which begins on the second Tuesday in January and lasts 30 days

name: south_dakota
sentence: The judiciary is made up of several levels.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The State Supreme Court, composed of four judges and one chief justice, is the highest court in the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Below the Supreme Court are circuit courts.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Below the circuit courts are the courts of first instance, which deal with criminal and civil cases of lesser importance.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota had the lowest per capita tax rate in the United States in 2005.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Crown does not collect personal or corporate income tax, estate tax or tax on intangible personal property.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The government sales tax rate is 4.5 per cent.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Various localities have local levies, so in some areas the rate is 6 per cent.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Crown's sales tax does not apply to Indian sales on Indian reserves, but many reserves have a contract with the Crown.

name: south_dakota
sentence: On-reserve businesses collect the tax and government refunds from Indian tribes the percentage of sales tax collected in relation to the ratio of the Indian population to the total population of the affected county or region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ad valorem property taxes are local taxes and are an important source of financing for school systems, counties, municipalities and other local governments.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Special Tax Division of South Dakota regulates certain taxes, including taxes on cigarettes and alcohol.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is represented at the federal level by Senator John Thune, Senator Mike Rounds and Representative Dusty Johnson.

name: south_dakota
sentence: All three are Republicans.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is one of seven States with only one seat in the United States House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the United States presidential elections, South Dakota received three out of 538 votes in the Electoral College.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As in all other states, with the exception of the neighbouring Maine and Nebraska, South Dakota's electoral votes are granted in a winning system.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota's policies are generally dominated by the Republican Party.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since the creation of the state, the Republicans have won state electoral votes in all but five presidential elections: 1896, 1912 (by the Progressive Party of Theodore Roosevelt), 1932, 1936 and 1964.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (Democratic George McGovern, from South Dakota, failed to carry his country of origin in 1972.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: Only Alaska was worn less often by a democrat.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In addition, a democrat has not won the post of governor since 1974.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2016, the Republicans hold a 15% registration advantage over the Democrats and hold large majorities in the Chamber of State and the Senator of State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Despite the republican and conservative general inclinations of the state, democrats have been successful in various state-wide elections, including those involving representatives of the South Dakota Congress in Washington.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Indians have become more active in state and county electoral policy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 2002 election, the American Indian vote carried Tim Johnson as a Democratic candidate by a margin of 532 votes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Until his election defeat in 2004, Senator Tom Daschle was the leader of the Senators' minority (and briefly his majority leader during the democratic control of the Senators in 2001-2002).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other prominent Democrats in South Dakota include former presidential candidates George McGovern and Hubert Humphrey.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2016, South Dakota voted for Republican candidate Donald Trump against Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton with a margin of 30%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2018, Republican MP Kristi Noem beat Democrat Billie Sutton in the Gubernatorial election by a small margin, and Republican Dusty Johnson defeated Democrat Tim Bjorkman for the state seat in the US House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Contemporary political issues in South Dakota include the costs and benefits of the state lottery, the relatively low ranking of South Dakota in education spending (especially teachers' compensation – the state sales tax has recently been increased from 4 per cent to 4.5 per cent to finance an increase in teachers' remuneration), and recent legislative and electoral attempts to ban abortion in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A bill supported by the Republicans passed in March 2019 requires that all public schools display "In God we trust" in a prominent place.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota culture reflects the Indian, rural, western and European American roots of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A number of annual events celebrating the state's ethnic and historical heritage are held around the state, such as Days of '76 in Deadwood, Czech Days in Tabor, and the annual festivities of St. Patrick and Cinco de Mayo in Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The various tribes hold many annual pow wows on their reserves throughout the state, to which non-native Americans are sometimes invited.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Custer State Park holds an annual Buffalo Roundup, where horse volunteers gather the park's herd of approximately 1,500 bison.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Elk (Lakota) was a medical and heyokha man whose life extended to the transition to reserves.

name: south_dakota
sentence: His stories of the Indian War movement and 19th-century phantom dance, and his deep thoughts on personal visions and Amerindian religion, form the basis of the book Black Elk Speaks, first published in 1932.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (In several editions, a first annotated edition was published in 2008.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: Paul Goble, author and illustrator of award-winning children's books, has been based at the Black Hills since 1977.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Laura Ingalls Wilder, whose semi-autobiographical books are based on her experiences as a child and young adult at the border, is one of the most well-known writers in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: She derived her life from a home near De Smet as a base for five of her novels: By the Shores of Silver Lake, The Long Winter, Little Town on the Prairie, This Happy Golden Years and The First Four Years.

name: south_dakota
sentence: They gained a renewed popularity in the United States when Little House on the Prairie was adapted and produced as a television series in 1974.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Wilder's daughter, Rose Wilder Lane, who became a fully-known writer, was born near De Smet in 1886.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has also produced several outstanding artists.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Harvey Dunn grew up in a house near Manchester at the end of the 19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: While Dunn worked most of his career as a commercial illustrator, his most famous works showed various scenes of border life; he finished those near the end of his career.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Oscar Howe (Crow) was born in Crow Creek Indian Reserve and won fame for his watercolour paintings.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Howe was one of the first Amerindian painters to adopt techniques and style strongly influenced by the mid-20th century abstraction movement, rather than relying on traditional Amerindian styles.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Terry Redlin, originally from Watertown, was an accomplished painter of rural and wildlife scenes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Many of his works are on display at the Redlin Art Center in Watertown.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sioux Falls is the largest city in South Dakota, with a population of 153,888 inhabitants in 2010 and a metropolitan area of 238,122 inhabitants.The city, founded in 1856, is located in the southeast corner of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Retailing, finance and health care became more important in Sioux Falls, where the economy was originally focused on agro-industry and career.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City, with a population of 67,956 and a metropolitan area of 124,766, is the second largest city in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is located at the eastern edge of the Black Hills, and was founded in 1876.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City's economy is largely based on tourism and defense spending, due to the proximity of many tourist attractions in the Black Hills and Ellsworth Air Force Base.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The next eight cities in the state, by order of population in 2010, are Aberdeen (26,091), Brookings (22,056), Watertown (21,482), Mitchell (15,254), Yankton (14,454), Pierre (13,646), Huron (12,592) and Vermillion (10,571).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Pierre is the capital of the state, and Brookings and Vermillion are the sites of the two largest universities of the state (South Dakota State University and South Dakota University, respectively).

name: south_dakota
sentence: With a population of about 14,000, Pierre is the second-largest state capital in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Of the ten largest cities in the state, only the fast city is to the west of Missouri.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The first South Dakota newspaper, the Democratic Dakota, started publishing in Yankton in 1858.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Today, the largest newspaper in the State is the Sioux Falls Argus Leader, with a Sunday draw of 63,701 and a weekday draw of 44,334.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Rapid City Journal, with a Sunday draw of 32,638 and a week's draw of 27,827, is the second largest newspaper in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The other four largest newspapers in the state are the Aberdeen American News, Watertown public opinion, Huron Plainsman and the Brookings Register.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1981, Tim Giago founded the Lakota Times as a newspaper for the local American Indian community on the Pine Ridge Indian Reserve.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The newspaper, now published in New York and known as Indian Country Today, is available in every state of the country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sioux City Journal also covers parts of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Nine television stations broadcast programs in South Dakota; South Dakota public television broadcasts programs in a number of locations around the state, while the other stations broadcast programs in Sioux Falls or Rapid City.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The two largest television markets in South Dakota are Sioux Falls-Mitchell, with a 246,020 screen, and Rapid City, with a 91,070 screen.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The two markets rank 114th and 177th respectively in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The first State television station, KELO-TV, was broadcast in Sioux Falls in 1953.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Among the first KELO programs was Captain 11, a program for children in the afternoon.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Captain 11 ran from 1955 to 1996, making him the longest children's television program in the country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A number of South Dakotas are famous for their work in TV and publishing.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The former anchor and author of NBC Nightly News Tom Brokaw is from Webster and Yankton, USA Today the founder Al Neuharth was from Eureka and Alpena, the game host Bob Barker spent much of his childhood in Mission, and entertainment hosts Pat O'Brien and Mary Hart are from Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2006, there were 136,872 enrolments in primary and secondary schools in South Dakota, including 120,278 in the public school system.

name: south_dakota
sentence: There are 703 public schools in 168 school districts, giving South Dakota the highest number of schools per capita in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The current high school graduation rate is 89.9%, and the average TCA score is 21.8, slightly higher than the national average of 21.1.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 89.8% of the adult population had at least one high school diploma, and 25.8% had one or more bachelor's degrees.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2008, the average salary of teachers in public schools in South Dakota was $36,674, the lowest in the country (the national average was $52,308).

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2007, South Dakota passed a law inspired by the Indian Education for All Act (1999) of Montana, which requires education on Amerindian tribal history, culture and heritage in all schools, from pre-school to college, in order to increase awareness and appreciation of Indian culture among all residents of the state and to enhance understanding of Indian students' contributions to their own culture.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Council of Regents of South Dakota, whose members are appointed by the governor, controls the six public universities of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota State University (SDSU) in Brookings is the largest university in the state, with a enrolment of 12,831 students.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The University of South Dakota (USD), located in Vermillion, is the oldest university in the state and has the only law and medicine school in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota also has a number of private universities, the most important of which is the Augustana University of Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Due to its low population, South Dakota does not host large leagues of professional sports franchises.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state has minor leagues and independent leagues, all of which play in Sioux Falls or Rapid City.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sioux Falls has four teams: the Sioux Falls Canaris (baseball), the Sioux Falls Skyforce (basketball), the Sioux Falls Stampede (hockey) and the Sioux Falls Storm (inside American football).

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Canary Islands play in the American Association, and their home ground is Sioux Falls Stadium.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Skyforce plays in the NBA G League and is owned by the Miami Heat of the NBA.

name: south_dakota
sentence: They play Pentagon Sanford.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Stampede and Storm share Denny Sanford Premier Centre.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Stampede room in the USHL, and Storm room in the IFL.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City has a hockey team named Rapid City Rush that plays in the ECHL.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Rush began their inaugural season in 2008 at the Rushmore Plaza Civic Center.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota universities run a variety of sports programmes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: For many years South Dakota was one of the only states in the country without a NCAA Division I football or basketball team.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, several years ago, SDSU decided to transfer its teams from Division II to Division I, an initiative followed by the University of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other government universities compete at the NCAA or NAIA Division II or III levels.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Famous South Dakota athletes include Billy Mills, Mike Miller, Mark Ellis, Becky Hammon, Brock Lesnar, Chad Greenway, and Adam Vinatieri.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mills was born in the city of Pine Ridge and participated in the 1964 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, becoming the only American to win a gold medal in the 10,000-metre event.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mitchell's Miller is a two-time NBA champion who played university basketball at the University of Florida, leading them to the 2000 NCAA Championship game in his second year, and won the 2001 NBA Rookie of the Year award.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ellis, from Rapid City, played for the University of Florida and four MLB teams before retiring in 2015.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Hammon of Rapid City played for the WNBA New York Liberty and San Antonio Silver Stars before becoming assistant coach for the NBA San Antonio Spurs in 2014.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Webster's Lesnar is a former heavyweight champion in UFC and WWE.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Vinatieri is an NFL Placekicker who grew up in Rapid City and attended the SDSU.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Fishing and hunting are popular open-air activities in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Fishing contributes more than $224 million to the economy of South Dakota, and hunting contributes more than $303 million.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2007, more than 275,000 hunting permits and 175,000 fishing permits were sold in the state; approximately half of the hunting licences and more than two thirds of the fishing licences were purchased by South Dakotas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The most popular game species include pheasants, white-tailed deer, mule deer and turkeys, as well as waterfowl such as Canada geese, snow geese and mallards.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Targets for anglers include walleye in the eastern glacial lakes and the Missouri River reservoirs, chinook salmon in Oahe Lake and trout in the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other sports such as cycling and running are also popular in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1991, the state opened the George S. Mickelson Trail, a 175-km railway in the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In addition to being used by cyclists, the trail is also the site of part of the annual Rushmore Mountain marathon; the entire marathon route is at an altitude of more than 4,000 feet (1,200 m).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other events in the state include the Tour de Kota, a 478 miles (769 km), a six-day cycling event that covers much of eastern and central South Dakota, and the annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally, which attracts hundreds of thousands of participants from across the United States.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee () is a state in the southeastern part of the United States of America.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee is the 36th largest by region and the 16th most populated of the 50 states.

name: tennessee
sentence: It is bordered by eight states, with Kentucky in the north, Virginia in the northeast, North Carolina in the east, Georgia, Alabama and Mississippi in the south, Arkansas in the west, and Missouri in the northwest.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Appalachians dominate the eastern part of the state, and the Mississippi forms its western border.

name: tennessee
sentence: Nashville is the capital of the state and the largest city, with a 2019 population of 670,820 inhabitants and a 2019 metro population of 1,934,317.

name: tennessee
sentence: The second largest city in Tennessee is Memphis, which has a population of 651,073 and a metro population of 1,346,045 inhabitants in 2019.

name: tennessee
sentence: The State of Tennessee is rooted in the Watauga Association, a border pact of 1772 generally regarded as the first constitutional government west of the Appalachians.

name: tennessee
sentence: What is now Tennessee was originally part of North Carolina, then the Southwest Territory.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee was admitted into the Union as 16th State on 1 June 1796.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee was the last state to leave the Union and join Confederation at the beginning of the American civil war in 1861.

name: tennessee
sentence: Occupied by the Union forces from 1862 onwards, he was the first state to be resettled in the Union at the end of the war.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee has provided more soldiers for the Confederate Army than any other state outside Virginia, and more soldiers for the Union Army than the rest of the combined Confederation.

name: tennessee
sentence: From the reconstruction he had a competitive party policy, but a democratic takeover in the late 1880s had led to the adoption of laws on the abandonment of the right to vote that excluded most blacks and many poor whites from voting.

name: tennessee
sentence: This reduced political competition in the state until after the adoption of civil rights legislation in the mid-20th century, although unlike in the deep South, the Republicans of Tennessee still expected at least a third of the vote in state-wide elections via the East Tennessee and the Highland Rim Unionists.

name: tennessee
sentence: In the 20th century, Tennessee moved from an agrarian economy to a more diversified economy, assisted by massive federal investments in the Tennessee Valley Authority and, in the early 1940s, in the city of Oak Ridge.

name: tennessee
sentence: This city was founded just outside Knoxville to house the Manhattan project's uranium enrichment facilities, helping to build the world's first atomic bombs, two of which were dropped on Imperial Japan towards the end of World War II.

name: tennessee
sentence: After the war, the Oak Ridge National Laboratory became and remains a key centre of scientific research.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2016, the tennessine element was named for the state, largely in recognition of the roles played by Oak Ridge, Vanderbilt University and the University of Tennessee in discovering the element.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee's major industries include agriculture, manufacturing and tourism.

name: tennessee
sentence: Poultry, soybeans and livestock are the government's main agricultural products and the major manufacturing exports include chemicals, transportation equipment and electrical equipment.

name: tennessee
sentence: Great Smoky Mountains National Park, the most visited national park in the country, is located in the eastern part of the state, and part of the Appalachian Trail follows roughly the border between Tennessee and North Carolina.

name: tennessee
sentence: Other major tourist attractions include the Aquarium du Tennessee and the Chattanooga Choo-Choo Hotel in Chattanooga; Dollywood in Pigeon Forge; the Aquarium de Ripley des Smokies and Ober Gatlinburg in Gatlinburg; the Parthenon, Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum and the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville; the Jack Daniel Distillery in Lynchburg; the residence and tomb of Elvis Presley in Graceland; the Memphis Zoo; the National Museum of Civil Rights in Memphis; and the Bristol Highway in Bristol.

name: tennessee
sentence: The first variant of the name that became Tennessee was recorded by Captain Juan Pardo, the Spanish explorer, when he and his men passed through an American Indian village called "Tanasqui" in 1567 while traveling inland to South Carolina.

name: tennessee
sentence: At the beginning of the 18th century, British traders met a city of Cherokee called Tanasi (or "Tanase", in the syllable : "") in the present Monroe County, Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: The city was located on a river of the same name (now called the Little Tennessee River) and appears on the maps as early as 1725.

name: tennessee
sentence: It is not known if it was the same city as Juan Pardo's, although recent research suggests that Pardo's "Tanasqui" was located at the confluence of the Pigeon River and the French Broad River near modern Newport.

name: tennessee
sentence: The meaning and origin of this word is uncertain.

name: tennessee
sentence: Some accounts suggest that this is a Cherokee modification of an earlier Yuchi word.

name: tennessee
sentence: It is said to be a "meeting place," a "wind river," or a "big bend river."

name: tennessee
sentence: According to ethnographer James Mooney, the name "can't be analysed" and its meaning is lost.

name: tennessee
sentence: The modern spelling, Tennessee, is attributed to James Glen, the governor of South Carolina, who used this spelling in his official correspondence in the 1750s.

name: tennessee
sentence: The spelling was popularized by Henry Timberlake's "Drawing of the Cherokee Country" publication in 1765.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 1788 North Carolina created Tennessee County, the third county to be established in what is now the Middle Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: (Tennessee County was the predecessor of the present counties of Montgomery and Robertson.)

name: tennessee
sentence: When a constitutional convention met in 1796 to organize a new state outside the South-West territory, it adopted the name of the "Tennessee" state.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee is known as The Volunteer State, a nickname that some claimed to have won during the War of 1812 because of the important role played by Tennessee volunteer soldiers, especially during the Battle of New Orleans.

name: tennessee
sentence: Other sources differ as to the origin of the state nickname; according to The Columbia Encyclopedia, the name refers to volunteers for the war between Mexico and America from 1846 to 1848.

name: tennessee
sentence: This explanation is more likely, as President Polk's call for 2,600 national volunteers at the beginning of the war between Mexico and America resulted in only 30,000 Tennessee volunteers, largely in response to Davy Crockett's death and the appeals of the former Tennessee governor and then Texas politician Sam Houston.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee borders eight other states: Kentucky and Virginia to the north; North Carolina to the east; Georgia, Alabama and Mississippi to the south; Arkansas and Missouri on the Mississippi River to the west.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee is linked to Missouri as a state bordering other states.

name: tennessee
sentence: The State is tried by the Tennessee River.

name: tennessee
sentence: The highest point in the condition is Clingmans Dome at 2643 feet (2,025 m).

name: tennessee
sentence: Clingmans Dome, located on the eastern border of Tennessee, is the highest point on the Appalachian Trail and is the third highest summit in the United States east of Mississippi.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state line between Tennessee and North Carolina crosses the summit.

name: tennessee
sentence: The lowest point in the state is the Mississippi River, at the Mississippi State Line: 54 meters.

name: tennessee
sentence: The geographical center of the state is located in Murfreesboro.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state of Tennessee is geographically, culturally, economically and legally divided into three major divisions: the Eastern Tennessee, the Middle Tennessee and the Western Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Constitution of the State does not allow more than two judges of the five-member Supreme Court of Tennessee to be drawn from a single major division and a similar rule applies to certain commissions and commissions.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee has six main physiographic regions: the Blue Ridge, the Appalachian Ridge and the valley region, the Cumberland Plateau, the Highlands Coast, the Nashville Basin and the Gulf Coast Plain.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee houses the most caves in the United States, with more than ten thousand documents.

name: tennessee
sentence: About half of the state is located in the Tennessee Valley watershed in the Tennessee River.

name: tennessee
sentence: Approximately the northern half of the Middle Tennessee, including Nashville and Clarksville, and a small portion of the Eastern Tennessee are in the Cumberland River basin.

name: tennessee
sentence: A small portion of north central Tennessee, in the counties of Sumner, Macon and Clay, is located in the Green River watershed.

name: tennessee
sentence: These three basins are tributaries of the Ohio River watershed.

name: tennessee
sentence: Most of the West Tennessee lies in the lower Mississippi River watershed.

name: tennessee
sentence: The entire state is located in the Mississippi watershed, with the exception of a small area of Bradley and Polk counties across the Conasauga River, which is part of the Mobile Bay watershed.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Blue Ridge area is located on the eastern edge of Tennessee, which borders North Carolina.

name: tennessee
sentence: This region of Tennessee is characterized by the high mountains and rugged terrain of the Western Blue Ridge Mountains, which are subdivided into several sub-ranges, namely the Smoky Mountains, the Bald Mountains, the Unicoi Mountains, the Unaka and Roan Highlands Mountains, and the Iron Mountains.

name: tennessee
sentence: The average altitude in the Blue Ridge area is 1,500 metres above sea level.

name: tennessee
sentence: Clingmans Dome, the highest point in the state, is located in this area.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Blue Ridge area has never been so sparsely populated, and today much of it is protected by the Cherokee National Forest, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, and several federal wilderness and state parks.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Ridge and Valley area, where many tributaries join to form the Tennessee River in the Tennessee Valley, is about 89 km west of the Blue Ridge.

name: tennessee
sentence: This area of Tennessee is covered with fertile valleys separated by wooded ridges, such as Mount Bays and Mount Clinch.

name: tennessee
sentence: The western part of the Tennessee Valley, where depressions become wider and ridges lower, is called the great valley.

name: tennessee
sentence: In this valley there are many cities and two of the three urban areas of the region, Knoxville, the third largest city in the state, and Chattanooga, the fourth largest city in the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: The third urban area, the three cities, including Bristol, Johnson City and Kingsport and their environs, is northeast of Knoxville.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Cumberland plateau rises west of the Tennessee Valley

name: tennessee
sentence: The altitude of the Cumberland Plateau ranges from 1,500 to approximately 2,000 feet (460 to approximately 610 m) above sea level.

name: tennessee
sentence: The East Tennessee has several important transport links with the Middle and Western Tennessee, as well as the rest of the nation and the world, including several major airports and interstates.

name: tennessee
sentence: The McGhee Tyson Airport (TYS) in Knoxville and Chattanooga Metropolitan Airport (CHA) in Chattanooga, as well as the Tri-Cities Regional Airport (TRI), provide air service to many destinations.

name: tennessee
sentence: I-24, I-81, I-40, I-75 and I-26, as well as many state highways and other important roads, cross the Grande Division and connect Chattanooga, Knoxville and the three cities, as well as other cities such as Cleveland, Athens and Sevierville.

name: tennessee
sentence: To the west of the Cumberland Plateau is the Highland Rim, a raised plain that surrounds the Nashville Basin.

name: tennessee
sentence: The northern area of the Highland Rim, known for its high tobacco production, is sometimes called the Pennyroyal Plateau, located mainly in southwestern Kentucky.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Nashville Basin is characterized by a rich and fertile agricultural country and a wide variety of natural fauna.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Middle Tennessee was a common destination for settlers who crossed the Appalachians since Virginia in the late 18th and early 19th centuries.

name: tennessee
sentence: An important trade route called the Natchez Trace, created and used for many generations by American Indians, connects the middle Tennessee to the city of the lower Mississippi of Natchez.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Natchez Trace route was used as the base of a panoramic highway called Natchez Trace Parkway.

name: tennessee
sentence: Some of the last large American chestnut trees are growing in this region.

sentence: They are used to aid in the reproduction of burn-resistant trees.

name: tennessee
sentence: The average Tennessee is one of the main population and transport centres of the state and the heart of the state government.

sentence: Nashville (the capital), Clarksville and Murfreesboro are its most important cities.

sentence: Interstates 24, 40, 65 and 840 provide service to the Division, with the first three meetings in Nashville.

name: tennessee
sentence: To the west of the Highland Rim and Nashville Basin is the Gulf Coastal Plain, which includes the Mississippi Bay.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Gulf coastal plain is, in terms of area, the main land region of Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: It is part of the great geographic region that begins in the Gulf of Mexico and extends north to southern Illinois.

name: tennessee
sentence: In Tennessee, the Gulf Coast Plain is divided into three sections from the Tennessee River to the east to the Mississippi River to the west.

name: tennessee
sentence: The easternmost stretch, about 16 km wide, consists of hilly lands along the west bank of Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: To the west of this narrow strip of land is a vast area of hills and streams that extends to the Mississippi River.

name: tennessee
sentence: In Memphis, the Tennessee Bottoms ends with steep bluffs overlooking the river.

name: tennessee
sentence: To the west of Tennessee Bottoms lies the Mississippi Alluvial Plain, less than 90 metres above sea level.

name: tennessee
sentence: This area of lowlands, flood plains and marshlands is sometimes called the Delta region.

name: tennessee
sentence: Memphis is the economic centre of West Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: Most of West Tennessee remained Indian land until the Cessation of Chickasaw in 1818, when Chickasaw ceded its lands between Tennessee and Mississippi.

name: tennessee
sentence: The portion of Chickasaw's divestment in Kentucky is now known as the Jackson Purchase.

name: tennessee
sentence: Areas under the control and management of the National Parks Service include the following:

name: tennessee
sentence: Fifty-four state parks with an area of approximately 132,000 acres (530 km2), as well as parts of Grands Monts Smoky National Park and Cherokee National Forest, and Cumberland Gap National Historic Park are located in Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: Sportsmen and visitors are attracted to Reelfoot Lake, originally formed by the earthquakes of 1811–12 New Madrid; the stumps and other remains of a once dense forest, as well as the lotus bed covering the shallow waters, give the lake a strange beauty.

name: tennessee
sentence: Most of the condition has a humid subtropical climate, with the exception of some of the higher elevations in the Appalachians, which are classified as having a temperate climate of mountain or continental humid due to cooler temperatures.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Gulf of Mexico is the dominant factor in Tennessee's climate, with southern winds accounting for most of the annual precipitation of the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: In general, the condition has warm summers and mild to cold winters with generous precipitation throughout the year, with the highest average monthly precipitation generally in winter and spring between December and April.

name: tennessee
sentence: The driest months are on average between August and October.

name: tennessee
sentence: On average, the state receives 50 inches (130 cm) of precipitation per year.

name: tennessee
sentence: Snowfall ranges from 5 inches (13 cm) in the West Tennessee to more than 80 inches (200 cm) in the highest mountains of East Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: Summers in the state are generally warm and humid, with most of the average state of about 90°F (32°C) during the summer months.

name: tennessee
sentence: Winters tend to be mild to fresh, increasing in freshness at higher altitudes.

name: tennessee
sentence: In general, for areas outside the highest mountains, the average night hollows are close to freezing for most states.

name: tennessee
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 113°F (45°C) at Perryville on 9 August 1930, while the lowest recorded temperature was -32°F (−36°C) at Mountain City on 30 December 1917.

name: tennessee
sentence: Although the state is far enough away from the coast to avoid any direct impact of a hurricane, the state location makes it likely to be affected by the remnants of tropical cyclones that weaken on the earth and can cause significant rainfall, such as tropical storm Chris in 1982 and hurricane Opal in 1995.

name: tennessee
sentence: The average state is about fifty days of thunderstorms per year, some of which can be severe with large hail and devastating winds.

name: tennessee
sentence: The tornadoes are possible throughout the state, with the West and the Middle Tennessee the most vulnerable.

name: tennessee
sentence: Sometimes, strong or violent tornadoes occur, such as the devastating tornadoes of April 2011 that killed twenty people in North Georgia and Southeast Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: On average, the state has 15 tornadoes a year.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee tornadoes can be severe, and Tennessee leads the nation in the percentage of total tornadoes that have died.

name: tennessee
sentence: Winter storms are an occasional problem, like the infamous 1993 Blizzard, although ice storms are more likely.

name: tennessee
sentence: Fog is a persistent problem in some parts of the state, particularly in Eastern Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: The capital and largest city is Nashville, although Knoxville, Kingston, and Murfreesboro have all served as state capitals in the past.

name: tennessee
sentence: The metropolitan area of 13 counties of Nashville has been the largest in the state since late 1990.

name: tennessee
sentence: Memphis was the biggest city in the state until 2018 when it was overtaken by Nashville.

name: tennessee
sentence: Chattanooga and Knoxville, both to the east near the Smoky Mountains, are about a third of this size.

sentence: The city of Clarksville is a fifth significant population centre, 72 km northwest of Nashville.

name: tennessee
sentence: Murfreesboro is the sixth largest city in Tennessee, with a population of 146,900.

name: tennessee
sentence: The area now known as Tennessee was first inhabited by Paleo-Indians nearly 12,000 years ago.

name: tennessee
sentence: The names of the cultural groups that inhabited the area between the first colony and the time of European contact were unknown, but several distinct cultural phases were named by archaeologists, including Archaic (8000–1000 B.C.), Woodland (1000 B.C. – 1000 B.C.) and Mississippi (1000–1600 B.C.), whose chiefs of staff were the cultural predecessors of the Muscogee who lived in the Tennessee River valley before the migration of Cherokee into river waters.

name: tennessee
sentence: The first European excursions recorded in what is now known as Tennessee were three expeditions led by Spanish explorers, namely Hernando de Soto in 1540, Tristan de Luna in 1559 and Juan Pardo in 1567.

name: tennessee
sentence: Pardo registered the name "Tanasqui" of a local Indian village, which evolved to the current name of the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: At the time Tennessee was inhabited by tribes of Muscogee and Yuchi.

name: tennessee
sentence: Perhaps because of devastating European diseases the Indian tribes, which would have left a vacuum of population, and also because of the expansion of the European colony in the north, the Cherokee moved south of the area now known as Virginia.

name: tennessee
sentence: As European settlers spread throughout the region, the Indian populations were forcibly displaced to the south and west, including all the Muscogee and Yuchi peoples, the Chickasaw and Choctaw peoples, and finally the Cherokee peoples in 1838.

name: tennessee
sentence: The first British colony in today's Tennessee was built in 1756 by settlers of the colony of South Carolina at Fort Loudoun, near Vonore today.

name: tennessee
sentence: Fort Loudoun became the westmost British outpost on that date.

name: tennessee
sentence: The fort was designed by John William Gerard of Brahm and built by forces under the direction of British Captain Raymond Demeré.

name: tennessee
sentence: After his completion, Captain Raymond Demeré abandoned command on 14 Aug. 1757 to his brother, Captain Paul Demeré.

name: tennessee
sentence: Hostilities broke out between the British and the neighbour Overhill Cherokees, and the siege of Fort Loudoun ended with its surrender on 7 Aug. 1760.

name: tennessee
sentence: The following morning, Captain Paul Demeré and a number of his men were killed in an ambush nearby, and most of the rest of the garrison was taken prisoner.

name: tennessee
sentence: In the 1760s, long hunters from Virginia explored much of the East and Middle Tennessee, and the first permanent European settlers began to arrive at the end of the decade.

name: tennessee
sentence: The majority of 18th-century settlers were English or mainly English, but almost 20% were also Scottish-Irish.

name: tennessee
sentence: These settlers formed the Watauga Association, a community built on land leased to the Cherokee people.

name: tennessee
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War, Fort Watauga at Sycomore Shoals (now Elizabethton) was attacked (1776) by Dragging Canoe and his belligerent faction of Cherokee, who were aligned with British loyalists.

name: tennessee
sentence: These Cherokee renegades were designated by settlers as Chickamauga.

name: tennessee
sentence: They opposed the annexation by North Carolina of the Washington District and the concomitant settlement of the Transylvanian colony further north and west.

name: tennessee
sentence: The lives of many settlers were spared from the first warrior attacks by the warnings of Nancy Ward, cousin of Dragging Canoe.

name: tennessee
sentence: The boundary fort on the banks of the Watauga River later served as a gathering place in 1780 for the men of Overmountain to make a voyage over the Appalachian Mountains, to engage and defeat the British army at the Battle of Kings Mountain in South Carolina.

name: tennessee
sentence: Three counties in the Washington District (now part of Tennessee) left North Carolina in 1784 and formed the state of Franklin.

name: tennessee
sentence: Efforts to gain admission to the Union have failed, and the counties (currently eight) joined North Carolina in 1789.

name: tennessee
sentence: North Carolina ceded the area to the federal government in 1790, after which it was organized in the Southwest Territory.

name: tennessee
sentence: In an effort to encourage settlers to move westward into the new territory, in 1787, the mother state of North Carolina ordered to cut off a road to take settlers to the Cumberland colonies – from the south end of Mount Clinch (in Eastern Tennessee) to French Lick (Nashville).

name: tennessee
sentence: The Trace was called the "North Carolina Road" or "Avery Trace", and sometimes "The Wilderness Road" (although it should not be confused with Daniel Boone's "Wilderness Road" by the Cumberland Gap).

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee was admitted to the Union on 1 June 1796 as the 16th State.

name: tennessee
sentence: It was the first state created from territories under the jurisdiction of the federal government of the United States.

name: tennessee
