sentence: Since the campaign began in 1986, the expression has become "a declaration of identity, a declaration of Texas swagger".

name: texas
sentence: "Texas-size" is an expression that can be used in two ways: to describe something that is about the size of the American state of Texas, or to describe something (usually but not always from Texas) that is great compared to other objects of its type.

name: texas
sentence: Texas was the largest state in the United States, until Alaska became a state in 1959.

name: texas
sentence: The phrase "everything is bigger in Texas" has been used regularly since at least 1950 and has been used since 1913.

name: texas
sentence: Houston is one of five cities in the United States with permanent professional businesses in all major performing arts disciplines: the Houston Grand Opera, the Houston Symphony Orchestra, the Houston Ballet and the Alley Theatre.

name: texas
sentence: Known for its vibrant visual and performing arts, the Houston Theater District, a 17-block neighbourhood in the heart of downtown Houston, ranks second in the country for the number of theatre seats in a concentrated downtown area, with 12,948 seats for live shows and 1,480 cinema seats.

name: texas
sentence: Founded in 1892, the Fort Worth Museum of Modern Art is Texas's oldest art museum.

name: texas
sentence: Fort Worth also has the Kimbell Art Museum, the Amon Carter Museum, the National Cowgirl Museum and the Hall of Fame, the Will Rogers Memorial Center and the downtown Bass Performance Hall.

name: texas
sentence: Dallas' downtown arts district is home to artistic venues such as the Dallas Art Museum, Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Centre, Margot Opera and Bill Winspear, the Trammell & Margaret Crow Asian Art Collection and Nasher Sculpture Center.

name: texas
sentence: The Deep Ellum neighbourhood within Dallas became popular in the 1920s and 1930s as the first jazz and hotspot blues in the southern United States.

name: texas
sentence: The name Deep Ellum comes from the local population that pronounces "Deep Elm" under the name "Deep Ellum".

name: texas
sentence: Artists like Blind Lemon Jefferson, Robert Johnson, Huddie "Lead Belly" Ledbetter, and Bessie Smith played in Deep Ellum clubs.

name: texas
sentence: Austin, The Live Music Capital of the World, has "more live music venues per capita than music centers such as Nashville, Memphis, Los Angeles, Las Vegas or New York City."

name: texas
sentence: The city's music revolves around nightclubs on 6th Street; events such as film, music and South by Southwest multimedia festival; the longest concert program on American television, Austin City Limits; and the Austin City Limits Music Festival at Zilker Park.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1980, San Antonio has become "The Capital of World Tejano Music".

name: texas
sentence: The Tejano Music Awards provided a forum to increase the awareness and appreciation of Tejano music and culture.

name: texas
sentence: The second President of the Republic of Texas, Mirabeau B. Lamar, is the father of education in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: During its term of office, the state reserved three leagues of land in each county to equip public schools.

name: texas
sentence: Later, 50 additional leagues of land set aside for the support of two universities would become the basis of the State Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: Lamar's actions laid the foundations for a system of public schools in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Between 2006 and 2007, Texas spent $7,275 per student, down from the national average of $9,389.

name: texas
sentence: The pupil-teacher ratio was 14.9 below the national average of 15.3.

name: texas
sentence: Texas paid instructors $41,744 less than the national average of $46,593.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Education Agency (TEA) operates the state's public school systems.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has more than 1,000 school districts; all districts, with the exception of the Stafford Municipal School District, are independent of the municipal government and many cross the city's borders.

name: texas
sentence: School districts have the power to tax their residents and to assert a prominent domain over private property.

name: texas
sentence: Due to the fair funding of schools by the courts for school districts, the State has a controversial tax redistribution system called "Robinson Hood Plan".

name: texas
sentence: This system transfers property tax revenues from rich school districts to the poor.

name: texas
sentence: The AME has no authority over the activities of the private school or at home.

name: texas
sentence: Students from Texas take the state of Texas Academic Readiness Assessments (STAR) in primary and secondary school.

name: texas
sentence: STAAR evaluates students' achievements in reading, writing, mathematics, science and social studies required under Texas school standards and the No Child Left Behind Act.

name: texas
sentence: The test replaced the TAKS (Texas Assessment of Knowledge and Skills) test in the 2011-2012 school year.

name: texas
sentence: Generally prohibited in the West in general, corporal punishment in schools is not unusual in more conservative rural areas of the State, with 28,569 students in public schools paddling at least once, according to government data for the 2011-2012 school year.

name: texas
sentence: The rate of corporal punishment at school in Texas is exceeded only by Mississippi, Alabama and Arkansas.

name: texas
sentence: The two most recognized leading universities in the state are the University of Texas in Austin and the University of A&M in Texas, ranked 21st and 41st best universities in the country according to the latest 2020 report of the Centre for World University Rankings.

name: texas
sentence: Some observers also include the University of Houston and the Technical University of Texas as level 1 flagships alongside the UT Austin and the A&M.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Higher Education Coordination Council ranks state public universities in three distinct levels:

name: texas
sentence: Texas Bill 588, a controversial alternative in Texas, guarantees Texas students who have graduated in the 10 percent of their high school class the automatic admission to state-funded universities.

name: texas
sentence: The bill encourages demographic diversity while trying to avoid problems arising from Hopwood v. Texas (1996).

name: texas
sentence: Thirty-six (36) separate public universities exist in Texas, of which 32 belong to one of the six state university systems.

name: texas
sentence: The discovery of minerals on the lands of the Permanent University Fund, particularly oil, contributed to the rapid growth of the two largest academic systems in the state: the University of Texas system and the Texas A and M system.

name: texas
sentence: The other four academic systems: the University of Houston system, the University of Northern Texas system, the State of Texas system, and the Texas technical system are not funded by the University's Permanent Fund.

name: texas
sentence: The Carnegie Foundation ranks four universities in Texas among the Tier 1 research institutions: the University of Texas in Austin, the University of A&M in Texas, the University of Houston and the Technical University of Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas at Austin and A&M University of Texas are the flagship universities of the University of Texas System and Texas A&M University System, respectively.

name: texas
sentence: Both were established under the Texas Constitution and hold interests in the Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: The State has sought to increase the number of flagship universities by raising some of its seven institutions designated as "emerging research universities".

name: texas
sentence: The two that should first emerge are the University of Houston and the Technical University of Texas, probably in this order from the discussions on the floor of the 82nd Texas Legislature.

name: texas
sentence: The State is home to a variety of private institutions of higher education, ranging from liberal arts colleges to a nationally recognized first-level research university.

name: texas
sentence: Rice University in Houston is one of the largest universities of teaching and research in the United States and ranked 17th best university in the country by US News & World Report.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity University, a private university, mainly undergraduate in liberal arts in San Antonio, ranked first among the universities that awarded mainly bachelors and master's degrees in the Western United States for 20 consecutive years by US News.

name: texas
sentence: Private universities include Abilene Christian University, Austin College, Baylor University, Mary Hardin–Baylor University and Southwest University.

name: texas
sentence: Texas universities host three presidential libraries: the George Bush Presidential Library at A&M University of Texas, the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum at the University of Texas at Austin, and the George W. Bush Presidential Library at the South Methodist University.

name: texas
sentence: Despite the concentration of elite medical centers in the state, the Commonwealth Fund ranks Texas's health care system third among the country's worst.

name: texas
sentence: Texas ranks close to the last in terms of access to health care, quality of care, avoidable hospitalization expenses, and equity among the various groups.

name: texas
sentence: The causes of the state's poor rankings include politics, a high poverty rate and the highest illegal immigration rate in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: In May 2006, Texas launched the "red code" program in response to the report, with the state having 25.1 per cent of the population without health insurance, the largest proportion in the country.

name: texas
sentence: The Trust for America's Health ranked Texas 15th in terms of adult obesity, with 27.2% of the state population obese.

name: texas
sentence: The 2008 survey on obesity for men ranked four cities in Texas among the 25 fattest cities in America; Houston ranked 6th, Dallas 7th, El Paso 8th and Arlington 14th.

name: texas
sentence: Texas had only one city (Austin 21st) in the top 25 "most interesting cities" in America.

name: texas
sentence: The same survey positively assessed government obesity initiatives with a "B+".

name: texas
sentence: The state is ranked forty-second in the percentage of residents engaged in regular exercises according to a 2007 study.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has the highest maternal mortality rate in the developed world, and the death rate of Texas women as a result of pregnancy-related complications doubled from 2010 to 2014, reaching 23.8 per 100,000.

name: texas
sentence: An unmatched rate in any other U.S. state or economically developed country.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has many elite research centers.

name: texas
sentence: The State has nine faculties of medicine, three dental schools and two schools of optometry.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has two Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4) laboratories: one at the University of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB) in Galveston, and the other at the Southwest Foundation for Biomedical Research in San Antonio, the first private BSL-4 laboratory in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Medical Center in Houston has the world's largest concentration of research and health care institutions, with 47 member institutions.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Medical Center performs the highest number of heart transplants in the world.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas Cancer Centre M.D. Anderson in Houston is a highly recognized academic institution focused on cancer patient care, research, education and prevention.

name: texas
sentence: San Antonio's South Texas Medical Center facilities rank sixth in the impact of clinical medicine research in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas Centre for Health Sciences is another highly ranked research and educational institution in San Antonio.

name: texas
sentence: The American Heart Association and the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center call Dallas at home.

name: texas
sentence: The institution's medical school employs the largest number of Nobel Prize laureates in the world.

name: texas
sentence: The Texans have historically had difficulties crossing Texas due to the large size and rugged terrain of the state.

name: texas
sentence: Texas compensated for the construction of America's largest road and rail network.

name: texas
sentence: The regulatory authority, the Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT), maintains the state's vast road network, and regulates aviation and public transportation systems.

name: texas
sentence: The State is an important transport centre.

name: texas
sentence: From the Dallas/Fort Worth area, trucks can reach 93 per cent of the country's population within 48 hours, and 37 per cent within 24 hours.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 33 foreign trade zones (FTZs), the country's largest.

name: texas
sentence: In 2004, a combined total of $298 billion in goods transited through the Texas TFAs.

name: texas
sentence: The first highway in Texas was the Gulf highway opened in 1948 in Houston.

name: texas
sentence: In 2005, 79,535 miles (127,999 kilometres) of public road crossed Texas (instead of 71,000 miles (114,263 kilometres) in 1984).

name: texas
sentence: To finance the recent growth of state highways, Texas has 17 toll roads (see list) with several additional toll lanes proposed.

name: texas
sentence: In central Texas, the southern portion of the State Highway 130 toll road has a speed limit of 85 miles per hour (137 km/h), the highest in the country.

name: texas
sentence: All the federal and state highways in Texas are paved.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 730 airports, the second largest in any state of the nation.

name: texas
sentence: Larger in Texas by size and passengers served, the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport (DFW) is the second largest per region in the United States, and the fourth largest in the world with 18,076 acres (73.15 km2).

name: texas
sentence: In traffic, DFW Airport is the busiest in the state, the fourth busiest in the United States, and the sixth busiest in the world.

name: texas
sentence: American Airlines Group, the American / American Eagle, the largest airline in the world in total number of passenger miles transported and the size of the passenger fleet, uses DFW as its largest and largest hub.

name: texas
sentence: It ranks as the largest airline in the United States by the number of passengers transported to the country per year and the largest airline in the world by the number of passengers transported.Southwest Airlines, headquartered in Dallas, operates in Dallas Love Field.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's second largest air installation is the George Bush Intercontinental Airport (IAH) in Houston.

name: texas
sentence: It served as the largest hub for the former Continental Airlines, which was based in Houston; it is the largest hub for United Airlines, the third largest airline in the world, per stolen passenger-miles.

name: texas
sentence: IAH offers services to the most Mexican destinations in any American airport.

name: texas
sentence: The other five largest airports in the state serve over three million passengers each year: Austin-Bergstrom International Airport, William P. Hobby Airport, San Antonio International Airport, Dallas Love Field and El Paso International Airport.

name: texas
sentence: Del Rio International Airport is the smallest in the state to be designated as an international airport.

name: texas
sentence: Approximately 1,150 seaports point the coast of Texas with over 1000 miles (1,600 km) of canals.

name: texas
sentence: Ports employ nearly one million people and manage an average of 317 million metric tons.

name: texas
sentence: Texas ports connect to the rest of the U.S. Atlantic coast with the Gulf section of the Intracoastal Waterway.

name: texas
sentence: The port of Houston is today the busiest port in the United States in foreign tonnage, the second in total tonnage and the tenth in the world in tonnage.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston Canal is 160 metres wide by 22 metres deep and 80 kilometres long.

name: texas
sentence: Part of the state's cowboy tradition is derived from the large cattle roads that its herders organized in the 19th century to drive cattle to the railways and markets of Kansas, for the expedition to the east.

name: texas
sentence: Cities along the way, such as Baxter Springs, Kansas' first cow town, have developed to take care of seasonal workers and tens of thousands of cattle.

name: texas
sentence: The first railway operated in Texas was the Buffalo Bayou, Brazos and Colorado Railway, which opened in August 1853.

name: texas
sentence: The first railway to enter Texas from the north, completed in 1872, was the Missouri–Kansas–Texas railway.

name: texas
sentence: With increased access to the railway, farmers did not have to carry their cattle to the Midwest and shipped beef from Texas.

name: texas
sentence: This has led to a decline in the economy of cow towns.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1911, Texas has led the nation along miles of railway within the state.

name: texas
sentence: The length of the Texas Railway peaked in 1932 at 17,078 miles (27,484 kilometres), but decreased to 14,006 miles (35,540 kilometres) in 2000.

name: texas
sentence: While the Texas Railway Commission initially regulated the state railways, in 2005 the State reassigned these functions to TxDOT.

name: texas
sentence: In the Dallas–Fort Worth area, three public transit agencies provide rail service: Dallas Area Rapid Transit (DART), Denton County Transportation Authority (DCTA) and Trinity Metro.

name: texas
sentence: DART began operating the first light rail system in the southwest of the United States in 1996.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity Railway Express (TRE) suburban rail service between Fort Worth and Dallas is provided by Trinity Metro and DART.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity Metro also operates the TEXRail railway line, linking downtown Fort Worth and Northeast Tarrant County to DFW Airport.

name: texas
sentence: The commuter A train line, operated by DCTA, serves as an extension of the DART Green line to Denton County.

name: texas
sentence: In the Austin area, the Capital Metropolitan Transportation Authority operates a suburban rail service called Capital MetroRail to the northwest suburb.

name: texas
sentence: The Metropolitan Transit Authority of Harris County, Texas (METRO) operates light rail lines in the Houston area.

name: texas
sentence: Amtrak provides Texas with a limited toll rail service.

name: texas
sentence: Three regular routes serve the state: the Texas Eagle daily (Chicago–San Antonio), the triweekly Sunset Limited (New Orleans–Los Angeles), with stops in Texas, and the Heartland Flyer daily (Fort Worth–Oklahoma City).

name: texas
sentence: Texas may have one of the first high-speed lines in the country.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Central Railway Company is planning to build a privately financed high-speed railway line between Dallas and Houston.

name: texas
sentence: The present Constitution of Texas was adopted in 1876.

name: texas
sentence: Like many States, it explicitly provides for the separation of powers.

name: texas
sentence: The State Bill of Rights is much more important than its federal bill of rights and contains Texas-specific provisions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a plural executive branch system limiting the power of the governor, which is a weak executive compared to other states.

name: texas
sentence: With the exception of the Secretary of State, electors elect the leaders independently, so candidates are directly accountable to the public and not to the Governor.

name: texas
sentence: This electoral system led to the division of certain executive powers between the parties and reduced the governor's ability to implement a program.

name: texas
sentence: When Republican President George W. Bush was Governor of Texas, the state had a democratic lieutenant governor, Bob Bullock.

name: texas
sentence: The Executive is composed of the Governor, the Lieutenant Governor, the Comptroller of Public Accounts, the Land Commissioner, the Attorney General, the Commissioner of Agriculture, the Texas Railway Commission, the State Council of Education and the Secretary of State.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas bicameral legislature consists of the House of Representatives, with 150 members, and one senator, with 31 members.

name: texas
sentence: The Speaker of the House directs the House and the Lieutenant Governor, the Senator.

name: texas
sentence: The legislature meets in ordinary session every two years for just over a hundred days, but the governor may request special sessions as often as desired (notably, the legislature cannot come into session).

name: texas
sentence: The State's fiscal year begins on 1 September.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's judiciary is one of the most complex in the United States, with many layers and overlapping jurisdictions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has two courts of last resort: the Texas Supreme Court, for civil matters, and the Texas Criminal Court of Appeal.

name: texas
sentence: With the exception of some municipal judges, partisan elections select judges at all levels of the judiciary; the Governor fills vacancies by appointment.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is remarkable for its use of capital punishment, having led the country to executions since the death penalty was reinstated in Gregg v. Georgia (see Capital punishment in Texas).

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Ranger Division of the Texas Department of Public Safety is a law enforcement agency within the jurisdiction of the State.

name: texas
sentence: Over the years, the Texas Rangers have investigated crimes ranging from murder to political corruption.

name: texas
sentence: They acted as riot police and inspectors, protected the governor of Texas, chased fugitives and acted as a paramilitary force for both the republic and the state.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Rangers were created informally by Stephen F. Austin in 1823 and formally formed in 1835.

name: texas
sentence: The Rangers are an integral part of several important events in Texas history and some of the most well-known criminal cases in Old West history.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Constitution defines the responsibilities of county governments, which serve as agents of the state.

name: texas
sentence: The so-called Commissioners Courts and Judges Courts are elected as the administrative body.

name: texas
sentence: Most State cities, with more than 5,000 inhabitants, have local governments.

name: texas
sentence: The vast majority of them have charters for the forms of council-managerial government, by which voters elect members of the council, who hire a director of a professional city as an operating officer.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1870s, the White Democrats regained power in the state legislature of the biracial coalition at the end of Reconstruction.

name: texas
sentence: At the beginning of the twentieth century, Parliament passed bills to impose voting taxes, followed by white primaries; these measures effectively deprived most blacks, poor whites and Mexican Americans.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1890s, 100,000 blacks voted in the state; in 1906, only 5,000 could vote.

name: texas
sentence: As a result, the Democratic Party has dominated Texas's politics since the beginning of the century, imposing racial segregation and white supremacy.

name: texas
sentence: It held power until the adoption, in the mid-1960s, of national legislation on civil rights that upholds the constitutional rights of all citizens.

name: texas
sentence: Although Texas was essentially a single-party state during this period and democratic primary was considered "the real election," the Democratic Party had conservative and liberal factions, which became more pronounced after the New Deal.

name: texas
sentence: In addition, several factions of the party separated briefly in the 1930s and 1940s.

name: texas
sentence: The conservative white voters of the state began supporting the candidates for the Republican presidency in the middle of the 20th century.

name: texas
sentence: After that period, they supported the Republicans for local and state offices as well, and most whites became members of the Republican Party.

name: texas
sentence: The party also attracted some minorities, but many continued to vote for the Democratic candidates.

name: texas
sentence: The passage to the Republican Party is largely attributed to the fact that the Democratic Party became increasingly liberal during the 20th century, and therefore increasingly uncontrollable with the average voter in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Since Texas has always been a conservative state, voters have turned to the GOP, which now more closely reflects their beliefs.

name: texas
sentence: Commentators also attributed the change to Republican political consultant Karl Rove, who managed numerous political campaigns in Texas in the 1980s and 1990s.

name: texas
sentence: Other reasons cited include the court-ordered redistribution and demographic changes in relation to the Sun Belt that favoured the Republican Party and conservatism.

name: texas
sentence: The redistribution of Congressional districts led by Republican Tom DeLay in 2003 in Texas was called by the New York Times "an extreme case of partisan Gerrymandering".

name: texas
sentence: A group of democratic legislators, the "Texas Eleven", fled the state in an effort to abuse quorum to prevent Parliament from acting, but failed.

name: texas
sentence: The State had already been reshuffled following the 2000 census.

name: texas
sentence: Despite these efforts, the legislature adopted a map strongly in favour of Republicans, based on 2000 data and ignoring the estimates of nearly a million new residents in the state since then.

name: texas
sentence: Career lawyers and analysts in the Department of Justice objected to this plan by diluting the votes of African-American and Hispanic voters, but the political appointees stole and approved it.

name: texas
sentence: In League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry (2006), the National Supreme Court ruled in favour of the state (and Republicans).

name: texas
sentence: In the 2014 Texas election, the Tea Party movement made great strides, with many of the Tea Party's favourites elected to power, including Dan Patrick as Lieutenant Governor, Ken Paxton as Attorney General, as well as many other candidates, including Conservative Republican Greg Abbott as Governor.

name: texas
sentence: The voters of Texas are leaning towards fiscal conservatism, while taking advantage of the enormous federal investment in the state in military and other facilities obtained by the power of the South Solid in the 20th century.

name: texas
sentence: They also have a tendency to have socially conservative values.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1980, most voters in Texas have supported Republican presidential candidates.

name: texas
sentence: In 2000 and 2004, Republican George W. Bush won Texas with 59.3 per cent and 60.1 per cent respectively, partly because of his status as "preferential son" as former state governor.

name: texas
sentence: John McCain won the state in 2008, but with a smaller margin of victory over Bush at 55 percent of the vote.

name: texas
sentence: Austin, Dallas, Houston and San Antonio are constantly focusing on democrats in local and state elections.

name: texas
sentence: The demographic evolution of the state can lead to a change in its overall political alignment, as a majority population of Black and Hispanic/Latino voters supports the Democratic Party.

name: texas
sentence: Residents of counties along the Rio Grande, closer to the border between Mexico and the United States, where there are many Latin American residents, usually vote for Democratic Party candidates, while most other rural and suburban areas of Texas voted for Republican Party candidates.

name: texas
sentence: As of the 2014 general election, a large majority of the members of the delegation of the U.S. House of Texas are Republican, as well as the two U.S.

name: texas
sentence: The senators.

name: texas
sentence: At the 114th Congress of the United States, of the 36 congressional districts in Texas, 24 were organized by Republicans and 11 by Democrats.

name: texas
sentence: One seat is empty.

name: texas
sentence: The senators from Texas are John Cornyn and Ted Cruz.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1994, the Texans have not elected a democrat to a state-wide post.

name: texas
sentence: The state's democratic voters are mainly Liberal and minority groups from Austin, Beaumont, Dallas, El Paso, Houston and San Antonio, as well as minority voters from Eastern and Southern Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Texas banned sanctuary cities, but the mayor of Houston Sylvester Turner swore that the city would not help ICE agents.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a reputation for harsh criminal punishment for criminal offences.

name: texas
sentence: It is one of the 32 states that use capital punishment, and since the Supreme Court of the United States authorized the resumption of capital punishment in 1976, 40 per cent of all United States executions took place in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: In 2008, Texas had the fourth highest rate of incarceration in the United States.It also has strong self-defence laws, allowing citizens to use lethal force to defend themselves, their families or their property.

name: texas
sentence: While American football has long been regarded as "king" in the state, Texans enjoy a wide variety of sports.

name: texas
sentence: Texans may applaud a plethora of professional sports teams.

name: texas
sentence: Within the Big Four professional leagues, Texas has two NFL teams (the Dallas Cowboys and the Houston Texans), two major League baseball teams (the Houston Astros and the Texas Rangers), three NBA teams (the San Antonio Spurs, the Houston Rockets and the Dallas Mavericks) and one National Hockey League team (the Dallas Stars).

name: texas
sentence: The Dallas–Fort Worth Metroplex is one of the twelve metropolitan areas in the United States that host sports teams from all professional leagues of the Big Four.

name: texas
sentence: Apart from the Big Four, Texas also has a WNBA team (the Dallas Wings) and two Major Football League teams (the Houston Dynamo and FC Dallas).

name: texas
sentence: Collegial athletics is of great importance in Texas culture, especially football.

name: texas
sentence: The State has 12 schools in the I-FBS Division, the largest in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: Four state universities, the Baylor Bears, Texas Longhorns, TCU Horned Frogs and Texas Tech Red Raiders, participate in the Great 12 Conference.

name: texas
sentence: Texas A&M Aggies left the Big 12 and joined the South-East Conference in 2012, which led the Big 12 to invite the TCU to join; TCU was previously at the Mountain West Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston Cougars and the Mustangs of the SMU participate in the American athletic conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Bobcats of the State of Texas and the UT's Arlington Mavericks participate in the Sun Belt conference.

name: texas
sentence: Four of the state's schools claim at least one national football championship: Texas Longhorns, Texas A&M Agies, TCU Horned Frogs, and SMU Mustangs.

name: texas
sentence: According to an I-A Division investigation, rivalry between the University of Oklahoma and the University of Texas at Austin, the Red River Shootout, ranks third in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: The TCU horn frogs and the SMU Mustangs also share a rivalry and compete each year in the battle for the Iron Skullet.

name: texas
sentence: A fierce competition, the Lone Star Showdown, also exists between the two largest universities in the state, Texas A&M University and the University of Texas in Austin.

name: texas
sentence: The athletic side of the Lone Star Showdown rivalry was suspended after the Texas Aggies joined the Southeast Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The University Interscholastic League (UIL) organises most of the competitions in primary and secondary schools.

name: texas
sentence: The events organized by UIL include athletics competitions (the most popular being secondary football) as well as artistic and academic subjects.

name: texas
sentence: Texans also enjoy the rodeo.

name: texas
sentence: The world's first rodeo was hosted in Pecos, Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The annual Animal Houston and Rodeo is the largest rodeo in the world.

name: texas
sentence: It begins with hiking from several points of the state that meet in Reliant Park.

name: texas
sentence: The Southwest Exhibition and Livestock Fair in Fort Worth is the oldest rodeo in the history of the state that incorporates many of the most historic traditions into its annual events.

name: texas
sentence: Dallas hosts the Texas State Fair each year in Fair Park.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1997, the Texas Motor Speedway has hosted annual races from the NASCAR Cup Series and the IndyCar Series.

name: texas
sentence: Since 2012, Austin's Circuit of the Americas has hosted a round of the Formula 1 World Championship – the first on a permanent road circuit in the United States since the 1980 Grand Prix at Watkins Glen International – as well as Grand Prix motorcycle races, FIA World Endurance Championship and United SportsCar Championship.

name: utah
sentence: Utah (YOO-tah, (listening) YOO-taw) is a state in the United States.

name: utah
sentence: It is bordered by Colorado to the east, Wyoming to the northeast, Idaho to the north, Arizona to the south, and Nevada to the west.

name: utah
sentence: It also touches a corner of New Mexico in the south-east.

name: utah
sentence: Of the fifty American states, Utah is the 13th by zone; with a population of more than three million, it is the 30th most populated and the 11th least dense.

name: utah
sentence: Urban development is concentrated mainly in two areas: the Wasatch Front in the north-central part of the state, which is home to about two thirds of the population and includes the capital, Salt Lake City; and Washington County in the south, with more than 170,000 inhabitants.

name: utah
sentence: Most of western Utah is in the Great Basin.

name: utah

sentence: Utah is known for its natural diversity and has features ranging from arid deserts with sand dunes to flowering pine forests in mountain valleys.

sentence: Like most western and southwestern states, the federal government owns much of the land in Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Utah has a dry, semi-arid climate in the desert, although its many mountains have a wide variety of climates, the highest points in the Uinta mountains being above the wood line.

name: utah
sentence: Dry weather is the result of the state's location in the rain shadow of Sierra Nevada in California.

name: utah
sentence: Half of the east state is in the rain shadow of the Wasatch Mountains.

name: utah
sentence: The main source of precipitation for the state is the Pacific Ocean, with the state usually on the major Pacific storm trail from October to May.

name: utah
sentence: In summer, the state, particularly the south and east of Utah, is on the monsoon moisture trail from the Gulf of California.

name: utah
sentence: Most plain areas receive less than 12 inches (305 mm) of precipitation per year, although corridor I-15, including the densely populated Wasatch Front, receives approximately 15 inches (381 mm).

name: utah
sentence: The Great Salt Lake Desert is the driest region in the state, with less than 5 inches (127 mm).

name: utah
sentence: Snowfall is common in all valleys, except in remote southern valleys.

sentence: Although St. George receives only about 3 inches (76 mm) per year, Salt Lake City sees about 60 inches (1,524 mm), increased by effect snow Lake of Great Salt Lake, which increases total snowfall to the south, south-east and east of the lake.

sentence: Some areas of the Wasatch chain on the lake effect trail receive up to 500 inches (12,700 mm) per year.

name: utah
sentence: This micro-climate of increased snowfall from Great Salt Lake extends throughout the vicinity of the lake.

name: utah
sentence: The cotton canyons adjacent to Salt Lake City are located in the right position to receive more precipitation from the lake.

name: utah
sentence: The ever-deep snowfowl led the Utah ski industry to adopt the slogan "the greatest snow on earth" in the 1980s.

name: utah
sentence: In winter, temperature inversions are a common phenomenon in Utah basins and valleys, resulting in thick fog and fog that can last for weeks at a time, particularly in the Uintah basin.

name: utah
sentence: Although at other times of the year its air quality is good, winter reversals give Salt Lake City one of the worst winter pollution in the country.

name: utah
sentence: Previous studies have shown a widespread decline in snow quantity above Utah, accompanied by a decline in the snow-precipitation ratio, while anecdotal claims have been made that the measured changes in the amount of snow in Utah are misleading and do not reflect actual changes.

name: utah
sentence: A 2012 study found that the proportion of winter precipitation (January to March) falling as snow has decreased by nine per cent over the last half century, a combined result of a significant increase in precipitation and a slight decrease in snowfall.

name: utah
sentence: Meanwhile, the depth of snow observed in Utah decreased and was accompanied by a steady decrease in snow cover and surface albedo.

name: utah
sentence: Weather systems likely to produce precipitation in Utah have decreased in number, with those producing snowfall decreasing at a much higher rate.

name: utah
sentence: Utah's temperatures are extreme, with cold temperatures in winter due to its altitude, and very hot summers on a state scale (except for mountain areas and high mountain valleys).

name: utah
sentence: Utah is usually protected from major cold air explosions by mountains in the north and east of the state, although major Arctic explosions may sometimes reach the state.

name: utah
sentence: January average high temperatures range from about 30°F (−1°C) in some northern valleys to about 55°F (13°C) in St. George.

name: utah
sentence: Temperatures below 0°F (−18°C) should be expected occasionally in most regions of the state in most years, although some regions often see it (for example, the city of Randolph has an average of about fifty days a year with such low temperatures).

name: utah
sentence: In July, average peaks ranged from about 85 to 100°F (29 to 38°C).

name: utah
sentence: However, low humidity and high altitude usually result in large temperature variations, resulting in cool nights on most summer days.

name: utah
sentence: The record temperature in Utah was 118°F (48°C), recorded south of St. George on 4 July 2007, and the low record was -69°F (−56°C), recorded at Peter Sinks in the Northern Bear Mountains of Utah on 1 February 1985.

name: utah
sentence: However, the record level for a inhabited area was −49°F (−45°C) at Woodruff on 12 December 1932.

name: utah
sentence: Utah, like most western United States, has a few days of thunderstorms.

name: utah
sentence: On average, there are less than 40 days of stormy activity in the year, although these storms may be briefly intense when they occur.

name: utah
sentence: They are more likely to occur during the monsoon season, from mid-July to mid-September, especially in southern and eastern Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Dry lightning strikes and generally dry weather often triggers forest fires in the summer, while intense thunderstorms can cause flash floods, especially in the rugged southern Utah terrain.

name: utah
sentence: Although spring is the wettest season in northern Utah, late summer is the wettest time for much of the south and east of the state.

name: utah
sentence: The tornadoes are rare in Utah, with an average of two striking the state each year, rarely more EF1 intensity.

name: utah
sentence: An exception to note, however, was the unprecedented F2 Salt Lake City Tornado that moved directly to downtown Salt Lake City on August 11, 1999, killing one person, wounding another sixty, and causing approximately $170 million in damage.

name: utah
sentence: The only other deadly tornado reported in Utah's history was a 7-year-old girl who was killed while camping in Summit County on July 6, 1884.

name: utah
sentence: The last tornado of intensity above (E)F0 occurred on September 8, 2002, when an F2 tornado hit Manti.

name: utah
sentence: On 11 August 1993, an F3 tornado struck the Uinta Mountains north of Duchesne at an altitude of 10,500 feet (3,200 m), causing damage to a Scout camp.

name: utah
sentence: This is the strongest tornado ever recorded in Utah.

sentence: Utah hosts more than 600 vertebrate animals, as well as numerous invertebrates and insects.

sentence: Virginia is divided into 95 counties and 38 independent cities, the latter acting in many respects as county equivalents.

sentence: Washington State is one of seven states that do not collect personal income tax.

sentence: Washington companies are responsible for various other government levies, including business tax and business (B & O), a gross revenue tax that imposes variable rates on different types of businesses.

sentence: The Washington State sales tax is 6.5%, which is combined with a local sales tax that varies by location.

sentence: The excise tax applies to certain goods such as gasoline, cigarettes and alcoholic beverages.

name: washington
sentence: Property tax was the first tax levied in the state of Washington, and its collection accounts for about 30 per cent of the total income of Washington's state and local governments.

name: washington
sentence: It continues to be the primary source of income for public schools, fire protection, libraries, parks and recreation, and other special-purpose districts.

name: washington
sentence: All real and personal property is subject to tax unless specifically exempted by law.

sentence: Personal property tax applies to personal property used in the conduct of a business or to other personal property that is not exempt by law.

name: washington
sentence: All property taxes are paid to the treasurer's office in the county in which the property is located.

name: washington
sentence: Washington does not tax intangible assets such as bank accounts, shares or bonds.

sentence: The State also does not charge tax on retirement income earned and received from another State.

sentence: Washington doesn't collect taxes on inheritance.

sentence: However, estate tax is decoupled from federal estate tax laws and, as a result, the state imposes its own estate tax.

sentence: West Virginia is a state in the Appalachian and Middle Atlantic regions of the southern United States.

name: west_virginia

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia became a state following the Wheeling Conventions of 1861, at the beginning of the American Civil War.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Delegates from the unionist counties in northwestern Virginia decided to move away from Virginia, which also included secessionist counties in the new state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia was admitted to the Union on 20 June 1863 and was a key frontier state during the war.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It was the only state to form by separating itself from a Confederate state, the first to separate from any state from Maine separated from Massachusetts, and was one of the two states (with Nevada) admitted to the Union during the American civil war.

sentence: While some of its inhabitants were slaves, most were Yemeni farmers, and delegates provided for the progressive abolition of slavery in the new state constitution and the state parliament adopted the 13th amendment that abolished slavery on 3 February 1865.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The tribes that inhabited Western Virginia from 1600 onwards were the Siouan Monongahela culture to the north, the Fort Antique culture along the Ohio River from Monongahela to Kentucky, and the extension of an unknown inland distance, and the Siouan Tutelo and Moneton tribes to the east.

name: west_virginia
sentence: There was also the Iroquoian Susquehannock in the area approximately east of the Monongahela River and north of the Monongahela National Forest, a possible tribe called the Sendrondoa, or Shenandoah, in the Shenandoah Valley and the easternmost point of the state may have been home to the Manahoac people.

sentence: The Monongahelas were perhaps the same as a people known as Calicua, or Cali.

sentence: Perhaps the following was the same tribe: Moneton, Moheton, Senatorndoa, Tomahitan.

sentence: During the Beaver Wars, other tribes settled in the area.

sentence: There were the Iroquoians Tiontatecaga (also Little Mingo, Guyandotte), who seem to have separated from the Petun after they were beaten by the Iroquois.

sentence: They eventually moved somewhere between the Kanawha and Little Kanawha rivers.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Susquehannocks were the first participants in the Beaver Wars, but they were cut off from the Ohio River by the Iroquois around 1630 and found themselves in terrible straits.

name: west_virginia
sentence: From illness to constant war and inability to provide for their financial needs, they began to collapse and moved increasingly eastward to the Susquehanna River in eastern Pennsylvania.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Manahoacs were probably hunted in the 1680s, when the Iroquois began to invade Virginia.

sentence: Even before they left, the displaced indigenous people from the south flooded into freshly conquered areas and took care of them.

sentence: They appropriated themselves and merged with the Monetons, who began to designate themselves as the Mohetons.

sentence: The Calicua also began to designate themselves as Cherokees shortly afterwards, showing an apparent additional fusion.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia's climate is generally a humid subtropical climate (classification of the climate of Köppen Cfa, except Dfb at higher altitudes) with warm to warm, humid and cold winters, increasing in severity with altitude.

sentence: Some regions of the southern highlands also have a temperate mountain climate (Köppen Cfb) where winter temperatures are more moderate and summer temperatures slightly cooler.

sentence: The prickly pear of the East grows well in many parts of the state.

sentence: Average January temperatures range from about 26°F (−4°C) near the Cheat River to 41°F (5°C) along the Kentucky border sections.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The highest temperature recorded in the state was 112 °F (44 °C) at Martinsburg on 10 July 1936 and the lowest recorded in the state was −37 °F (−38 °C) at Lewisburg on 30 December 1917.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Annual precipitation ranges from less than 32 inches (810 mm) in the lower east to more than 56 inches (1,400 mm) in the upper parts of the Allegheny front.

sentence: Just over half of the precipitation occurs between April and September.

sentence: Dense fogs are common in many valleys of the Kanawha section, especially in the Tygart Valley.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is also one of the most cloudy states in the nation, with the cities of Elkins and Beckley ranking 9th and 10th respectively in the United States for the number of cloudy days per year (more than 210).

name: west_virginia
sentence: In addition to the persistent cloudy sky caused by the degradation of humidity by the Alleghenies, West Virginia also experiences some of the most frequent precipitation in the nation, with an average of snowshoes of nearly 200 days a year with rain or snow.

sentence: Snow usually lasts only a few days in the lower sections, but may persist for weeks in the upper mountainous areas.

sentence: Average snowfall in Highlands Allegheny can reach up to 180 inches (4,600 mm) per year.

sentence: Violent weather is somewhat less prevalent in Western Virginia than in most other eastern states, and is one of the least tornado-prone states east of the Rocky Mountains.

sentence: Tourism contributed $4.27 billion to the government economy and employed 44,400 people in 2010, making it one of the largest government industries.

sentence: Many tourists, especially in the eastern mountains, are attracted by the region's remarkable outdoor recreation opportunities.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Canaan Valley is popular for winter sports, Senatorca Rocks is one of the first climbing destinations in the eastern United States, the New River Gorge/Fayetteville area attracts mountaineers as well as water rafters, and the Monongahela National Forest is popular with hikers, backpackers, hunters and fishermen.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In addition to these outdoor recreational activities, the state offers a number of historical and cultural attractions.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Harpers Ferry National Historic Park is a historic town located at the confluence of the Shenandoah and Potomac rivers.

sentence: Harpers Ferry was the site of John Brown's 1859 raid on the Armory and the Arsenal of the United States.

sentence: Located about midpoint of the Appalachian Trail, Harpers Ferry is the base of the Appalachian Trail.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Greenbrier Hotel, originally built in 1778, has long been considered a leading hotel, frequented by many world leaders and American presidents over the years.

sentence: West Virginia is the site of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, which includes the Green Bank telescope.

sentence: The main building of the Weston State Hospital is the largest hand-cut sandstone building in the Western Hemisphere, the second largest in the world only in the Kremlin in Moscow.

sentence: One of the main resources in the West Virginia economy is coal.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia personal income tax is based on federal adjusted gross income (and not taxable income), as amended by specific elements of West Virginia law.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Citizens are taxed within five income brackets, which range from 3.0% to 6.5%.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The government's consumer sales tax is charged at 6% on most products, with the exception of unprepared foods.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia counties administer and collect property tax, although property tax rates reflect levies from state governments, counties, education county councils, and municipalities.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Counties may also charge a hotel occupancy tax on accommodation not situated within the boundaries of the city of a municipality that collects such a tax.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Municipalities may levy licence fees and taxes on gross revenues on businesses within the boundaries of the city and a hotel occupancy tax on accommodation spaces in the city.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Although the Department of Tax and Revenue plays an important role in the administration of this tax, less than half of the property tax collected is paid to the government.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The main beneficiaries of property tax are the county school boards.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Property taxes are paid to the sheriff of each of the 55 counties in the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Each county and municipality may impose its own property tax rates within the limits set by the West Virginia Constitution.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The West Virginia Parliament sets the tax rate for the Education County Councils.

name: west_virginia
sentence: This rate is used by all Education County Councils throughout the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: However, the total tax rate for county councils may differ from county to county due to excess levies.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Department of Taxation and Income oversees and otherwise assists counties and municipalities in their assessment and tax rate determination work.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The total tax rate is a combination of the taxes levied by four state tax authorities: the state, the county, schools and municipalities.

name: west_virginia
sentence: This total tax rate varies for each of the four classes of property, consisting of personal, real and intangible property.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Assets are valued based on their use, location and value as of July 1.

name: west_virginia
sentence: WV Assessments has a free database on West Virginia property tax valuations covering current and past years.

name: west_virginia
sentence: All properties are revalued every three years

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia does not impose inheritance taxes.

name: west_virginia
sentence: As a result of the phasing out of the federal estate tax credit, West Virginia estate tax is not imposed on estates of deceased persons on or after January 1, 2005.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Parliament of West Virginia is bicameral.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It consists of the Chamber of Deputies and the Senator, both housed in the Capitol of the State of West Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It is a citizen legislature, which means that the legislative office is not a full-time occupation, but rather a part-time position.

name: west_virginia
sentence: As a result, legislators often have full-time employment in their community of residence.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Generally, the legislature was in session for 60 days between January and early April.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The last day of the ordinary session ended with a confusing fury of last-minute legislation to respect a constitutional deadline of midnight.

name: west_virginia
sentence: For the remainder of the year, monthly interim sessions are held in preparation for the regular session.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Legislators also meet periodically for "special" sessions when they are called by the Governor.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The title of Lieutenant Governor is given by law to the Speaker of the Senate.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The governor, who was elected every four years on the same day as the United States presidential election, was sworn in the following January.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The governors of West Virginia may serve two consecutive terms, but they must serve a term of office before serving a third term.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The title of Lieutenant Governor is given by law to the Speaker of the Senate.

sentence: West Virginia is one of the 19 states that do not have a death penalty, and it is the only state in the southeastern United States that has abolished it.

sentence: Wisconsin is located on two Great Lakes and has many inland lakes of varying size; the state contains 11,188 square miles (28,980 km2) of water, more than all but three other states, Alaska, Michigan and Florida.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Outdoor activities are popular in Wisconsin, particularly hunting and fishing.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is represented by major league teams in three sports: football, baseball and basketball.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Lambeau Field, located in Green Bay, Wisconsin, houses the Green Bay Packers of the National Football League.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Packers have been part of the NFL since the second season of the league in 1921 and hold the record for the most NFL titles, winning the town of Green Bay the nickname "Titletown USA".

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Packers are the smallest franchise of the NFL and the only one held by shareholders at the state level.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The franchise was founded by "Courly" Lambeau who played and coached for them.

name: wisconsin

name: wisconsin
sentence: State support for the team is attested by the 81,000-person waiting list for the season tickets at Lambeau Field.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state's only major baseball team, the Milwaukee Brewers, have played at Miller Park in Milwaukee, the successor to Milwaukee County Stadium since 2001.

sentence: In 1982, the Brewers won the American League championship, marking their most successful season.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The team moved from the American League to the National League from the 1998 season.

name: wisconsin

name: wisconsin

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association are playing at home at the Fiserv Forum.

sentence: The state also has minor league teams in hockey (Milwaukee Admirals) and baseball (the Wisconsin Timber Rattlers, based in Appleton and the Beloit Snappers of the Class A minor leagues).

sentence: The Badger men's basketball team won the national title in 1941 and made trips to the four collegial basketball finals in 2000, 2014 and 2015.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming (German: Wyoming) is a landlocked state in the western United States of America.

name: wyoming
sentence: The 10th largest state by region is also the least populated and densely populated state of the contiguous United States.

name: wyoming
sentence: It is bordered by Montana to the north and northwest, South Dakota and Nebraska to the east, Idaho to the west, Utah to the southwest, and Colorado to the south.

name: wyoming
sentence: The population of the State was estimated at 578,759 in 2019.

name: wyoming
sentence: The capital of the State and the most populated city is Cheyenne, whose population was estimated at 63,957 in 2018.

name: wyoming
sentence: The western half of Wyoming is primarily covered by the range and range of the Rocky Mountains, while the eastern half of the state is a high-altitude prairie called the High Plains.

name: wyoming
sentence: Almost half of Wyoming's land is owned by the U.S. government, leading Wyoming to rank sixth by region and fifth by proportion of federal state land.

name: wyoming
sentence: Federal lands include two national parks — Grand Teton and Yellowstone — two national recreational areas, two national monuments, several national forests, historic sites, fish hatcheries and wildlife refuges.

name: wyoming
sentence: The first inhabitants of the region are Arapaho, Crow, Lakota and Shoshone.

name: wyoming
sentence: The south-west of Wyoming was claimed by the Spanish Empire and then as Mexican territory until it was ceded to the United States in 1848 at the end of the war between Mexico and America.

name: wyoming
sentence: The region acquired the name "Wyoming" when a bill was introduced in Congress in 1865 to provide a temporary government for the territory of Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: The name had been used earlier for the Wyoming Valley in Pennsylvania, and is derived from the word Munsee xwé:wam=nk, meaning "at the great river dish".

name: wyoming
sentence: The main drivers of Wyoming's economy are tourism and mining of minerals such as coal, oil, natural gas and trone.

name: wyoming
sentence: Agricultural products include livestock, hay, sugar beets, cereals (wheat and barley) and wool.

name: wyoming
sentence: The climate is semi-arid and continental, drier and windier than the rest of the country with higher extreme temperatures.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming has been a politically conservative state since the 1950s, the Republican candidate holding the state in all presidential elections since 1968.

name: wyoming
sentence: One of the most important is Teton County, which has obtained the notability of being Wyoming's most democratic county and which has not voted for a Republican since 2000.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's climate is generally semi-arid and continental (Köppen BSk climate classification), and is drier and more windy compared to most United States with higher extreme temperatures.

name: wyoming
sentence: Much of this is due to topography of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: Summers at Wyoming are warm with high July temperatures averaged between 85 and 95°F (29 and 35°C) in most of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: However, with increasing elevation, this average declines rapidly with locations above 9,000 feet (2,700 m) on average around 70°F (21°C).

name: wyoming
sentence: Summer nights throughout the state are characterized by rapid cooling with even the warmest places on average in the range of 50 to 60°F (10 to 16°C) at night.

name: wyoming
sentence: In most of the condition, most precipitation tends to fall in late spring and early summer.

name: wyoming
sentence: Winters are cold, but are variable with periods sometimes extremely cold interspersed between generally mild periods, with Chinook winds providing abnormally hot temperatures in some places.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is a dry state where most lands receive less than 10 inches (250 mm) of rain per year.

name: wyoming
sentence: Precipitation depends on altitude with lower areas in the Big Horn Basin on average from 5 to 8 inches (130 to 200 mm) (making it a real desert).

name: wyoming
sentence: Lower areas in the North and in the Eastern Plains tend to average about 10 to 12 inches (250 to 300 mm), resulting in a semi-arid climate.

name: wyoming
sentence: Some mountain areas receive a good amount of precipitation, either 20 inches (510 mm) or more, largely in the form of snow, sometimes 200 inches (510 cm) or more per year.

name: wyoming
sentence: The highest recorded state temperature is 114°F (46°C) at Basin on 12 July 1900 and the lowest recorded temperature is -66°F (−54°C) at Riverside on 9 February 1933.

name: wyoming
sentence: The number of storm days varies from state to state, with the southeastern plains having the greatest number of storm days.

name: wyoming
sentence: Thunderstorm activity in the state was highest in late spring and early summer.

name: wyoming
sentence: The southeastern corner of the State is the most vulnerable part of the State to tornado activity.

name: wyoming
sentence: By moving away from this point and westward, the incidence of tornadoes decreases considerably, with the western part of the state showing little vulnerability.

name: wyoming
sentence: The tornadoes, where they occur, tend to be small and brief, unlike some that occur further east.

name: wyoming
sentence: As indicated in the designation legislation for Wyoming Territory, the boundaries of Wyoming are lines of latitude 41°N and 45°N, and longitude 104°3'W and 111°3'W (27 and 34 west of the Washington Meridian), a geodetic quadrangle.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is one of the only three states (the others being Colorado and Utah) to have borders defined by only "right" lines.

name: wyoming
sentence: Due to the inaccuracy of surveys during the 19th century, the legal boundary of Wyoming deviates from actual latitude and longitude to half a mile (0.8 km) in some places, particularly in the mountainous region along the 45th parallel.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is bounded to the north by Montana, to the east by South Dakota and Nebraska, to the south by Colorado, to the south-west by Utah and to the west by Idaho.

name: wyoming
sentence: It is the tenth largest United States state in total area, containing 97,814 square miles (2533,340 km2) and consists of 23 counties.

name: wyoming
sentence: From the north border to the south border it is 276 miles (444 km)

name: wyoming
sentence: The Great Plains meet the Rocky Mountains in Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: The State is a large plateau broken by many mountain ranges.

name: wyoming
sentence: Surface heights range from the top of the Gannett peak in the Wind River Mountain Range, at 13,804 feet (4,207 m), to the Belle Fork Valley in the northeast corner of the state, at 3,125 feet (952 m).

name: wyoming
sentence: To the northwest are the Absaroka, Owl Creek, Gros Ventre, Wind River and Teton sectors.

name: wyoming
sentence: In the north centre are the Big Horn Mountains; in the northeast, the Black Hills; and in the south, the Laramie, Snowy and Sierra Madre chains.

name: wyoming
sentence: The snow chain in the southern central part of the state is an extension of the Colorado Rockies both in geology and appearance.

name: wyoming
sentence: The range of the Wind River in the western central part of the state is remote and includes more than 40 mountain peaks over 13,000 ft (4,000 m) in addition to the highest peak in the state, Gannett.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Big Horn Mountains, in the central north, are somewhat isolated from most of the Rocky Mountains.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Teton Range in the northwest extends 80 kilometres, part of which is included in Grand Teton National Park.

name: wyoming
sentence: The park includes the Grand Teton, the second peak of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: The continental ditch extends north-south over the entire central part of the State.

name: wyoming
sentence: The rivers east of the ditch flow into the Missouri Basin and possibly into the Gulf of Mexico.

name: wyoming
sentence: These are the North Platte, Wind, Big Horn, and Yellowstone rivers.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Snake River in northwestern Wyoming eventually flows into the Columbia River and Pacific Ocean, as well as the Green River in the Colorado Basin.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Continental Divide fork in the southern central part of the state in an area known as the Grand Divide Basin where water flowing into the ocean or flowing into it cannot reach the ocean – everything sinks into the ground and evaporates.

name: wyoming
sentence: Several rivers begin or cross the state, including the Yellowstone River, the Bighorn River, the Green River, and the Snake River.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming has 32 named islands; the majority are in Jackson and Yellowstone Lakes, Yellowstone National Park, in the northwestern part of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Green River in the southwest also contains a number of islands.

sentence: The United States Census Office has defined two metropolitan statistical zones (MSA) and seven micropolitan statistical zones (MiSA) for the State of Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 2008, 30.4 per cent of Wyomingites lived in either metropolitan statistical area, and 73 per cent lived either in a metropolitan statistical area or in a micropolitan statistical area.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Wind River Indian Reserve is shared by the East Shoshone and North Amerindian Arapaho tribes in the central western part of the state near Lander.

name: wyoming
sentence: The reservation houses 2,500 Shoshone from the East and 5,000 Arapaho from the North.

name: wyoming
sentence: Chief Washakie established the reserve in 1868 following negotiations with the federal government in the Treaty of Fort Bridger.

name: wyoming
sentence: However, the Northern Arapaho were forced by the federal government to the Shoshone Reserve in 1876 after the government did not provide a separate promised reserve.

name: wyoming
sentence: Today, the Wind River Indian Reserve is jointly owned, with each tribe having a 50% interest in land, water and other natural resources.

name: wyoming
sentence: The reserve is a sovereign land, self-managed and has two independent governing bodies: the Eastern Shoshone tribe and the Northern Arapaho tribe.

name: wyoming
sentence: Until 2014, the Shoshone Business Council and the Northern Arapaho Business Council met as the Joint Business Council to decide on issues that affect both tribes.

name: wyoming
sentence: Six elected members of each tribe shall serve on the joint council.

name: wyoming
sentence: Nearly half of Wyoming's land (approximately 30,099,430 acres (121,808.1 km2) is owned by the federal government; the state owns another 3,864,800 acres (15,640 km2).

name: wyoming
sentence: Most are administered by the Bureau of Land Management and the US Forest Service in many national forests and a national grassland, not to mention large areas of "public" land and an air base near Cheyenne.

name: wyoming
sentence: There are also areas run by the National Park Service and agencies such as the United States.

name: wyoming
sentence: Fish and Wildlife Service.

name: wyoming
sentence: Several Amerindian groups originally lived in the area now known as Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Crow, Arapaho, Lakota and Shoshone were just some of the first white explorers to meet during their first visit to the region.

name: wyoming
sentence: What is now the southwest of Wyoming became part of the Spanish Empire, and later the Mexican territory of Alta California, until it was ceded to the United States in 1848 at the end of the war between Mexico and the United States.

name: wyoming
sentence: The French-Canadian trappers of Quebec and Montreal ventured into the area at the end of the 18th century, leaving French toponyms such as Téton and La Ramie.

name: wyoming
sentence: John Colter, a member of the Lewis and Clark Expedition, himself led by Toussaint Charbonneau and his young wife Shoshone, Sacagawea, first described the area in 1807.

name: wyoming
sentence: At the time, his reports on the Yellowstone area were considered fictitious.

name: wyoming
sentence: Robert Stuart and a group of five men, returning from Astoria, discovered the Southern Pass in 1812.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Oregon trail later followed this road.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 1850 Jim Bridger located what is now known as Bridger Pass, which the Union Pacific Railroad used in 1868, as did Interstate 80, 90 years later.

name: wyoming
sentence: Bridger also explored Yellowstone and filed reports on the area, which, like Colter's, were widely regarded as great stories at the time.

name: wyoming
sentence: The region acquired Wyoming's name in 1865, when representative James Mitchell Ashley of Ohio introduced a bill to Congress to provide a "temporary government for Wyoming's territory."

name: wyoming
sentence: The territory was named after the Wyoming Valley of Pennsylvania, made famous by the poem Gertrude of Wyoming of 1809 by Thomas Campbell, based on the Battle of Wyoming in the American Revolutionary War.

name: wyoming
sentence: The name ultimately derives from the word Munsee xwé:wam=nk, meaning "in the great plane of the river".

name: wyoming
sentence: The population of the area continued to grow after the Union Pacific railway reached Cheyenne in 1867, and the federal government created Wyoming territory on 25 July 1868.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming lacked significant gold and silver deposits, unlike the mineral-rich Colorado, and did not experience the associated population growth of Colorado.

name: wyoming
sentence: However, South Pass City experienced a short-lived boom after the Carissa mine began producing gold in 1867.

name: wyoming
sentence: In addition, copper has been mined in some areas between the Sierra Madre Mountains and the snow chain near Grand Encampment.

name: wyoming
sentence: Once the government-sponsored shipments to Yellowstone began, Colter and Bridger's reports, once considered apocryphal, proved true.

name: wyoming
sentence: This led to the creation of Yellowstone National Park, which became the first national park in the world in 1872.

name: wyoming
sentence: Almost all of Yellowstone National Park is within the northwest limit of Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: On December 10, 1869, Governor of the Territory John Allen Campbell extended the right to vote to women, making Wyoming the first territory and, later, the State of the United States, to give women the right to vote.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming has also been a pioneer in welcoming women in politics.

name: wyoming
sentence: Women first served on juries at Wyoming (Laramie, 1870).

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming had the first female judicial officer (Mary Atkinson, Laramie, 1870) and the country's first female justice of the peace (Esther Hobart Morris, South Pass City, 1870).

name: wyoming
sentence: In addition, in 1924 Wyoming became the first state to elect a woman governor, Nellie Tayloe Ross, who took office in January 1925.

name: wyoming
sentence: Due to its history of civil rights, one of Wyoming's nicknames is "The State of Equality", and the state's official motto is "Equal Rights".

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's constitution included women's suffrage and a pioneering article on water rights.

name: wyoming
sentence: Congress admitted Wyoming to the Union as 44th state on 10 July 1890.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming was the site of the Johnson County War in 1892, which broke out between competing groups of cattle breeders.

name: wyoming
sentence: The passage of the Federal Homestead Act has led to an influx of small livestock farmers.

name: wyoming
sentence: A war of scope broke out when either or both of the groups chose a violent conflict over commercial competition in the use of public lands.

sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that Wyoming's population was 578,759 in 2019, Wyoming's population center is in Natrona County.

sentence: In 2014, the U.S. Census Office estimated the racial composition of the population to be 92.7% White (82.9% non-Hispanic whites), 2.7% Alaska Native Americans, 1.6% Blacks or African Americans, 1.0% Asian Americans and 0.1% Hawaii Native Americans or Pacific Islands.

sentence: In 2011, 24.9 per cent of Wyoming's population under 1 year of age were minorities.

sentence: According to the 2010 census, the racial composition of the population was 90.7 per cent White, 0.8 per cent Black or African Americans, 2.4 per cent Alaska Native Americans, 0.8 per cent Asian Americans, 0.1 per cent Hawaiian and other Pacific Islanders, 2.2 per cent of two or more races and 3.0 per cent of another race.

name: wyoming
sentence: Ethnically, 8.9% of the total population was of Hispanic or Latin origin (they can be of any race) and 91.1% non-Hispanic, with non-Hispanic whites constituting the largest non-Hispanic group at 85.9%.

sentence: In 2015, Wyoming had an estimated population of 586,107, an increase of 1,954 (0.29%) from the previous year and 22,481, or 3.99%, since the 2010 census.

name: wyoming

sentence: In 2004, the foreign-born population was 11,000 (2.2%).

sentence: In 2005, the total number of births in Wyoming was 7,231 (birth rate of 14.04 per 1,000).

name: wyoming
sentence: With little population, Wyoming is the least populated state in the United States.

sentence: Wyoming has the second lowest population density in the country (behind Alaska) and is the sparsest population in the 48 contiguous states.

sentence: It is one of only two states (Vermont) whose population is lower than that of the national capital.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Constitution of Wyoming establishes three powers: executive, legislative and judicial.

name: wyoming
sentence: The legislative power of the State consists of a 60-member House of Representatives and a 30-member Senate.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Executive is headed by the Governor and includes a Secretary of State, an Auditor, a Treasurer and a Superintendent of Public Education.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming has no lieutenant governor.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Secretary of State is first on the line of succession.

name: wyoming
sentence: The small population of Wyoming guaranteed him only one seat in the United States House of Representatives and therefore only three votes in the electoral college.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Wyoming State Liquor Association is the only legal distributor of government spirits, making it a state of control over alcoholic beverages.

name: wyoming
sentence: With the exception of wine, state legislation prohibits the purchase of alcoholic beverages for resale from any other source.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's highest court is the Wyoming Supreme Court, with five judges presiding over appeals from lower state courts.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is unusual in the sense that it does not have an intermediate court of appeal, like most states.

name: wyoming
sentence: This is largely due to the population of the State and, consequently, to the reduction in the workload.

name: wyoming
sentence: Appeals from State District Courts are brought directly before the Wyoming Supreme Court.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming also has state district courts (formerly county courts) with limited jurisdiction, which deal with certain types of cases, such as civil claims with lower amounts, criminal offences and criminal proceedings.

name: wyoming
sentence: Itinerant judges are also often referred to cases involving small claims.

name: wyoming
sentence: Prior to 1972, Wyoming judges were chosen by popular vote in a non-partisan election.

name: wyoming
sentence: This earlier system was criticized by the bar, which called for the adoption of the Missouri Plan, a system designed to balance the independence of the judiciary with judicial responsibility.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 1972, an amendment to Article 5 of the Wyoming Constitution, which contains an amended version of the plan, was adopted by voters.

name: wyoming
sentence: Since the adoption of the amendment, all judges of the Wyoming State Courts have been appointed by the Judicial Nominations Commission and appointed by the Governor.

name: wyoming
sentence: They are then subjected to a retention vote by the electorate one year after their appointment.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's political history challenges the easy ranking.

name: wyoming
sentence: The State was the first to grant women the right to vote and elect a woman governor.

name: wyoming
sentence: On December 10, 1869, John Allen Campbell, First Governor of Wyoming Territory, approved the first law in U.S. history explicitly granting women the right to vote.

name: wyoming
sentence: That day was later commemorated as Wyoming Day.

name: wyoming
sentence: On 5 November 1889, voters approved the first constitution in the world which grants women the right to vote in full.

name: wyoming
sentence: While the state elected prominent democrats to the federal office in the 1960s and 1970s, politics became resolutely more conservative since the 1980s, when the Republican Party came to dominate the delegation of the State Congress.

name: wyoming
sentence: Today, Wyoming is represented in Washington by his two senators, John Barrasso and Cynthia Lummis, and his only member of the House of Representatives, MP Liz Cheney.

name: wyoming
sentence: All three are Republicans.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state has not voted for a democrat for a president since 1964, one of only eight times since the establishment of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: At present, there is only one relatively reliable democratic county, the rich Teton, and one swing county, Albany University County.

name: wyoming
sentence: In the 2004 presidential election, George W. Bush won his second win with 69% of the vote.

sentence: Former Vice President Dick Cheney is a resident of Wyoming and represented the state in Congress from 1979 to 1989.

name: wyoming
sentence: Republicans are no less dominant at state level.

name: wyoming
sentence: They have been a majority in the Senate since 1936 and in the State House since 1964.

name: wyoming
sentence: However, the Democrats held the position of governor for all eight years, except between 1975 and 2011.

sentence: The Republicans have the majority of the votes recorded in all but two counties: Albany and Teton, where they have a plurality of registered voters.
